I was behind the counter—I saw the prisoner inside the step of the door—she took this piece of print off the iron railing inside the door, put it under her shawl, and walked off with it—I went out and took her, three doors from the shop, with it hanging below her shawl—I brought her back—she pointed to two other women walking in another direction, and said they took it and gave it to her.
Prisoner. It was hung outside the door. Witness. It was not; it was the extreme piece, but not outside.
JAMES WARD (police-constable G 25.) I took the prisoner, and have the cotton; she said one of the other women took it and gave it her.

Prisoner's Defence. I was by the shop, and two girls took it off and gave it to me—I was going away—the gentleman took and brought me back to the shop—he said, "If you have got any money by you that you were going to purchase it with, I will let you go"—they wanted to search me, but I said no, I had no money.
JOHN LEWIS (City police-constable 581.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

949.
WILLIAM JACKSON and
JOHN RINGER were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of Feb., 1 pair of trowsers, value 9s., the goods of
John Hoskins, and that Ringer had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN HOSKINS . I am a tailor, and live in Marylebone. On the 1st of Feb. I met Mr. Carter, who told me something—I went to my shop, and missed a pair of trowsers that I had hung on a bar, inside, half an hour be
fore—I and Carter ran to the end of George-street, and saw the two pri
soners passing Baker-street, about a quarter of a mile from my shop—we fol
lowed them pretty close—they turned down Adam-street, and about the middle of Adam-street they turned and saw us following them—Jackson turned round short, came back again, and ran into my arms—I stopped him—he said, what do you stop me for—Ringer ran away, and threw a bundle which he had over the area railings; it was picked up, and contained these

trowsers, which was the pair I had lost—Ringer was followed, and a gentle
man stopped him at the corner of Manchester-square—I am quite sure that he is the person that threw away a bundle.
Ringer. Q. Did you see me chuck the trowsers over the railings? A. Yes—I was not round the next corner.

BENJAMIN CARTER . I live in Crawford-street—about twenty minutes past ten on the 1st of Feb. I saw Ringer leaning up against the railings of my father's shop—Jackson came up and spoke to him—he then went back to
wards the prosecutor's—he almost immediately came back and gave Ringer something, and they ran off together—I informed the prosecutor—I am sure they are the men—I followed them to Adam-street, and saw Ringer throw the trowsers over the railings.

Jackson's Defence. I was returning from my sister's, I got to Adam-street; the prosecutor stopped me, and accused me of stealing trowsers, which had not; I was not near the shop; I never saw Ringer before.
Ringer's Defence. I was turning down Adam-street to Manchester-square, and two gentlemen stopped me, because somebody cried "Stop thief."
WILLIAM CUMMING (police-sergeant D 3.) I produce a certificate of Ringer's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

JACKSON—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.

RINGER—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

950.
JAMES STACEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Feb., I handkerchief, value 1s., the property of a certain man, whose name is un
known known, from his person.

FREDERICK MILES (City police-sergeant G 14.) About half-past two o'clock on the 24th of Feb. I was in Newgate-street—I saw the prisoner put his hand into a gentleman's pocket, and take out a handkerchief—he then put it into his hat—I ran across the road and told the gentleman—I then collared the prisoner, and forced him into a shop—the gentleman came into the shop, but said he would not prosecute—I do not know who he was—I have made inquiries.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLAKTINE. Q. Have you no power of insisting on his going? A. No—he went out of the shop—I kept the handkerchief—I should know him again.
NOT GUILTY .

951.
JAMES FLOCKTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 3 gowns, value 2l.; 5 shawls, 3l. 4s.; 1 shift, 2s.; 1 bed-gown, 3s. 6d.; 2 petticoats, 4s.; 1 tippet, 6d.; 1 apron, 1s.; 1 pair of earrings, 1l.; 15s.; 1 necklace, 7s.; 1 ring, 8s.; and 1 buckle, 2s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Blunt: and 20 yards of linen cloth, value 2l.; 1 set of bed-furniture, 7s.; 3 shawls, 1l. 10s.; 2 veils, 7s.; 1 petticoat, 2s.; 1 shift, 2s.; 1 pair of shoes, 3s.; 6d.; 1 carpet-bag, 2s.; 6d.; and 3 gowns, 2l. 5s.; the goods of
William Blunt.

ELIZA BLUNT . I live in Copthall-court—I had these things safe about half-past twelve o'clock on the 24th of Feb., in the third floor—the door of the room was locked—I missed the things—the street-door was always open—the bed-room door lock was picked—these are my things and my mo
ther's—her husband's name is William Blunt.

STEPHEN QUESTED (City police-constable 171.) I was on duty, going up Angel-court, and saw two men standing there—when I got close to them, one put his hand into his pocket and gave the other 6d.—he went away—I watched them, and one was peeping round the corner—I stopped a few minutes, and then saw the prisoner and another person proceeding along Throgmorton-street

with a carpet bag, I then saw the other two that I had seen before—the prisoner and the other called a cab—I went and took them—this bundle I found on the prisoner—the one who had the carpet-bag got away—these are the things I found on the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Had you seen me with one of the others? A. I had before that day, but not then.

Prisoner's Defence. There are a parcel of men going about teazing boys to rob their masters, and then when they see the boys taken they are off-I was standing, and a young man came and asked me to carry a bundle to a cab—he took me into some passage—he went up stairs, and fetched two bundles down—gave me the biggest, and went on with the carpet-bag to a cab—he put his bag in, and then I put the bag in—the policeman came—he said he was going to Mr. Davis—he went to catch him, and he ran off—I told him the man hired me to take a bundle to the cab.

STEPHEN QUESTED (re-examined.) I had seen the prisoner and the others together, but not that day—the prisoner threw something over a hoarding, and it was this necklace—this buckle be threw behind me when I took him.

GUILTY . * Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

952.
WILLIAM GUNN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 5s., the goods of
Alfred Frisby.

JOHN RODMELL . I am servant to Mr. Alfred Frisby, a boot and shoe maker, in White Lion-street, Clerkenwell—between five and six o'clock on the 8th of Feb. I received information—I went outside, and overtook the pri
soner, thirty or forty yards from the door—he just turned the corner—I found on him these boots, which are my master's.
Cross-examined by MR. FRAZER. Q. Where were they hanging up? A. Inside, on the door-post.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Seven Days.

953.
MARY GURD was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Feb., 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; 4 half-crowns, and 4 shillings; the property of
Dorothy Quick, from her person.

DOROTHY QUICK . I live in Plough-court, Fetter-lane. About one o'clock, on the 10th of Feb., the prisoner came to me, and I went out with her—I had four half-crowns, four shillings, and a handkerchief—she said she was badly off, and almost starved, and begged me to give her something to drink, which I did—when I came out she and I stood in the street together, and when I came home she followed me home, and asked for something to eat—I went up stairs, got her some tea and meat—she staid till four o'clock—I said I was going on an errand—I locked the door, and came down—she came down, and walked with me, and in going home she asked me to lend her some money—I said I could not, but I would give her some more to drink—I did so—after I parted with her, at the corner of the court, I went home, and went to sleep—at half-past eight o'clock next morning I had not a farthing to go to market with—I know I had the money when I went in-doors—I went and asked her for my money—she said she had not had it, or seen me since half-past eight.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you mean you had noticed your money when you went into your room? A. Yes—she wanted to borrow a sixpence of me at the corner of the court—I put my hand into my pocket, and had no sixpence—I then had my money safe—I could not have dropped it—I first mentioned at Guildhall that I had lost four half-crowns and four shillings—I told the policeman that I had lost 14s.—I did not recollect

what money I had till after I went home—I do not recollect when first men
tioned that I had four half-crowns—I mentioned it at Guildhall, but not after I had heard what money was found—I neither heard from the officer nor saw that there were four half-crowns—I said I had lost 14s. at the station—I did not mention four half-crowns at the station—I was puzzled, as they were all in favour of the prisoner, because she lives opposite to them—she was let out of the station—they released her after I gave her in charge—I know I put four half-crowns and four shillings into this pocket, and about a shilling's worth of halfpence in another—I got rid of all the halfpence—I did not spend more than 1s. in drink.

MARY ANN WILMOTT . I am fourteen years old, and live in this court. I was going on an errand at five minutes past nine o'clock—I saw the prisoner go up, and go into Mrs. Quick's room, and when I came back I saw her coming down.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know the prisoner? A. Yes—I have seen her a great many times—when she came to Mrs. Quick's I could not see her face very well—she was dressed in a dark gown, I cannot say what—I saw her face when she came at four o'clock that afternoon, and I saw her face that night as she was coming in and going out.

THOMAS EAVES (City police-constable, No. 303.) I searched the prisoner's room, and found four half-crowns and four shillings in this bag—the handker
chief has not been found.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it true that, after she gave the prisoner in charge, you released her? A. Yes—the inspector was gone to the chief office, and if I had stopped there I should have left my duty—the sergeant told me to leave her in charge of the station clerk—I believe she went home—I did not hear the prosecutrix say anything about the half-crowns—she said she had lost 15s., and after the charge was given she altered it to 14s.

COURT. Q. What did she say she had lost? A. She said the had lost about 15s.—she was not able to say what coin it was in, but I believe she saw it on the table—when the clerk took the charge I did not hear her say anything about any half-crowns.

JOHN SMITH . I am foreman to Mr. Gurney, a wine and spirit-merchant, in Farringdon-street. On the 5th of Feb. the prisoner gave me a sovereign in this bag to change—she came tipsy in a cab—I gave her four half-crowns and eight shillings—I paid a cabman 2s. for her ride—she had come some distance—she sells fruit in the street—she will keep sober for a month, and then break out.
NOT GUILTY .

954.
JOHN VICKERS and
WILLIAM SIMMONDS were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of Feb., 11lbs. weight of mutton, value 4s., the goods of
Samuel Matthews; and that Simmonds had been before convicted of felony.

DAVID LESTER . I am in the employ of Samuel Matthews, a butcher, in Newgate-market. On Saturday night, the 4th of Feb., I saw the prisoners together—they went into the shop, and came out—I saw Vickers take from the board a pair of necks of mutton—I let them go about three yards from the shop—I went after Vickers, touched him on the shoulder, and asked what. he had got there—he said, "Nothing"—he let the necks of mutton fall down by his feet—Simmonds said he was going to take them to the next shop to get them weighed—neither of them had asked a word about the price.
Vickers. Q. How is your shop situated? A. It runs down on each side—the gates go across it—the mutton weighed 9lbs.

WILLIAM KEMP (City police-constable, No. 225.) I took the prisoners—Simmonds said he had been with Vickers all the evening, and that they went to buy something for dinner, and were going to take the meat to the next shop to weigh; and he said, "You are very well, but you have not got us right this time"—I said, "You must go to the station with me, and if you can clear your friend you will be set at liberty."

Simmonds. The master gave no charge of me; he did of Vickers, who is my brother-in-law; I went to the master, and said, "It was my fault; it laid at the corner of the board, and I said it belonged to the next shop;"there was no one in the prosecutor's shop; I went to the station, and stated the case, and said I was in my brother's company from half-past six o'clock till that time; the inspector said, "I shall take charge of you;" my brother had no more intention of stealing the meat than he has now; I was never given in charge; the policeman said to me, "It is no use going in, you can do the prisoner no good, he is sure to be locked up;" the meat was on the corner of the board joining the two shops.

DAVID LESTER
re-examined. There were five persons inside my master's shop—I was outside, minding the meat—this meat was lying inside the shop—they could not have been mistaken as to which shop it belonged to—there are places between the two, about seven feet high—it was very good Scotch mutton—I value it at 3 1/2 d. per lb.

Vickers. The two pieces of mutton were lying on one side of the counter, and I said to my brother, "Will you have one of these?"—he said, "Yes"—I took them up, and I dare say I was not three yards off when the witness came and took me by the arm—I then went back to his master, who said, "Stand there, you d----d rascal; I will give you a night's lodging if I can give you nothing else"—I had 2s. 5 1/2 d. about me—I could buy it at 3d. a pound at any shop in the market—there was a witness to prove that I was in the act of turning into the shop, and I desired him to be called, but they would not let him—he gave me his word that he would be here, and speak.

DAVID LESTER
re-examined. There was no witness at all.
WILLIAM KEMP . There were a number of persons outside—he was asked if he had any friends or witnesses, and he said he had not.
WILLIAM BROWN CROSS (police-constable G 217.) I produce a certificate of Simmonds's former conviction, which I got from the Sessions'-house, at Clerkenwell—(read)—he is the person.

VICKERS*—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

SIMMONDS*—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi:
Fifth Jury, before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
955.
HENRY EDWARDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Feb., 1 pair of trowsers, value 10s.; 1 pair of studs, 1s. 6d.; and 1 hand
kerchief, 2d.; the goods of
John De Ruzario; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Two Months.

956.
JOHN CRONIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Feb., 3 3/4lbs. weight of sugar, value 2s., the goods of
John Fairrie and others, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined One Month.

957.
GEORGE EDWINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Feb., 11 shillings, the monies of
Rowland Charles Hurley; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

958.
JOHN STEVENS and
JACOB WATSON were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 10th of Feb., 10lbs. weight of suet, value 3s.; and 42lbs. weight of fat, 12s.; the goods of
George Jeffery, the master of John Stevens.

GEORGE JEFFERY . I am a butcher, and live at Knightsbridge—Stevens was in my employ between four and five years. On the 10th of Feb. he was sent with my cart and horse with some fat to Elborough's, a tallow
melter, in South Audley-street—he had no authority to dispose of it to any one else—I saw him start between four and five o'clock in the afternoon.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. Did you give an order that he should take the fat to the tallow-chandler's that day? A. Yes—I think it was about four o'clock—I saw the fat put into the cart by him, and one of my other servants.

GEORGE PHILLIPS . I am a butcher, and was in the employ of the pro
secutor—I am not now. About ten minutes to five o'clock on the evening of the 10th of Feb., I saw Stevens coming up Piccadilly with Mr. Jeffery's cart, alone—he turned round Park-lane, then stopped the horse, and took Watson up into the cart—Watson had an empty bag—Stevens then drove up Park-lane, turned down Hertford-street, and stopped about four minutes—they then took some fat out of the cart, and put it into Watson's bag, and went a little way, then Watson got out, and Stevens handed him a bag of fat on the shafts of the cart, and Watson came down towards Hertford-street—I followed, and gave him in charge of a policeman—I went with him to the station—I then came with a, policeman down to Mr. Jeffery's, and took Stevens.

Cross-examined. Q. When were you in Mr. Jeffery's employ? A. I left the last time about three weeks before Christmas—I have not been in employ since—I did not leave on a charge of robbery that 1 am aware of—I have no idea at all what I left for, my master never assigned any reason—I had been working for him nine or ten months on and off, but at this time I had been there five weeks regularly—I never was told that I left on suspicion of having robbed my master—I am not aware that Stevens detected me in the act of stealing from my master—I never robbed him of anything—there were wages due to me when I went away, which my master paid, and said when he wanted me again he would send for me—I did not ask for a charac
ter—since I left him I have lived upon my friends—my mother has sent me up money when I wrote—she lives at Southampton—I cannot tell when I wrote to her last, or what was the last amount of money I had from her, whether it was a bank note, or gold, silver, or copper—I knew Mr. Jeffery's horse and cart—the horse was walking when I first saw it—I lodge with Mr. Lloyd, Lancelot-place, Brompton—there was no question made about a leg of mutton, or a shoulder when I was with my master.

JOHN DEANE (police-constable C 97.) About five o'clock in the after
noon of the 10th of Feb. I was on duty—I was called by Phillips—in con
sequence of what he told me I followed him down Hertford-street—he pointed out Watson—I went and took him—he had this bag, containing fat—I asked what it was—he said fat, he had bought it from different persons—I said I thought it had been stolen, he must go with me to the station—he said the same at the station—I went to Mr. Jeffery's with Phillips, and took Stevens.
NOT GUILTY .

959.
JOHN WELLESLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Feb., 2 dead pigeons, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Hawes; and, that he had been before convicted of felony.
WILLIAMS HAWES . I am a poulterer, living in Paddington-street. I had

two pigeons in the shop window at five o'clock in the evening of the 7th of Feb.—I missed them when the policeman came about half-past five, and saw them on the pavement, about four or five doors from my house—an officer picked them up—they were mine.

WILLIAM ROSS (police-constable D 157.) I was on duty in Paddington-street, and saw the prisoner walk by the shop two or three times—he snatched the pigeons, put them under his smock, and ran away—I ran, and he dropped them—I took him, and brought him back to the shop—a brother officer picked them up, and they were shown to the prosecutor.
THOMAS COWAN (police-constable D 206.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person—I was present at his trial.

GUILTY . * Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

960.
JOHN BUCKLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Feb., 1 metal cock, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
William Hay, his master.

FREDERICK JOSEPH HARDING . I am barman to Mr. William Hay, a li
censed victualler, in Porter-street, Soho. The prisoner was in his employ occasionally for three or four years, doing the pewterer's work—on the 14th of Feb. I was with him in the cellar—he was at work from half-past three to four o'clock, making a joint to a pewter pipe, but not about this cock—I saw it there—it is my master's—I left the prisoner in the cellar—he came up, and went away—I went into the cellar three or four minutes after, and missed the cock.

HENRY MULLONY . I am a copper-smith, and live in Upper St. Martin's-lane. On the 14th of Feb., from two to five o'clock in the afternoon, the pri
soner brought this cock for sale, and knowing him, I bought it.
ROBERT TAYLOR (police-constable F 37.) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I met some friends, and was very tipsy. I managed to make a joint in the cellar some how. This would not have happened if I had not been in liquor.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

961.
HENRY THOMPSON and
TIMOTHY SILK were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February, 2 1/4lbs. weight of pork, value 1s. 3d. the goods of
James House; and that Thompson had been before convicted of felony; to which

SILK pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

JAMES. I am a cheesemonger, living in Munster-street, Regent's-park. On the 20th of Feb. I received information, and went to Clarence-gardens, about ten yards from my house, and saw the prisoners together—there was another, but he was not close to them—Silk had the piece of pork—he looked at it, and put it under his jacket—he saw me, and threw it over the palings into the gardens—I ran, took Silk, came back, and took Thompson—it was my pork, and was taken from my stall-board, in front of the window—I saw it about a minute before.

JOHN CHAPMAN MASON . I live opposite the prosecutor, and saw the two prisoners and another close to the shop, together—Silk went from the others, took the pork, and walked off—the other two followed him down the gardens—I told the prosecutor, and went with him after them—I saw the prisoners together in Clarence-gardens—Mr. House's son got over the palings, and got the pork.
GEORGE ALLEN (police-constable S 77.) The two prisoners were brought to the station—Thompson said he knew nothing about it—Silk said nothing.
Thompsons Defence. I saw somebody run by; I turned, and saw the shop-keeper run; I went to see what was the matter; some one said, "I think this is one." I know nothing about it.

THOMAS HOWARD (police-constable E 139.) I produce a certificate of Thompson's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—Thompson is the person—he was tried by the name of George Butcher.

THOMPSON—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

962.
CHARLOTTE PAMPHILION and
EMMA JACKSON were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 15th of Feb., 9 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 4s., the goods of
Thomas Butler.

EDWARD LLOYD . I am assistant to Thomas Butler, a linen-draper, in High-street, Shoreditch. On the 15th of Feb. the prisoners came into the shop together—they wanted to see some cotton dresses—I showed them a quantity—Pamphilion placed one on the top of the others on the counter; then Jackson opened one, and covered those that were placed on the top of the others with it—I laid hold of the dress that was covering the others, folded it up, and told her she did not want it open—Pamphilion then pointed my attention to a dress that was in the fixture behind me, and before I turned round to reach it, I cast my eye on the quantity that were on the counter—I then turned my back to the counter, and took the piece from behind—I re
turned to the counter, and missed one off the counter—I showed them the dress I brought down—I afterwards went out of sight, to the other shop, told one of the young men what I thought, and gave him instructions to go out
side—when I returned, Jackson was pointing to a dress that Pamphilion had on—she wanted one similar to that—I said I had not got one, but very likely I should have one in a day or two—one of them then said, "Are you sure?"—I said, "Very likely"—"Don't deceive us?" said one—they then went out, and I went behind the counter to see if the dress had dropped down—in the mean time the other shopman had stopped them at the door—I took them towards the counting-house—there is a desk at the end of the shop, just by the door, and a small place where the cashier goes into—Pamphilion moved on one side, and in that place I picked up the dress—she had passed that place—it was not near where I had shown them the dresses—this is the dress—it is my master's—it is one that was shown at the counter.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You had not examined that place by the desk before? A. No.

STEPHEN REEVE (police-constable G 49.) On the 15th I went into the shop, and found the prisoners—I took them into the waiting-room at the police-court—Pamphilion, in the hearing of Jackson, asked if I thought she would be transported—I said I did not know—she said the man found the dress on her—I said, "You did take it, then?"—she said, "Yes, and he found it on me."
Cross-examined. Q. Who was present? A. No one—I had not asked her any questions.

HARRIET HAYWARD . I am searcher at the station—I found 2s. on Jack
son—she said she was given in charge for stealing a gown-piece, but she did not take it; the other young woman took it, and the gentleman saw her.
(Pamphilion received a good character.)

PAMPHILION—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

JACKSON—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
963.
WILLIAM FAULKENER was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Feb., 1 sovereign, the monies of
John Thomas Bowden, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Seven Days, and
Whipped.

964.
JOHN HARPER was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

965.
JOHN WRIGHT was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 55.—
Confined Six Months.

966.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

967.
THOMAS MATTHEW BRADSHAW was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . * Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months.

968.
MARY ANN HAYES was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of Dec., 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
William Gregory, her master; and
ELLEN HAYES
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

M. A. HAYES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Month.

E. HAYES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Nine Months.

969.
WILLIAM SHAW was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

REBECCA GROVE . I am the wife of John Dove Grove, a licensed victualler, who lives in Broad-street, St. Giles. On the 29th of Jan., in the afternoon, the prisoner came for a pennyworth of gin—I served him, and he gave me a bad sixpence—I bent it, and gave it to my husband—the prisoner then showed me a good sixpence—I asked if he would pay for it out of that; he said no, he would not.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What did you do with the bad six
pence? A. My husband broke it in two and gave it to the policeman—I had not laid it down anywhere.

JOHN DOVE GROVE . I am the husband of Rebecca Grove. I saw the prisoner in my house—I accused him of having given a bad sixpence—he said that was not the sixpence he gave her; that she had put that into the till and rung the changes with him—I sent for a constable, marked the bad sixpence, and gave it him.

WILLIAM BARRETT (police-constable F 87.) On the 29th of Jan. I took the prisoner—I found on him a good sixpence—Mr. Grove delivered this bad sixpence to me—the prisoner was taken to the police office, and discharged the next day.
Cross-examined. Q. The whole of the case was stated? A. Yes; I have kept this bad sixpence ever since.

MARIA EVELING MOTT . I am servant to Mr. Taylor, who lives in the Arcade, Hungerford-market. On the 4th of Feb. the prisoner came in the even
ing for a penny bun, and gave me a bad sixpence—I looked at it and bit it—
he said it was a good one—I said I did not think it was—I gate it to my master—I went for a policeman, and when I came back the prisoner was gone.

WILLIAM HAYWARD TAYLOR . I am Mott's master—on the 4th of Feb. she gave me a bad sixpence—the prisoner asked me to take for the bun out of a good sixpence—I refused, and sent for a policeman—one came before Mott returned, and I gave the sixpence and the prisoner to him.
WILLIAM BOYCE (police-sergeant F 17.) On the 4th of Feb. I took the prisoner, and Mr. Taylor gave me this sixpence—I found a good sixpence on the prisoner.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these sixpences are both counterfeit.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . * Aged 17.—
Confined Nine Months.

970.
RICHARD HENRY STOPFORD was indicted
for uttering coun
terfeit coin.

ANN WEEKS . I am the wife of Benjamin Weeks, a tobacconist, in Dean-street, Westminster—on the 3rd of Feb. the prisoner came and bought some
thing—he paid me half-a-crown—I put it in my drawer—I afterwards gave it to my husband; he bent it, and laid it in the same drawer again—I after
wards gave it to the policeman—it had not been mixed with any other coin.
COURT. Q. Was there any other half-crown in the drawer? A. No.
Prisoner. She says it was on the 3rd of Feb. and it was on the 1st—I went in for half an ounce of tobacco.
WILLIAM CLIFTON (police-constable B 50.) On the 17th of Feb. I received from Mrs. Weeks this half-crown.
SARAH GLOVER . I am a cow-keeper. On the 15th of Feb. I saw a person, but I really cannot recollect the prisoner.

GEORGE GLOVER . I am the son of Sarah Glover. On the 15th of Feb. the prisoner came into my mother's shop, and for what he bought he tendered my mother a counterfeit half-crown—I detained him, and when the officer passed I gave him into custody, with the half-crown—I am sure it was the one the prisoner gave to my mother, and she brought it to me.

ADAM DUNT (police-constable B 170.) On the 15th of Feb. the prisoner was given into my custody—I took him to Queen-square, and he was let out on his own recognizances to appear on the Monday following, but he did not come—I took him next day—this is the half-crown I received from Mr. Glover.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

971.
ROBERT WARD was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

MARIA EVELING MOTT . I am servant to Mr. Taylor—on the 10th Feb. the prisoner came to my master's shop—he gave me a bad shilling—I bit it, and gave it to my master—he cut it in two, then came to the prisoner and gave him one of the halves—the prisoner said he had no right to cut it—I went for an officer.
WILLIAM HAYWARD TAYLOR . I have heard the evidence which Mott has given—it is correct—I gave the prisoner to the policeman.

HENRY CASTLE (police-constable F 135.) On the 10th of Feb., I was called and took the prisoner—Mr. Taylor gave me this half of a shilling—I asked the prisoner if he had any more about him—he said no he had not,
and I should not search him till I got to the station—I put my hand into his pocket, and found another bad shilling—he said a sailor gave them to him for carrying a parcel—he had no good money.
MR. JOHN FIELD . This shilling is counterfeit, and this is half of another counterfeit shilling.

GUILTY . * Aged 17.—
Confined Nine Months.

972.
MARY ALLEN was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

JOHN WILLIAM WORLEY . I am servant to Mr. Stannard, who keeps the York Hotel, in Covent-garden. On the 18th of Feb., I saw the prisoner—she gave me a counterfeit crown-piece—I did not discover whether it was bad or not—I immediately gave it to Mr. Stannard—on the 22nd, she came again, and gave me a counterfeit crown—I gave it to Mr. Stannard—on the 28th, she came again, and threw down a crown-piece on the counter—Mr. Stannard took it up, looked at it, and told her it was bad, and that she had brought two before—she repeated the word "bad?" five times over—Mr. Stannard then asked where she brought it from—she said from across the Park, and then said a gentleman in the Strand gave it her.

WILLIAM STANNARD . I received a crown-piece on the 18th, 22nd, and 28th of Feb.—the two first I received from Worley—the last I took from the prisoner myself—I did not discover that the first was bad till I had paid it away, and it was brought back to me after I had received the second one—I then compared them, and found they were precisely the same—I wrapped them up in paper, and put them in a small drawer—I gave all three to Walter.

CHARLES WALTER (police-constable F 138.) On the 28th of Feb., 1 re
ceived a crown-piece from Mr. Stannard—I marked it, and then he gave me these other two.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are all counterfeit, and I believe were all cast in one mould.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

973.
JOHN GROVES was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

JOHN M'CORMICK . I live on Ludgate-hill. About one o'clock on the 2nd of Feb., the prisoner came to my shop and tendered me a good half-crown—I gave him a pencil he had asked for, and two shillings in change—without looking at the pencil, he said that was not the sort he wanted, and described one that I never saw—I said I had not one, and he returned me the pencil, and two shillings—I saw that one of them was a bad one—he ran out but the pavement being slippery he fell down—I overtook and brought him back—he struggled violently to get away—I had one shilling in each hand—he strained both the backs of my hands, and I saw he swallowed something—my wife came to assist me, and he bit the back of her hand—I gave the bad shilling which the prisoner returned to me to the officer—I swear it was not one of those I gave him, as I had my money spread out on a green cloth under the sky-light, as I was going to send for the beer for dinner, and I can swear in the most positive manner that all the silver I had was good—I had four shillings, and one half-crown.

Prisoner. Q. Did you inspect them at the time you gave them to me? A. I did not—I called after you as you were going out—my shop is long—you might be six yards from the door when I served you—I called instantly after you—I think you heard me, and the attempt you made to go out proved it—you endeavoured to snatch the two shillings from my hands—I returned you the half-crown.
COURT. Q. Do you think he swallowed the half-crown? A. No—I hink he swallowed the good shilling I gave him.

Prisoner. Q. Did you see any other shilling about me? A. No—you took good care by having no bottoms to your trowsers pockets, that no money should be found on you—they were merely conductors, not pockets.
JOHN DEAR (City police-constable, No. 279.) I took the prisoner, and received this shilling from Mr. M'Cormick.
MR. JOHN FIELD . This is a counterfeit shilling.

Prisoner. Is it a thing impossible for that man to give me two shillings, and one to be bad, and the other good, and he not to know it? he may be mis
teken as well as anybody else.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

974.
GEORGE TITFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Feb., 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Charles Crouch, from his per
son: also, 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of John Bird, from his person: to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

975.
EDMUND SKINNER was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Feb., 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
James Francis Thompson.

FREDERICK COLLINS . I am in the employ of Mr. James Francis Thompson, a pawnbroker, in East-street, St. Marylebone. On the 21st of Feb. the pri
soner offered a handkerchief to pledge for 1s. 6d.—I lent him 1s. on it—he then went to the back of the shop, and I served another person—he then came to the counter and inquired if I had given him the shilling—I said yes, and he left the shop—previous to his coming to the counter the second time I had seen him put something into his pocket—I missed a handkerchief—I followed, and overtook him about twenty-five yards off—I found this hand
kerchief on him.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you know it? A. Yes—it is an unredeemed pledge, and hung at the back of the shop—I had noticed it two or three minutes before he came in—it is worth 2s.—the hand
kerchief was taken from his hand—I cannot say whether I took in this hand
kerchief originally, but I have bad it in my hand several times—we have no other of the same description—I will swear that when the prisoner came into our shop it was hanging on the line—I had noticed it two or three minutes before, as I was looking round the shop—there was a woman and a policeman in the shop when the prisoner came in—there was another young man in the shop, who took the report of the policeman, and I served the prisoner, and then another customer—I cannot recollect whether the woman that I served went out before the prisoner—our shop had not been very full—I attended to a female after I had paid the prisoner—I think she pawned a shawl—I do not recollect what she wanted on it—I had some discussion with the prisoner—he asked 1s. 6d., and I offered him 9d.—he said that would not do, and I gave him 1s.—I might have been a minute or two talking with him—I think it was not four or five minutes—I was serving him in front of the shop—there was a partition between him and the boxes—this handkerchief was in front of me as I was behind the counter, and this handkerchief was behind him—it was tied round a string—it would not undo with pulling—when I went after the prisoner I tapped him on the shoulder, and told him he must come back to the shop with me—he had this handkerchief in his hand—he said, "This is what you want, I suppose"—he added, at the police-office, that he had picked it up in the passage.
COURT. Q. Are you sure you saw this handkerchief two or three minutes before he came in, safe on the line? A. Yes.
ARTHUR GORE (police-constable D 199.) I took the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you the policeman who was in the shop? A. Yes—I was giving a description of some stolen property—I saw Collins in the shop—he served the prisoner—I was in uniform, and the prisoner must have seen me—he spoke to me—he said he had picked up the handkerchief near the door, and after that he said a woman gave it him in the street—he did not say he had followed a woman whom he thought had dropped it—he might have said that to the prosecutor, but if he did it was before I took him—he was exceedingly confused and alarmed when I took him—(examination read)—"The prisoner say, 'In going out I saw a handkerchief in the pas
sage; I asked a woman if it was hers; she said no; I asked anotherwoman; the witness came and tapped me on the shoulder.' "
NOT GUILTY .

976.
SARAH ROBINSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Feb., 1 chisel, value 8d. the goods of
Charles Fowler and another.

ALFRED PENNY . I am shopman to Mr. Charles Fowler and another, pawnbrokers, Old-street. On the 9th of Feb., about seven o'clock, I was standing at the door—I saw the prisoner and a man come up-I saw the man steal some chisel., and give some to the prisoner, who was alongside of him—I caught hold of the prisoner at the end of the stall—she got from me twice, but I caught her again—the man then came up, knocked me down, and said, "You b----, if you don't let her go I will kill you"—I got up and ran after her, down a court—the tools were chuked away when I was knocked down—this chisel was found by a boy in the road—he gave it to the ploliceman.

cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Were these things outside? Yes—Old-street is rather crowded sometimes—the man had some of the tools—the pri
soner had this one in her hand, and it dropped when I was knokced down.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) I accompanied Penny to Wake
field-place, in Bunhill-row, and found the prisoner in a privy—this chisel was picked up in my presence by a child.

ALFRED PENNY
re-examined. I had never seen the prisoner before—I have not the least doubt of her being the person—she had got as far as Wakefield—place, which is two or three minutes walk from our shop.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined six Months.

977.
CHARLOTTE BURTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Jan., 2 sheets, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Johnson.

ANN JOHNSON . I am the wife of Robert Johnson, we live in Upper Corn
wall-street, St. George's in the East—the prisoner took a furnished room of me in Sep. or Oct. last—I missed two sheets which were used in her room—I have sent her to pawn things, but never gave her permission the pledge these—after she left me I went to her and asked if she would bring the sheets back—she said I must wait her pleasure for them—I went again, and she gave me some very abusive language, and again told me I must wait her pleasure—these are the sheets—here is a mark on one of them, and the other I know to be mine.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not lend me the first sheet to pledge? A. No—I did not stant at the door with my umbrella when you came from the pawnbrokers—I did not hand you the last sheet—you did not ask me what you should do for a wrapper, and I did not take off my apron and wrap the sheet in it.
COURT. Q. Did you directly or indirectly autlhorise her to pledge either of the sheets? A. No, I swear I did not—I did not know she had pledged

them, nor have any of the money for them—she left me without notice, and left a fortnight's rent unpaid—I went and told her if she would bring the sheets, and make arrangement to pay for the things she had broken, I would forgive her the rent.
ARTHUR HOULGATE . I am in the service of a pawnbroker. This sheet was pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of Jan., in the name of Ann Johnson.
HENRY KINGSFORD . I am in the service of a pawnbroker. I produce a sheet pawned by a woman on the 9th of Jan., in the name of Ann Johnson.
Prisoner's Defence. This woman persuaded me to leave my friends, and go to live with her; she is only a brother keeper.

ANN JOHNSON
re-examined. I never kept such a house in my life—I keep a respectable house—the prisoner came to me and said she had been keeping her father's house, and had left him—she begged I would give her a night's lodging—I never suffer men and women to come to my house.

ANN CHANDLER . I am an unfortunate girl, the same as the prisoner, and Mrs. Johnson as she calls herself; she is married, but is living with a man who is not her husband; she said in my presence, that the lent the prisoner the sheets, and we treated her with a quartern of gin.
NOT GUILTY .

978.
WILLIAM FOLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Feb., 1 5l. Bank-note, the monies of
John Innan.

JOHN INNAN . I am in the service of the Marquis of Headfort. On the 9th of Feb., about half-past twelve o'clock, I was in a public-house with Daniel Rutherford, to whom I gave a 5l. note to pay for a pint of ale—the prisoner was the boy at the house—I saw him receive the note from Ruther
ford—he then left the room, and did not return—I never saw him again till he was at Queen-square.
WILLIAM FREEMAN . I live in Pond-street, Chelsea. The prisoner was desired to come to me for change and he never came.

JAMES BENNETT (police-constable R 243.) I took the prisoner in Church-street, Deptford, on the morning of the 10th of Feb.—he was drunk—the inspector taxed him with this—he denied it—he was asked if he lived at such a place in London—he denied that he did, but he was brought to London—he then said he received the note, and when he came out of the door he took a better thought, and thought he would keep it.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Nine Months.

979.
JAMES ALEXANDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Feb., 15lbs. weight of pork, value 8s. 9d., the goods of
John Clisby; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ALEXANDER BLACKETT . I am journeyman to Mr. John Clisby, of Corn
wall-terrace, Camden-town, a pork-butcher. On the 11th of Feb. he had four hands and springs of pork outside the window—I saw them safe at five o'clock, and missed two of them at ten at night—I can swear that the pieces which are here are part of them.
GEORGE WILSON (police-constable S 134.) I met the prisoner about half-past six on the 11th of Feb.—he had a bag on his shoulder with this pork in it.
JOHN EATON (police-constable S 193.) I produce the certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

980.
JAMES BOND was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Feb., 2 to
bacco pouches, value 1s., the goods of
John Evans.

JOHN EVANS . I am a tobacconist, and live in Munster-street, Regent's-park. On the evening of the 21st of Feb. the policeman brought the prisoner into my shop—I examined, and missed two tobacco pouches—he produced them to me—these are mine.
THOMAS KENDALL (police-constable S 69.) I had been watching the prisoner. I took him into the shop, and found these pouches in his trowsers pocket.
Prisoner. I bought them of a young man at the window. Witness. There was no one with him.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

981.
GEORGE TABRAR was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of Feb., 1 wheel, value 10s., the goods of
Daniel Coales.
DANIEL COALES . I live in Gray's-inn-lane, and am a smith. I missed a wheel from a store-cellar—I found it at the station—this is it—I have the mill belonging to it.

JOHN RUSSELL (police-constable G 165.) I found this wheel in the pos
session of the prisoner on the 11th of Feb.—he stated that it belonged to a lathe he had.
Prisoner. He did not find it on me. Witness. He was wheeling it along the street—there were three of them, and they took it by turns to wheel it.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

982.
JANE WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Feb., 26 yards of lace, value 2l., the goods of
John Nott.

ANN CHANDLER . I am in the service of Mr. James Nott, who keeps a lace shop in Upper-street, Islington. About four o'clock on the 16th of Feb. the prisoner and another woman came into the shop—the other woman asked me to show them some quilling net, and I showed it them in a box—I cut off a yard and a half at one price, and three yards at a halfpenny a yard—the boxes were then put away—the other woman then asked to look at some lace—I showed them a variety of lace—the prisoner and the other both looked at it, but none of it suited—while they were deciding, the prisoner took some lace—I saw her make a movement, and put it under her shawl—l am sure I saw the lace under her shawl, and I missed three cards of it, but I said no
thing—the other woman then decided on one, and bought a yard and a half at 1s. a yard—I then cleared all away, and the other woman offered me a sovereign to give her change, and take 2s. for what she had bought—there was not sufficient change in the till, and I gave it out of my pocket—the prisoner remarking that she had nothing but notes and gold about her, or she would lend the other a small sum—after I had made up the parcel, and given the change, I desired the lad to take the three cards of lace from under the prisoner's shawl, and I saw him do so—the prisoner said, "I humbly beg your pardon, Miss," and then I let them go—she had taken the cards of lace from the counter—she had a bad hand—it was wrapped up in a handkerchief—she leaned that on the counter, and her shawl was over that hand—she made a movement and took them—if the cards had been knocked down ac
cidentally they would have fallen—they remained under her shawl about a quarter of an hour.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was it not said at the time that she must have dragged the lace up with her shawl? A. The other woman said it must have been so—I allowed them to go away—I missed three cards
of lace from the counter—I did not see the prisoner take anything up, but I saw her make a sweep and sweep off some lace—I did not see where it went to—I was on the other side of the counter.
JOHN TRACEY . I am servant to Mr. Nott. I took the three cards of lace from close under the prisoner's arm.
Cross-examined. What sort of a shawl had she on? A. A blue woollen shawl with black spots—the lace was close under her right arm.

GUILTY . * Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

983.
MARY WYNNE was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Feb., 1 shawl, value 2s.; and 1 bonnet, 2s.; the goods of
Mary Anne Cooke, her mistress; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

MARY ANN COOKE . I live at Lisson-grove, and am a laundress. The prisoner was in my service—on the 14th of Feb., I called her up at four or five o'clock, and she answered me—when I got up afterwards I found my front door wide open—the prisoner was gone, and I missed a shawl and bonnet—these are them.
JOHN GRAYGOOSE . I am a pawnbroker. This shawl was pawned by the prisoner.

JOHN PHILLIPS (police-sergeant D 13.) I found the prisoner about nine o'clock the same evening at a dance in Cable-street, with this bonnet on her head, and the duplicate of the shawl was found on her at the station.
Prisoner. She said I was to have the bonnet till I paid for it; she bought it for me, and lent me the shawl.

MARY ANN COOKE
re-examined. I bought the bonnet for her, but I did not say she should have it till she paid for it—I did not lend her the shawl—I did not see her go away.
JAMES MANNING (police-constable D 44.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY
of stealing the Shawl only. Aged 19.—
Confined One Year.

984.
EDWARD DUDLEY and
WILLIAM CARTER were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of Feb., 1 box, value 1s.; And 1lb. weight of sugar
candy, 1s.; the goods of
Mary Saunders.

MARY SAUNDERS . I am a widow, and live in Brick-lane, St. Luke's. About six o'clock in the evening of the 16th of Feb. four or five boys came into my shop—the prisoners are two of them—they asked for a halfpenny-worth of something—as I turned to the window to get it, they ran away, and took with them a box containing barley-sugar—the officer brought Dudley back in half an hour, with this box, which is mine.

WILLIAM FARRANCE . I know the prisoners—I saw them on the 16th of Feb., as I was going on an errand—they said they were going the way I was—we got to Brick-lane, and they said they were going to buy a halfpenny-worth of something—they went into the shop, and came out running, and when they got on to Compton-street, Dudley threw the box down, because the policeman was coming—they ran awau—the policeman took me, and I told all about it.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) I took Carter a night or two afterwards—I said, "Carter, I want you"—he said, "I can take my solemn oath I was not there at all"—I said, "Where?"—he said, "Brick-lane"—I said, "What about that?"—he said, "I understood I was wanted about a box of barley-sugar"—I had watched bis residence for a night or two, but he was away from home.

Dudley. Farrance had the box, and carried it as far as Compton-street, and then gave it to me; I just looked at it; he would not take it again as he said there was a man coming; I put it on a step; he and another one took it.
Carter. He was the boy that took it; I never touched it.
MARY SAUNDERS . I saw the two prisoners in my shop—Farrance was outside.

DUDLEY†—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

CARTER†—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

985.
JAMES ALLEN was indicted
for embezzlement.

CHARLES SABINE . I live in Headley-place, Hoxton, and am a green-grocer. The prisoner was my errand-boy—it was his duty to take out coals, and to pay me the money he received directly he came back—if he received 3s. 1d. on the 21st of Jan., or 4s. 10d. on the 26th, he has not paid them to me.
FRANCES SARAH CROTTY . On the 21st of Jan. I paid the prisoner 3s. 1d. for his master.
ELIZABETH COE . I paid the prisoner 4s. 10d. on the 26th of Jan., for Mr. Sabine.
Prisoner. I will never do the like again.

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Five Days.
(The prosecutor engaged to employ the prisoner again.)

986.
ELIZABETH BENNETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Feb., 5 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. 6d., the goods of
John Wells.

GEORGE OHREN . I am salesman to Mr. John Wells, a pawnbroker, who lives in Adam's-row, Hampstead-road. On the 13th of Feb. I had a piece of printed cotton on a stall outsidd—I received information, and missed it-it was afterwards brought back—this is it—it is my master's, and has our mark on it.

CHARLES CARTER . I live in Providence-place, Kentish Town. I was standing at the prosecutor's stall, looking at some tools, and Mrs. Wells called out that the woman had taken something—I turned, and saw the prisoner turn up a street—I followed, and when she got half-way up the street she flung down this cotton—I lost sight of her for about two minutes, while she turned into a court, which was no thoroughfare—she came back, and by that time old Mrs. Wells came up, and said she took the cotton—the prisoner denied it—the policeman took her.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

987.
JOHN PERRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Feb., 1 coat, value 10s., the goods of
Nathaniel Cohen.
DEBORAH COHEN . I am the wife of Nathaniel Cohen—he lives on Great Saffron-hill. On the 13th of Feb. I had a coat hanging outside, pinned to another coat—I missed it—this is it.
MARY ANN BALCH . I saw the prisoner take two pins out, and throw them away—he took the coat down, ran into a passage, doubled it up, and took it away.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you known him before? A. Yes—he lived next door to us.

(Mr. Wilbraham, a gun-maker, gave the prisoner a good character, and pro
mised to employ him.)

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Six Days, and
Whipped.

988.
WILLIAM RADFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 2 wheelbarrows, value 1l. 8s., the goods of
Charles Oldfield.

CHARLES WOOD . I am clerk to Charles Oldfield, a builder. On the 21st of Jan. I missed two wheelbarrows from his yard in Sussex-square, Padding
ton—I found them on the 27th, on a piece of waste ground at the back of Charles-street, Paddington—the prisoner was not using them at the time—he said he had borrowed them of Rayner, who was acting as foreman to Mr. Oldfield.
Prisoner. I had them between two and three months. Witness. He might have had them three weeks, but not longer.
JAMES RAYNER . I did not lend the prisoner any barrows in Nov., Dec., or Jan.

Prisoner. Two months ago he was drinking with me in a public-house, and he said, "Are those barrows safe"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "Very well, we are going to begin again"—I said, "Very well, when you want them I will send them"—that was in a public-house in Bathurst-street, and he asked me if I had a sieve—I said, "No"—he said they had lost two sieves—an
other of the men came to me on the Thursday following, and told me to send the barrows home, which I did by a man, and he did not return them.
ROBERT WIBLIN . I was at work with the prisoner in Jan.—I saw the wheelbarrows—he said he would sell them to me.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you tell me that I could come to work with you? A. Yes, and you offered to sell me the barrows for 12s.—I said I would let you know in the morning, but I had some new ones come in, and did not want them.

WILLIAM CLARIDGE . I am a labourer. I hired these barrows of the prisoner about six weeks ago—he did not say anything to me about selling them, but I was in want of two, and he said he had two—I had them two days, and they were then taken from me.
Prisoner. Wiblin got on the work, and he wanted to get me away—it is all malice his coming against me—I was told by two or three of his men to mind what I was about as he would get me off.

ROBERT WIBLIN
re-examined. I have not the least animosity against the prisoner—I have taken his boy since he has been here, and I had my tool-house broken open and my shovel stolen—the prisoner wanted me to brand the barrows with my iron.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined Three Months.

989.
JAMES WATSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Feb., 1 pair of shoes, value 10s.; the goods of
Justus Wangemann: and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JUSTUS WANGEMANN . I am a baker, and live at No. 3, Colt-lane, Cam
bridge-road, Bethnal-green. These shoes were in my bakehouse about ten o'clock in the morning, on the 9th of Feb.—I saw them again at the pawn
broker's the next afternoon—these are them—the prisoner baked pies at my place three or four times.
WILLIAM BLANNAN . I am shopman to Mr. Ashley, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these shoes about seven o'clock, on the 9th of Feb., for 3s.
CHARLES PATTEN (police-constable K 206.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

990.
JAMES LYON was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Feb., 1 plane, value 4s.; the goods of
Henry Gumm.

HENRY GUMM . I am a carpenter, and live in St. John's Wood-terrace. I had a plane safe on Friday evening the 10th of Feb., about half-past five—I found it at the station on the 13th—this is it—it had been in the house
keeper's room in an unfinished house.

ALEXANDER REID (police constable D 124.) I stopped the prisoner with this plane, on the 13th of Feb.—I asked what he was going to do with it—he said it was not his, and he was carrying it for a man at the West-end of the town.
Prisoner. A boy asked me to carry it while he tied up his braces—I showed the boy to the policeman. Witness. No he did not.

GUILTY . * Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months.

p.hi:
Sixth Jury, before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
991.
THOMAS COX was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 1/4lb. weight of Italian juice, value 6d.; the goods of
James Sansom; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Two Months.

992.
GEORGE HUNTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Feb, 1 coat, value 2l.; the goods of
Henry Kohne; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 51.—
Confined Three Months.

993.
THOMAS CALLENDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Feb., 1 bell, value 20s.; 2 stancheons, 15s.; 2lbs. weight of brass, 1s. 6d.; and 3 knobs, 3s.; the goods of
Robert Ashley and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Two Months.

994.
ROBERT ROWLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Feb., 7lbs. weight of bacon, value 4s. 6d.; the goods of
John French Colebrook, and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months.

995.
JAMES ROW was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 8s.; the goods of
John Jacob; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Eight Days and
Whipped.

996.
WILLIAM LINGE and
ANN DONOVAN were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 9th of Feb., 6lbs. weight of potatoes, value 3d.; the goods of
John Jordan, the master of
William Linge.

JOHN JORDAN . I live in Fox-street, Limehouse, and deal in potatoes. Linge was in my service to sell potatoes, but was never to sell on credit without my special consent—I had missed potatoes for a long time—I ap
pointed Sarah Tabraham to watch on the morning of the 9th of Feb., and I also went to my neighbour's house opposite to watch—while there I saw Donovan go to the shop—she and Linge went to the potato-bin—she took hold of one end of her apron which she had on her person, and Linge took hold of the other end of it, and though the scales were immediately before them, and it was Linge's duty to weigh them, they put them into her apron without—when she got as far as the curb-stone immediately opposite my shop I stopped her, and taxed her with stealing them, in the presence of Linge—Donovan said she had not stolen them—I asked what quantity she had got—she said she did not know, but she had given him 6d.—I asked Linge what quantity he had sold her—he said twopenny worth—I sent for a policeman,

and gave them both into custody—in a minute or two afterwards Linge appeared to take a 6d. out of his mouth, and on my making some remark condemnatory of his conduct, he said he thought there was no barm in giv
ing her a few.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. I think you are rather uncertain as to whether any money passed between them? A. Yes—I saw none; but it might have passed—I was eight or nine yards distance, looking out of a win
dow—my shop has an open front—I can undertake to say, that these potatoes were not put in the scale at all, as the prisoners were standing in the middle of the shop, between me and the scales which were at the bottom of the shop; but I could see above them, and see the scales—my shop may be about four yards long; the scales are on the side, but near to the bottom—Tabraham was at the door of the house that I was in; she had not to turn her head to get out, which I had—Linge's general instructions were, not to give credit; if he had, I should have looked to him to have made up the deficiency.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Would you have allowed Linge, on his credit, to have served your customers? No—if these potatoes had been sold, they should have been weighed; that is the only mode of determining the price—I am certain that no weighing took place.

SARAH TABRAHAM . I was directed by Mr. Jordan to watch his premises—I was at my own door, which is opposite his shop—I saw Donovan go into the shop; both she and Linge took the potatoes, and placed them in her apron—she then went out—the potatoes had not been weighed, and there was no money paid that I could see; I had a full opportunity of seeing, if any thing of the sort had passed.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoners were standing close together when the potatoes were taken out, were they not? A. Yes—they were some distance from me—I swear that no money passed between them—I was at the door, and could see plainly—they were standing side by side, and both faced the bin—Donovan stood nearest to me; her side face was towards me.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You were stationed there for the express purpose of watching? A. Yes; and I have done so on other occasions; I was parti
cularly attentive to see whether money passed, and am positive it did not.

THOMAS SHEEN (police-constable K 187.) I took the prisoners at the shop—I weighed the potatoes which Donovan had; there were 11lbs. of them—Linge said he was very sorry that he had done so, and he would never do so again—Donovan said she had given him sixpence.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

LINGE—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

DONOVAN—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month.
(There were two other charges against the prisoners.)

997.
WILLIAM ASHLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 28rd of Feb., 1 bottle-cap, value 10s., the property of
William Conyngham; and 2 thim
bles, 1s. 6d.; 1 finger-guard, 1s. 6d.; and 1 shawl, 5s.; the goods of
Eliza Dolbey.

ROBERT SHELL . I am butler to Mr. Conyngham, of Porchester-terrace, Bayswater—on the 23rd of Feb., about a quarter past two o'clock, I observed the passage-door of the house open, after shutting it before I went to my dinner—I then saw the door of the servants' sitting-room open, which I had seen shut before—I went into that room, and found the prisoner secreted be
hind the door; I collared him, and asked what he did there—he said he was come to see if any of the workmen (meaning the sweeps) were there at work
—I called out, and the other servants came to my assistance—the prisoner asked me to let him go—I went for a policeman.

WILLIAM CONYNGHAM . I heard a cry from ray butler; I went down, and saw him holding the prisoner—I sent for the policeman—the prisoner threw himself on his knees, and begged of me to let him go—he said he was starving—he then took these articles from his trowsers—this is the cap of a dressing-bottle—I afterwards found the bottle without the cap—I know the cap to be mine, and I saw him take it from his trowsers, with this shawl and thimble—I saw them delivered to the policeman.

ELIZA DOLBEY . I am in the service of Mr. Conyngham—this shawl is mine, and this thimble and guard—they were in my work-box, on the table in the servants' room; the bottle-cap was on the table, near the work-box.
THOMAS BAXTER (police-constable D 201.) I took the prisoner, and these things—he said it was the first time he had ever done such a tiling.
Prisoner. I travelled to get work and could not—I never did such a thing before.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

998.
MARTHA BARRETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 2 cups, value 6d.; 2 saucers, 6d.; 1 handkerchief, 6d.; 1 jacket, 2s.; 1 towel, 3d.; 1 sheet, 1s.; 2 aprons, 1s.; and 1 neckerchief, 6d.; the goods of
Charles George Chapman, her master.

JAMES REYNOLDS (police-sergeant T 1.) On the 12th of February I was on duty in Turnham-green, about a quarter before three o'clock in the morn
ing—I saw the prisoner carrying this bundle and a basket—I asked where she was going, she said to Colnbrook, and she had left a situation at Clapton at four o'clock the afternoon before—that her father had come to meet her—he was gone on in a wagon, and had got her boxes—she said this bundle which she had contained her clothes—I took her towards the station, and on the road she told me that these cups and saucers she had taken from her mis
tress—and the statement she had made respecting her leaving her place at Clapton was all false—I examined the bundle at the station, and found these articles in it.

ANN CHAPMAN . I am the wife of Charles George Chapman, we live in Pelham-row South, Brompton—the prisoner came to me on the 3rd of Jan. as a servant, and left me on the 11th of Feb.—I went to bed that night about a quarter to twelve o'clock, also leaving her up and my husband—when I was in bed she bronght me the baby—she rubbed her eyes, and said she was very weary—I told her to tell her master to come up stairs, and she could go to bed—she slept in the kitchen—I heard no more of her till a quarter before five, when the policeman came to the door—I then discovered the prisoner was gone, and I missed this property—the cups and saucers had been in the kitchen-cupboard—we had used some of them for tea on that afternoon—the kitchen was in great confusion, and the window open—she had not given me notice to leave.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Four Months.

999.
MICHAEL HENNESSEY and
WILLIAM DARBY were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February, 139lbs. weight of lead, value 11s. 6d.; the goods of
Isaac Walker and others; and fixed to a certain building of theirs.

WILLIAM NICOL (police-constable K 17.) On the 17th of Feb. I was in Fore-street, Limehouse, about nine o'clock at night—I saw the two prisoners in a nook by a marine-store dealer's, and saw a bag near them—I said, "What have you got here?"—I stooped to look, and they both ran away—I

took possession of the lead, and gave a desctiption of the prisoners to another officer—I took the lead to the station—there were 47lbs. of it—I afterwards saw the prisoners at Poplar station, I knew them directly—I am quite sure they are the boys—I took the lead to Mr. Taylor's brewhouse, at Limehouse next morning—I compared it with some lead produced by another officer, and some lead on the top of the gutter of the store-room, and it exactly fitted.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Have you the lead here? A. Yes—the nook was six or seven yards from the brewhouse.

WILLIAM TEATLING (police-constable K 264.) I received information from Nicol, and took the prisoners, in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour after
wards, at the corner of Fore-street, standing both together—I did not tell them what I took them for, I only said, "I want you two youths"—Hennessey said, "I don't know anything about the lead."

THOMAS SHEEN . I am a policeman. I was called by Teatling to assist him—I went the next morning to where the prisoners were taken, and found 47lbs. more of lead—I took that to the brewhouse, compared that and the other lead—it matched exactly.

HENRY WOOK . I am a policeman. I went on the roof of the store-room at the brewhouse with Brundell—I had observed the week before that half the lead was gone, and now found the remainder was gone—Brundell pointed out some lead in the cellar of an empty house just by—I compared that with the other pieces of lead—it corresponded with them and with the roof also.

JOHN BRUNDELL . I am foreman carpenter in the employ of Mr. Isaac Walker And two others—I inspect their premises from time to time—I missed about half the lead from the top of this place the week before—when Wood came on the Saturday morning we put the lead on again, and it matched exactly—it had been in the gutter and on the roof.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What is the height of the place? A. From eight to nine feet.
COURT. Q. How could boys, like the prisoners, get there? A. We had pulled down part of an old house next to it, and by that means they could get up.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were there not a number of work
men employed there? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

1000.
MARGARET ELLIS and
MARY ANN PARKER were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of Feb., 1 jacket, value 16s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 8s.; 1 waistcoat, 2s. 6d. 1 pair of boots, 2s.; 1 rule, 1s.; 1 snuff-box, 6d.; 1 handkerchief, 6d. 1 shilling, and 8 halfpence; the property of
James Prin
ham Grinham.

JAMES PRINHAM GRINHAM . I live in Great Peter-street, Westminster, and am a mason. On the evening of the 19th of Feb. I met Parker in King-street between eleven and twelve o'clock—I went home with her to a house in New-square, Westminster—I saw Ellis there—they were both in the same room with me—they persuaded me to undress and go to bed—I was not perfectly sober—Parker laid down on the bed for a few minutes with her clothes on—both the prisoners assisted in taking my clothes off, as I was not very fast in doing it—they took my clothes outside the room, and Ellis said I was to rest contented, my clothes would be all right in the morning—I awoke next morning and there was nobody in the house but me, and my clothes were all gone—I had a snuff-box in one of my pockets, a two-foot rule, a shilling and some halfpence—I have since seen my clothes at a pawnbroker's in Strutton-ground—when I found I was left alone I waited in the house till

I saw some persons pass, and I sent for some clothes to put on—I went to the station and gave information—these are the clothes, and what I had on when I went to the house—these are my boots, and this rule is mine—the snuff-box I have not found.

JOHN JAMES LLOYD . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Strutton-ground. On the morning of the 20th of Feb. Ellis pawned this jacket, waistcoat, and trowsers—I did not know her before, but I have no doubt of her—I after
wards saw the prosecutor at my shop—Ellis came again afterwards, and I gave her in charge.

ROBERT SUTTLE . I took Parker on another charge. As I was bringing her out of the shop where I took her, a woman said, "Take these boots with you"—I took up these boots and said to Parker, "Are these yours?"—she said, "Yes, I want them; they are my boots"—I found on her this rule and a new pair of clogs—she said she found them behind the door—she first said she lived in Chapel-street—we fetched a woman to identify her, and then she said she lived in New-square.

Parker's Defence. I never saw the prosecutor's clothes since I left him in the room with a young woman; he said he would pawn his waistcoat next morning and pay us; I said, "If you have no money, my friend may stop, but I shall not"—I went away, and the next day I came back and found these boots and the rule behind the door; I was rather in liquor; I went to sell them, and as I did so there were two shillings on the counter; the person said I was going to take them, and I was taken.
Ellis's Defence. I merely went to get an affidavit of an article I had lost the ticket of, and was taken; I know nothing of the prosecutor; I neve saw him in my life.

ELLIS—
GUILTY . Aged 44.

PARKER—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

1001.
CHARLES LEDGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of Feb., 1 leaden pipe, value 3d., and 1 metal cock, 4d. the goods of
John Irwin, and fixed to a building; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ANGELO IRWIN . I live with my father, John Irwin, who keeps the Anchor and Hope beer shop in Spencer-street, St. George's. On the 6th of Feb. I saw the prisoner with a person in the tap-room at my father's—they came about twelve o'clock, and stopped till nearly three—I then missed the pri
soner, and did not see him any more—after that James Beard came and spoke to me—I lifted up the window and saw that the brass cock was broken off from the pipe that runs from the kitchen up the wall, and to the butt—the cock was not broken, but I saw the the pipe without it—I have never seen the cock since—it was my father's property—I had seen it attached to the pipe the same morning.

JAMES BEARD . I am a shoemaker. I was at the Anchor and Hope on the 6th of Feb.—I went through the house, to go into the yard, about half-past two o'clock—while I was in the water-closet, in the yard, I saw the prisoner come to the water-cock—he lifted his hand up and down, and broke the tap off, the pipe, and the brass cock with it—he placed it under the frock he had on, and walked right through the house—I did not see where he went to—I gave notice of it.
Prisoner. You stated before that you saw me looking at the clock? Witness. You certainly turned your eye and looked as you were going through.
JAMES MALIN (police-constable K 99.) I took the prisoner, in Ratcliffe-highway, on the 10th of Feb.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to the docks, and could not get any em
ployment; I met with two men, we went to this house, and played at bagatelle; I had occasion to go into the yard; Beard came before me, and walked through the house, he was talking to the landlady, and I looked up to see what time it was; if I had been guilty there was plenty of time to give me in charge.

THOMAS JONES . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person—I was at that time an officer—I took him, and he had been convicted before that.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1002.
GEORGE MEAD and
ABEL ALLEN were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February, 1 truss of hay, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Hodson, the master of Mead.

ROBERT HODSON . I am a farmer, and live at Willesden; Mead was my carter. On the morning of the 13th of Feb. I delivered him half a load of hay and half a load of straw, to take to Mr. Hoare's stable, in Great York
mews, and about the middle of the day I received a letter.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How many trusses were there? A. Eighteen of each—I am not the proprietor of the farm, but I transact the business of it for my uncle, who is aged—his name is also Robert Hodson—Mead has been in my service about eight years—he has three children.

WILLIAM MITCHELL . I live in Earl-street, and am jailor of Marylebone Police-court. On the morning of the 13th of Feb. I was coming along the New-road from Edgeware-road—I saw Mead driving the bone and cart—Allen was walking and talking with him by the side of the cart—I saw the cart stop facing Homer-row, New-road—Mead loosened the ropes—as I passed I heard Mead say to Allen, "Carry it on your back"—I turned my head, and saw Allen take a truss of hay from the load, and go down Homer
row with it—I then met Thompson, and gave him information.
Allen. Q. Did you see me take it off the cart? A. No; but I saw it on your shoulder, and you were going from the cart.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON (police-sergeant D 4.) I received informa
tion from Mitchell, and met Allen in the New-road—he had nothing then—I said, "What have you done with the truss of hay? you have taken it to Atkins's, you must go and show me where it is"—he went and pointed it out to me—I asked him to carry it away—he refused—I said, "I shall take you into custody for stealing this"—he said, "I have not stolen it, I was ordered to carry it by Mead"—I asked if he received any money—he said no—I took him to the station—he said Mead was in the habit of leaving hay—I returned, and took Mead at the corner of Stingo-lane—I said I wanted him for stealing a truss of hay—he made no answer, and I took him to the station, and there he said he was allowed to sell it by the coachman and groom of Mr. Hoare, on account of their not being able to give him anything for the delivery—I saw the vacancy of a truss of hay on the cart—this is the truss.
MR. HODSON. This truss is like my hay, but I would rather not swear to it—here is a remarkable brown vein in it which went round the rick—Mead was not authorized to sell it.
Allen's Defence. I was out of employ, and Mead asked me to take the truss to such a place, and to say he would call as he came back.
NOT GUILTY .

1003.
GEORGE NICHOLSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Feb., 84lbs. weight of copper, value 3l., the goods of
George Green and others; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1004.
JOSEPH HOYE was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Feb., 100lbs. weight of beef, value 1l. 17s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Bonsor, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Month.

1005.
DENNIS SULLIVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 1 lb. weight of tobacco, value 3s. 10d. and 1 jar, 2s. 2d. the goods of
Charles William Schnitzler; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Confined Three Months.

1006.
WILLIAM DEAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 2 half-crowns, the monies of
Robert Eales; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

1007.
CHARLES MOOR was indicted
for stealing, on tie 25th of Feb., 1 coat, value 3l. 3s., the goods of
Edward Banks; to winch he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1008.
THOMAS BROOME was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Feb., 7 quarts of brandy, value 2l. 17s.; 12 bottles, 3s.; and 1 box, 2s.; the goods of the
London Dock Company.

WILLIAM HODDER EVANS . I am foreman of the case-wine warehouse, No. 4, London Docks.
