I was occupying a box on the floor, No. 10, which is the second floor of the warehouse—there is an entrance into the warehouse by a staircase—between that staircase and the box which I occupy there is a pile of spirits, which prevents my seeing any persons passing up the staircase—there is a staircase leading to No. 11, and a person on that staircase could see a person on the staircase leading to No. 9—there is a trap-door through No. 10, from which goods are let down to No. 9, and from that out of a loop-hole—on the 7th of Feb., between three and four o'clock, the prisoner came to me at my warehouse—he handed me orders for five cases of wine—they were such orders as authorised me to deliver them to him—the smallest of those cases contained-three dozen, and the largest six dozen—I had known the prisoner many years—he was in the habit of coming with orders, and he knew the mode of business—the proper way of delivering those cases was down the trap-door, and through, the loop-hole—when he delivered the orders to me, I told him to make haste down, he should have them directly—one of those cases was in No. 10, and four were in the upper floor—in order to get out of No. 10, the prisoner had to go round those cases of brandy which were piled up—Watkins was at that time going up the stairs of No. 11 floor—he called out to me, and in consequence of that, I sent Smith round—the prisoner, in going out, would have to pass the cases of brandy, and the case now in question was one that was in that pilr—Watkind went after the prisoner—Smith went after him, and I followef—ehen I got down I found the prisoner standing by this case of brandy, directly under the tail of his cart—Watkins and Smith had got to him beforr—I heard the prisoner say he believed he had got the wrong case—I said I thought he had—he was then taken into custody

—the case he took was not at all similar, in shape or size to the cases of wine which he was to take—the smallest of them was thirty-three inches, and the case he took was only eighteen inches—this case of brandy had never been let through the loop-hole.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. The large cases come through the loop-hole? A. Yes; but when they are very small, and we cannot sling them, they are carried down by hand—there was no necessity for this case of brandy going through the loop-hole—I have known the prisoner many years—he was in the emply of a carman named Elsom—I never knew any thing against him.
COURT. Q. Do you allow the carmen to take the cases out of No. 10? A. No; we order one of the gangs of men to deliver them to the carmen.

GEORGE SMITH . I am a labourer in the Docks. On the 7th of February I was called by Mr. Evans to load for the prisoner—I came down from No. 11 to No. 10—while I was coming down I saw the prisoner standing at the end of the gangway, at the foot of the stairs that lead to No. 11—I passed on to Mr. Evans, and Watkins came along directly after—in consequence of what Watkins said I was sent to where the cart was loading—I found the prisoner standing at the tail of his cart, unfolding a tarpaulin in the bottom of the cart—the case of brandy stood at his feet, under the tail of the cart—I looked at the case; he turned round, and said to me, "I think I have made a mistake; I want No. 8, this is not it"—he took a paper from his pocket—this little case could have been got conveniently into the curt, under the tarpaulin.

ROBERT WATKINS . I was going up the stairs, from No. 10 to No. 11, on that day—I turned round, and saw a person similar to the prisoner, with a straw hat on—I saw him go our, with a case on his shoulder—I called out—we went round, and saw the prisoner with a case, at the tail of the cart—it was such a case as I had seen the man carry—the prisoner said a man had brought it out of the ground floor, with a paper cap on.
Cross-examined. Q. How neat were you to the person? A. About thirty yards from him—I was going up the stairs—I could see any person going out.

EDWARD CULBERT (police-constable H 200.) The prisonr was given into my custody—he told me that some man had brought the case out with a paper cap and a fustian coat on—I asked if he had the case on his shoulder—he said the man had it, but he met him at the corner of the warehouse.

WILLIAM HODDER EVANS
re-exmined. This warehouse is part of the London Docks, and within the walls.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Nine Months.

1009.
ANN ROSE , the younger, was indicted
for stealing on the 23rd of Jan., 1 blanket value 2s., the goods, of
Samuel Rose.

ANN ROSE . I am the wife of Samuel Rose, we five in Chalton-street; Somers-town—the prisoner is my daughter. I missed amongest other things, a blanket, in Jan.—this is it—I never gave the prisoner authority to take it from my house—she was living with me at the time.
COURT. Q. How came you to prosecute this child for this little article? A. It is not only this, she has been very trying for two years—I have taken things out before, and she has pawned them again.
WILLIAM TRANAH . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tottenham-court-road. I produce this blanket—it was pawned by a female, but I do not know who—I have the counterpart of the duplicate that was given.
SAMUEL FRANCIS (police-constable S 146.) I produce the duplicate of the

blanket. The prisoner was in bed when I was called in—I went out of the room while she dressed herself, and her mother called oat that she was de
stroying some duplicates—I went in and asked the prisoner for them—she refused to give them—I then held her in the bed while her mother took a bag of duplicates from under her, and this was one of them.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years—Penitentiary.
(The prisoner's sister stated that she was constantly robbing her parents, and using great violence to her mother. There were two other charges against her.)

1010.
MARY HOLLAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Feb, 1 kettle, value 2s. 6d.; 7 wine glasses, 1s. 6d.; 1 decanter, 1s.; 1 pair of salt holders, 2s.; 6 cups, 1s. 6d.; 6 saucers, 1s.; 1 milk-pot, 6d.; 3 orna
ments, 1s.; 2 jugs, 6d.; 1 sugar-glass, 2s.; 2 pictures, framed and glazed, 4s. 1 teapot, 1s.; 9 yards of printed cotton, 3s.; 1 cape, 2s.; 10 towels, 10s.; 5 petticoats, 6s.; 6 gowns, 10s.; 6 bed-gowns, 5s.; 3 frocks, 2s.; 1 pair of stays, 6d.; 1 razor, 6d.; 3 pillow-cases, 1s. 6d.; 1 table-cloth, 1s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 3s.; 3 shawls, 7s.; 1 coat, 4s. 6d.; 1 cloak, 1s.; 1 handkerchief, 2s.; 2 boxes, 9d.; 1 bonnet, 2s.; 1 knife, 6d.; 1 fork, 6d.; 2 blankets, 8d.; and 2 pain of sugar-tongs, 15s.; the goods of Barnet Abrahams.

PRISCILLA ABRAHAMS . I am the wife of Barnet Abrahams, a general dealer. We live in Castle-place, Castle-street, Whitechapel—the prisoner was my servant—she had 1s. a week, and her board and lodging. On the 15th of Feb. I left her in charge of my child and the place—I returned about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon, found the outer door shut, and the child in the cradle—the prisoner was gone, and the place was stripped—the drawen had been broken open—the pictures taken from the wall—the china from the cupboard, and the sugar-tongs and wearing-apparel gone—the things were worth rather more than 5l. altogether—these now produced are the articles.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When was she taken? A. The same evening, about seven.

MARY HARVY . I live in Wentworth-street. The prisoner came to me on the 15th of Feb. with a large bundle, which she said was her clothes, that she was going to leave her situation, and asked if she might leave them till seven the next morning, as she was going off very early in the morning—she said her father was dead, and she was going to his funeral—I found the articles she left were not clothes, and sent for the policeman.

PHŒBE SEATHARD . I am the wife of Jeremiah Thomas Seathard. The prisoner brought a quantity of things to my place on the 15th of Feb., and inquired for a lodging—the policeman and the prosecutor came afterwards, and the things were given up.

WILLIAM FREDERICK SMALLSHAW . I am assistant to Mr. Fleming, a pawnbroker, in Whitechapel. I produce a pair of silver sugar-tongs, pawned on the 15th of Feb., by a female, who I believe was the prisoner.

MILES DOWLING (police-constable H 135.) I live in Crown-court, Little Pearl-street. I was called to the prosecutor's, and examined the place—I found this instrument on the drawers, which appeared to have been broken open with it—the marks correspond with it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined One Year.

1011.
JAMES GODDARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of Jan., 5lbs. weight of indigo, value 30s., the goods of the London Dock Company, his masters.

JOHN CLEMENT . I am constable of the London Docks. The prisoner was in their employ, as manager of the indigo warehouse—on Monday after
noon, the 30th of Jan., a few minntes before four o'clock, I saw the prisoner coming towards the west gate of the dock from the indigo warehouse—he came up to the gate—I said, "Mr. Goddard, where are you going at this time?"—(it was earlier than he ought to go—he ought to have been at the warehouse to see the men out, and the warehouse locked up)—he said, "I am only going to the Custom-house; I shall be back in aminute"—I said, "The reason I have stopped you is, I think you have got something in your hat, and I must see what you have got"—I got him into the box—he appeared much distressed, and said, "I am a ruined man"—I took off his hat, and found these four cakes of indigo—I felt his pockets, and found he had some more indigo in his under coat pockets—he took that out at my desire—I asked him the reason of his taking that indigo out—he said, "I have got indigo of my own, I am taking that out to test the prices"—I said, "Have you indigo of your own at the warehouse?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "What quantity?"—he said, "A 2lbs. sample left last quarter"—I have weighed the indigo that was found on the prisoner—it is 5 3/4lbs.—this would not be taken out of the docks as a sample in this state and manner—it is worth 6s. a pound before the duty is paid—I left him in the custody of the gate-keeper, Fryer—the prisoner said, "For God's sake don't ex
pose me."

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. He has been in the service of the company some time? A. Yes, ten year—it was not his place to give passes for indigo, so that persons would be allowed to go out—he has not been allowed to sign passes the last five months—he was interdicted from signing passes for indigo the last five months—supposing an importer to give an order, the prisoner would not give a pass then—not for the last five months—at the Police-court I said he was authorized to sign passes for samples of indigo, and I had examined passes—I knew he was at one time allowed to sign passes for samples of indigo, but till my return to the dock that day I did not know he was interdicted from doing it—there is a book called the signature-book, which is kept by the gate-keepers, of persons who are authorised to sign passes, and the prisoner's name is erased from the book.

COURT. Q. What means have you of knowing that he has been inter
dicted? A. The superintendent informed me of it.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Will you swear the prisoner has not signed passes within one week of this occurrence? A. He has not to my know
ledge—I will not swear he has not—the book I speak of as being scratched is kept at the office—I can have access to it—it is scratched by the accountant—it is generally kept in my own office—I have not looked at it since I was at the police-office—I was informed by the superintendent that he had interdicted Mr. Goddard from signing passes—whether the name has been scratched out I do not know—I am sure I separated the pieces found in the prisoner's hat from those in his pocket—these are the four found in his hat—he carried his hat very well—it had no greater motion than a pocket hand
kerchief and a pair of gloves would have given it—I could not tell that he had anything in it till I spoke to him, and then his countenance fell.

Q. His hat had a little appearance which attracted your attention? A. I had considerable doubt whether it had anything in it before I spoke to him, but when I did I had no doubt—his countenance altered—he smelt of rum,
and appeared to have been drinking from his manner—he was not perfectly sober—he was about the usual pitch that I have seen him at other times.

WILLIAM ROBSON . I am warehouse-keeper of No. 1 department, at the London Docks—the indigo warehouse forms a portion of that department. On Monday, the 30th of Jan., there was a considerable number of chests of indigo in it, and there are still—176 chests by the same ship—these were all open at that time, and have been so since—the prisoner had the entire management of that warehouse, and full access to every chest in the ware-house—he was manager of the indigo, and one part of his duty was to take eare that no part of it was taken away—I have looked at the indigo found in his hat and pockets, and have compared it with that in the chests—I am not a judge of indigo, but the stamp on these squares is the same that the exterior of the chests bear, and some of the squares in the chests bear the same mark, A I K—I have got them here—these marks correspond with some of the other indigo left behind, and the marks on the chests.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You would not undertake to swear it is the same? A. No; all the cakes that are imported have not the same marks; there are a great variety of marks in eighty or a hundred chests—they might have different stamps—I dare say it is a common mark—the in
digo is sold at quarterly sales; at such sales, it is usual to sell the warehouse sweepings, for the benefit of the proprietor of the warehouse, at the docks—after the sales the floors are swept up, and there are very frequently small pieces, as big as a walnut, or occasionally a little larger; these are picked up and generally crushed, for the purpose of mixing with the ordinary dust that is swept from the floor—I believe it is better in lumps; but it has always been the custom in the indigo trade for this rubbish, to be crushed; that is our practice, as introduced by the prisoner—I cannot say how much we do in a year; it depends on what we have; in 1842, the docks sold perhaps three tons of it, and nearly half of that was sawdust—it sometimes fetches 2s. a-pound.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When this, is crushed, does it crush into solid cakes again? A. No; it is sold by public auction, in the Auction Mart.

GEORGE DIX . I am constable of the docks—I was directed to watch the indigo warehouse—I was doing so on the 30th of Jan.—I saw the prisoner come from the indigo warehouse, and go towards the west gate—I communi
cated with Clements.
Cross-examined. Q. That was his proper place to be in? A. Yes; he was to leave the warehouse when the doors were closed, and the labourers out; but they were not closed then.

COURT. Q. How long was it after you saw him come out of the ware-house that he went to the west gate? A. I should think six or seven mi
nutes.

WILLIAM FRYER . I am gate-keeper of the London Docks—on the 30th of Jan., a little before four o'clock, I was directed by Clements to go into the box near the west gate, to take charge of the prisoner; I saw him there, and I saw some dust of indigo on the desk—I asked what he was stopped with; was it with the indigo; he said, "Yes"—I said, "How much; a pound?" the prisoner said, "No; four or five"—I said I was very sorry; it was a bad job—he said he should be taken to the police, and he had no business to have done it—he wanted to go in and see Mr. Chandler, the superintendent; I said I must not let him out of the box till Mr. Clements returned—Mr. Cle
ments returned in about twenty minutes, and told him be would have to go before a Magistrate—when Mr. Clements was gone, the prisoner said be ought to be treated the same as the rest—he said Gale was stopped some time ago

with coffee, and that was quite as bad a case as his, and it was looked over; and Mr. Robson had been robbing the Company of time and stuff for weeks, and that was looked over—he said Spratty had got a case already packed and ready for removal, and he was suffered to go without going before a Magis
trate—he said he should make up big mind for the worst; he should say nothing at present, but what he had to say he should say before another tri
bunal.

Cross-examined. Q. All you heve been stating was what he said in an
swer to questions? A. No; I asked him what he was stopped with—I have been at the gate about twelve months, and in the dock about three years—I believe Robson is one of the witnesses.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Is the warehouse within the walls of the London Docks? A. Yes.
THOMAS COOPER . I have compared the indigo produced with the indigo in the wirehouse; it corresponds in marks with the rest of the indigo there.

Cross-examined. Q. You have seen the same at the West India and East India Docks? A. No; I have not seen that mark before—I belong to the East and West India Dock Company's indigo warehouse—I swear I have not said that I have indigo of this mark precisely in my warehouse—I have seen such marks, but not in the warehouse—I have seen them marked on the canvas when they have been going to other docks—the same mark is put on the canvas that is on the indigo—that on the canvas is the import mark, but the indigo may be another mark—as to the mark on the goods inside, I could not say.

JOHN SQUIRES . I am working forman in the indge department of the London Dockes—I have known the prisoner nine years—I saw him on the day in question at nine o'clock in the morning, waiting outside the warehouse door, before it was unlocked—he was not soher—I saw him again about the warehouse three or four times—he was still worse about twelve or one o'clock—there are conveniences in the docks to get drunk there—I saw him again about half-past three o'clock, and I should say he was then decidedly drunk—when he is drunk, I should say he does not know what he is about; he is more like a madman than anybody else—I have seen him go to the men, and actually order them to do things they ought not to do; order them to go to work about things that they ought not to do, and five minutes after he has come to me and said, "These men are doing wrong"—he has conducted him
self in an irrational manner.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Have you ever seen him drunk before this day? A. Many times—I am a working foreman—I have been in the Company's service fifteen years—my superiors were all aware of this; and parties coming down to the docks, respectable merchants have said he would some day lose his situation—I saw him three times that day; he war not sober at nine o'clock, worse between twelve and one, and decidedly drunk at three—he was sitting in the counting-house—I had some conversation with him in the day; he answered the questions on some occasions, not always—he was sitting in the office with his head on his hand.
MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Was that the position for a man to be in, lying with his head on his hands? A. No—I should say the proprietors do not allow men to lay their heads on their hands.

JOHN ALGER . I have known the prisoner from ten to twelve years—his character has been perfectly honest up to the present moment—since the death of his wife, about fifteen months ago, he has been quite a different man to what he was before—I have seen him frequently at my house, when he

has been intoxicated—when he has been in that state he has been quite dif
ferent to other men—when he is intoxicated he is an insane man—he came to my house one evening—we sat a considerable time in conversation and I said to him, "I have just purchased a watch"—he said, "Let us look"—I gave it into his hand, and he took and threw it behind the fire—he did not appear at that time conscious of the injury he was doing to me or my watch—I saw him the next morning, and I mentioned to him the strange conduct of throwing my watch behind the fire, and he knew nothing at all about it—I have observed the same manner with him when he has been in that state—I saw him on the day before this matter occurred at the docks—he was then very much in liquor—from my observation of his manner, when in a state of intoxication, I can undertake to say, that his manner is altogether different to what I have ever seen in other men—I have known these fits of tempo
rary insanity to continue upon him during the time of his intoxication at times—but when he has been in this state, he has, notwithstanding this, ap
peared to walk tolerably strong—he had the command of his legs like other men, but his reason appeared to be gone—I recollect another instance—he was at my house, and it rained very hard—he said, "It is a very wet night," and he got up, took his coat off, and walked out for about half an hour.

COURT. Q. Does he bestow his company generally on you when he is drunk? A. No, my lord—the watch was a great deal damaged, it stopped it—I did not have it repaired—it was not worth repairing—it had gone before, and it has not gone since, it was so much injured—it remained behind the fire some minutes—we took it out with the tongs as soon as we could.

JOHN CHAMBERS . I am a surgeon, and live in Hackney-road—I have known him about two years—I have seen him in a state of intoxication, such as has been described—I have seen him so too often, and there is a degree of nervous excitement about the brain that gives rise to those circum
stances that you have heard—I have seen other tipsy men—the conduct of the prisoner is contrary to theirs—he can stand on his legs generally—I de
cidedly think he does not know right from wrong.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you mean, when in a state of drunkenness, you believe him to be insane, and not know right from wrong? A. He does not—from what I have observed, I believe he would commit a theft without knowing what he was doing—that is one of his failings—he has a craving—I have heard the evidence in this case, and that leads roe to suppose that he was in one of his fits of insanity—I have heard that, on being taken, he said, "I am a ruined man"—the suddenness of the impression he re
ceived, on being taken on suspicion, threw off his insanity, and very likely brought him to his senses—it would with many people—I am not relatted to him—I have attended his family—I have represented that he was insane, to his unfortunate wife who died.

Q. But we understand he has only been insane since her death, and that is fifteen months ago? A. I believe it is—this has been increased from time to time—I do not know any one living person to whom I have men
tioned it.
COURT. Q. Is he sane when he is not intoxicated? A. He is a singular man altogether, I never could make head or tail of him.

JETHRO VIAL . I am a licensed victualler, and live in Virginia-row, Bethnal-green. I have known the prisoner from the first hour he came under the Hon. East India Company's warehouse, twelve years ago—I never saw nor heard anything dishonest of him till this accusation—he is an honest, upright man—I have frequently gone to his house like I have to other
warehouse-keepers, but never saw anything belonging to the Hon. East India Company's department.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Have you known him up to the present time? A. I have known him—I have seen him in my house once, and I have been to his house.
COURT. Q. Did you ever see him intoxicated? A. I have, and sorry I am to say it; and likewise, his wife has been ill-used by him when in that state.
(Edward Brennand, a solicitor; and John Giddy, a tailor, in Gloucester-street, Hackney-road; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

p.hi:
Sixth Jury, before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1012.
JAMES SIMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Feb., 2 printed books, value 6s. and 43 pamphlets, 2l.; the goods of
Samuel Gilbert, his master.

SAMUEL GILBERT . I am a publishing bookseller, and live in Paternoster
row. The prisoner was in my service, as a porter and collector for about eleven months—in consequence of something that occurred, I gave him into custody, on the 9th of Feb.—he was taken to the station—I saw a duplicate found on him—I proceeded with it to the shop of Mr. Lamb, a pawnbroker, in Stan
hope-street, Clare-market, and there I found this copy of the Mirror, and twenty-three numbers of Knight's London—I afterwards went to Mr. Winton, a publican, in Wych-street, Strand—I found there these six numbers of Froissart's Chronicle—these are not works which I have published, but which I have sold and dealt in—the prisoner was my porter, but he had nothing to do with selling property across the counter, or dealing with it in any way—he would have access to the books—he came to me at eight o'clock in the morn
ing, and remained till nine at night—I had a right to all his time during those hours—I paid him his wages every Saturday—I missed this volume of the Mirror.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You cannot tell whether any of these others have been sold? A. I cannot—they are sold by all the other book-sellers in the trade—Froissart's Chronicle has been out nine months, and Knight's London commenced in March, 1841; but some are numbers, and some are parts—one of these is for March, 1841—the duplicate found on the prisoner relates only to this volume of the Mirror—whether this book ever was in my shop I cannot say—other persons beside myself sell in my shop—the volume of the Mirror that we missed, I saw last in the prisoner's hand, but whether it was sold I cannot tell.
MR. DOANE. Q. What is the last date of the numbers of Knight's London that you found at the pawnbroker's? A. September, 1842.

OLIVER DEATH (City police-constable, No. 201.) I took the prisoner—I found this duplicate on him—I afterwards went to his lodging, in New Inn
passage, Clare-market—I there found two duplicates, in a little pocket-book in his drawer—one of them was out of date—I found these pamphlets, Cham
bers's Information for the People.
Cross-examined. Q. The only tickets that relate to anything here is that for the Mirror, and for Knight's London? A. Yes.
SAMUEL GILBERT . I sell "Chamber's Information for the People."
FREDERICK HEADWORTH . I am assistant to Mr. Lamb, a pawnbroker, in Stanhope-street, Clare-market. I produce this Mirror, which was pawned on
the 11th of Jan., 1843; and the numbers of Knight's London, on the 5th of Jan.—I do not know who pledged them—I have the counterparts of the duplicates.

HENRY LUKE WINTON . I conduct the business of a publican, for my father—I have known the prisoner about two years—I bought these six num
bers of Froissart's Chronicle of him—I took them in monthly—I first took them seven or eight months ago—the prisoner came there, and I was shown the works—I paid him a shilling a number for them—sometimes I paid him in money, and sometimes he had spirits—I cannot tell how much money I have given him—we used to have a settlement, sometimes in two or three months—these twenty-three numbers of Knight's London, produced from the pawnbroker's I bought of the prisoner, and gave them to him to get bound—I never went to any shop with him—I always bought at home—I knew the prisoner lived at a tailor's shop, in New Inn-passage—I went before the Magistrate, and heard the charge made against him, and found that the twenty-three numbers I gave him to bind he had pawned at Lamb's—after that I called on Mr. Gilbert—I did not tell him that the prisoner should be well defended—I took my father's attorney with me to say that we would not give up any more books to Mr. Gilbert, but produce them before the Magis
trate.

Cross-examined. Q. Does your father keep the Crown Inn, in the Borough? A. Yes—I live at the Crooked Billet, in Wych-street, and manage the business for my father—I bought these books in a regular way, and gave a regular price for them—I took in Knight's London from the first—we did not send beer to the prisoner, but sometimes he has fetched it.
NOT GUILTY .

1013.
JAMES SIMS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Sept., 1 pamphlet, value 1s.; and 2 books, 1s.; the goods of
Samuel Gilbert, his master.

SAMUEL GILBERT . On the 9th of Feb., I gave the prisoner into custody—I went from information to Mr. Winton's—I there found a copy of Frois
sart's Chronicle, which I can speak to as having been once in my shop, from an off-set of the tissue paper which has injured the colouring of it, and here is a break in the first quarter of one of the banners—my attention was called to it, as on one occasion I offered it to a person for sale—he saw this and would not have it—I put it aside as unsaleable on the shelf—I never sold it to my knowledge—I can distinctly swear to this as having been in my possession at that time—I found at Mr. Mountcashell's, in Bedford-court, Covent-garden, two books, one "Ball-room Guide," and "Fancy Needle-work"—they were not published by me, but I had such in my stock—I cannot say I missed them as my stock is extensive—the prisoner had no right to sell any copies of mine, and never bought any to my knowledge.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You cannot swear you did not sell the copy of Froissart? A. No—I did not sell it to the prisoner, but I can
not swear that nobody in my establishment did.
THOMAS GILBERT . I am the prosecutor's brother—I did not sell this book to the prisoner—I have seen him buy Chamber's Journal now and then—they are 1 1/2 d. a number.
GEORGE MOUNTCASHELL . I am a bookseller, and live in Bedford-court, Covent-garden. I bought these two books of the prisoner.
HENRY LUKE WINTON . I bought this copy of Froissart of the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

1014.
LYDIA MANN was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Feb., 2 sheets, value 5s.; and 1 blanket, 2s.; the goods of
James Sansum.

ANN SANSUM . I am the wife of James Sansum, who keeps the Cheshire Cheese, Dean-street, Holborn. On the 13th of Feb., the prisoner came to me—I let her have a lodging, and did not charge her anything for it—these sheets and blankets were in the room—next morning she went out—I went into the room, and missed them—I locked the door, and went down stairs—I then went up to the room again, and the prisoner was sitting on the I spoke to her about these things—she said she had not seen them—she walked into the room, and I locked her in while I went to her husband.

ELEANOR DUNN . I am the wife of Martin Dunn. I keep a clothes' shop—the prisoner came to my shop, and brought this blanket to dispose of and about half-past eleven she brought one sheet, and between two and three the other sheet—these are them—I am quite sure she is the person.

Prisoner. I was distressed—I took the first articles to get some breakfast, and the second to get them some dinner—I told the landlady I would get them out again—I told Mrs. Dunn I did not sell them—I left one for 7d., the other for 6d., and the other for 9d.—I said I must have them at night.

ELEANOR DUNN
re-examined. When she brought them I said, "Are they yours?"—she said, "Yes, my dear, I want to purchase bread for my children."

ANN SANSUM
re-examined. When we were at the police-office next morning, the prisoner said, "I meant to have told you where I had taken them to."

GUILTY . Aged 45.—
Confined Two Months.

1015.
PATRICK COCKLING was indicted
for Stealing, on the 25th of Nov., 3 1/2 yards of rope, value 1s. 4d.; 1 paint pot, 2d.; 1 brush, 4d.; 1 quart of plaister of Paris, 6d.; 1 yard of chain, 6d.; 1 chisel, 1d.; 1 awl, 1d.; and 1 gimlet, 1d.; the goods of
John Charles Felgate, his master.

JOHN CHARLES FELGATE . I am a builder, and live at Stepney. The pri
soner was in my service—I knew where he lived—I had occasion to go to his house on the 25th of Feb.—I there found this plaister of Paris, this scaffold cord, and other articles—they all belong to me—the prisoner was my carman—he had not the use of these things, and had no occasion to have any of them at his house—I was using this brush just before Christmas.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. Have you many persons in your em
ploy? A. Yes, bricklayers and labourers—I used this brush for priming over the wood—it is a very particular brush—I have used it many times—the handle got splintered and hurt my hand, so I cut it, and rounded it off—I did not miss this rope till I found it at the prisoner's—I do not sell these things—I had not seen this rope on my premises for the last seven or eight weeks—I know it by the binding of it—all my ropes are bound at the end—most ropes are dipped, but mine are not—some are bound with fine twine, and some with coarse twine—I cannot state when I had this gimlet, but I swear to it as I have used it so many hundred times—my tools are kept in a box in my shop—if my workmen required an instrument they might use my tools—the last time I used this chisel might have been before Christmas—I bad a lot of this chain hanging on hooks in the shop—this piece was the shortest amongst it—I had four pieces be
sides this—this one has been often used for chaining the gate—I recollect buying five pieces of chain—I was particular in what I brought away from the prisoner's—I left several pieces of rope there, because I would not bring anything that I was not sure of—I know this brad-awl—I have used it so many times.
COURT. Q. Had he any authority to take them? A. No—I never sold him any.

EDWARD WANDERER TOWNSON . I am a policeman. I went to the pri
soner's house, and found a paper of plaister of Paris—the chain, the rope, the awl, and other things—these are the articles—the prosecutor was with me, but the prisoner was not there—I produced these articles to the prosecutor in presence of the prisoner—the prisoner said he had bought the plaister of Paris of his master, and the other articles he had had in his house for some considerable time.

Cross-examined. Q. Was anybody else present? A. Yes, my brother officer—the prisoner was charged with stealing these things from his master—I did not hear his master say it would be better for him to tell all he knew—I do not think he could have said it—I was close to him.
JAMES HAMS (police-constable K 248.) I was present and heard what Townson has stated—I found the paint-brush, the pot and cord, which the prosecutor identified.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 42.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Four Months.

1016.
JAMES JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Feb., 1 saucepan, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
John Wilson; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

1017.
JOHN LONGHURST was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Feb., 29lbs. of lead, value 5s. the goods of
James Brown.

CHARLES ATKINS (police-constable S 91.) I saw the prisoner about four o'clock in the morning on the 17th of Feb. in Grove-end-road, St. John's-wood, going towards the Eyre Arms tavern. He turned and came back—he had this lead tied in this handkerchief under his arm—I asked what he had got; he said, "Nothing particular"—I said, "You have slates, have you not?"—he said, "Yes"—I then said, "You have either lead or copper with it"—he said, "Lead, man, lead," and that he was going to take it to Mr. Ponsford's, in Grosvenor-square—he then said he fetched it from there last night, and took it to his lodging in Henry-street, Portland-town—I then took him to the station, and found in the bundle these eight pieces of lead—when put together they form one piece—it weighs 29lbs.—I went to an unfinished house at the back of the Eyre-arms, and found some lead gone—Mr. Brown was there, and identified this lead.

JAMES BROWN . I live in St. John's Wood-terrace. I have the care of a house in an unfinished state at the back of the Eyre Arms—on the 17th of Feb. I went to the house and found the policeman there—I looked over the house and missed this piece of lead from the water-closet—it had not been fixed—I saw it there the day before—I know it because I had had both the edges of it planed.

Prisoner's Defence. Being unemployed I had been round by the Eyre Arms the day before; I came down towards Lowdon's-road, and I saw a man coming out with a basket, which appeared heavy; he shot it at the end of a heap in the street; I saw him cover something over, as if to conceal it; I thought I would wait and see what he had got, and I found these pieces of lead; I put them in my apron and buried them in a heap of sand; in the morning I went and got them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Four Months.

1018.
ANN BRETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of Feb., 1lb. 6oz. of bacon, value 8 1/2 d., the goods of
William Barton and another.
WILLIAM BARTON . I keep a shop at Old Brentford. The prisoner came to my shop on Saturday evening the 18th of Feb.—she bought some tea,

sugar, and butter, and I saw her take a piece of bacon off the butter counter and bring it to the grocery counter—my shopman served her, and while he went for something else she took this bacon—I saw her going out—I stopped her, and brought her back—I asked what she had in her apron—she said, "Nothing"—I opened her apron and found this bacon—it is mine.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not in the middle of the shop? I told you to weigh it and I would pay you. A. No, it was not.
JAMES CUISHAN (police-sergeant T 15.) I took the prisoner—she said she had sixpence-halfpenny, and if it came to more she would pay for it—she put down sixpence-halfpenny on the bacon.
Prisoner's Defence. I asked him to weigh it, and he gave me into custody; I am as innocent as a baby.

GUILTY . Aged 54.—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1019.
JANE WALLIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Feb., 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shawl, 5s.; 1 bonnet, 1s.; 1 cap, 6d.; 1 shift, 6d., and 2 aprons, 1s., the goods of
Margaret Greenshields, her mistress; also on the 21st of Feb. 1 watch, value 15s.; 1 necklace, 1s., the goods of
Edward Church, her master; to both of which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Four Months.

1020.
THOMAS HARRIS PITMAN was indicted
for embezzling and stealing 20l., the monies of
Robert Williams and others, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Judgment Respited.

(Rev. Dr. Bolton, master of the Grammar School at Tiverton; John King
lish, medical student; and William Anthony Dean, clerk to a solicitor, gave the prisoner a good character.)

1021.
JOHN AUSTIN and
FREDERICK HAYNES were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 11 plates, value 9d. and 4 saucers, 3d., the goods of Susannah Hyams; to which

AUSTIN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.

HAYNES pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 13.

1022.
GEORGE WALLINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Feb., 1 printed book, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Munting; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined Nine Days and
Whipped.

1023.
HUIR MUIR was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Feb., 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
John Parry; also, on the 18th of Feb., 1 pair of shoes, 3s. 9d., the goods of
John Payne; to both which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

1024.
BENJAMIN EVANS was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of March, 4 bottles, value 6d., the goods of
John Henry Manners Sutton; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

1025.
JOSIAHREAD,
ELIZA BAILEY , and
JAMES THOROGOOD , Were
indicted for assaulting
Joseph Headington, a police-constable, in the execution of his duty.

JOSEPH HEADINGTON (City police-constable, No. 218.) On the night of the 20th of Feb. I was on duty in Holborn, near Brook-street—I saw Thorogood stripped, and in the act of fighting with some one—I went up, and desired him to put his things on and go home—he immediately struck me a violent blow in the breast, which caused me to stagger against the shutters—I laid hold of him by his neckcloth and one of his hands, to prevent his striking me again—Bailey and Read came up and laid hold of me at the same time—they both commenced striking and kicking me, with others that are not in custody—I was knocked down by either Bailey or Read, I cannot say which—they were both behind me at that time—there was a general scuffle—I was repeatedly kicked about the body by Thorogood, Bailey, and Read—I never let go my hold—Jackman came up to my assistance.

HENRY THOMAS JACKMAN (police-constable G 192.) On the night of the 21st of Feb., between twelve and one o'clock, I heard a rattle, and went in the direction of the sound of it to Holborn—I saw Headington on the ground, with one hand hold of Thorogood's neckcloth and his hand, and the other two prisoners were kicking and striking him—I went up, and said that would not do, and Thorogood immediately kicked me in the groin—I was knocked down, but I immediately regained my feet and took hold of him, and the others caught hold of me—I was struck repeatedly in the face by Bailey—we succeeded in taking them all into custody.
WILLIAM ARNOLD (Citypolice-constable, No. 204.) On hearing the rattle spring, I went up, and saw the prisoners striking and kicking the officers—I dragged Bailey away.
Read's Defence. I never struck the policeman at all.

Bailey's Defence. I had a few words with my husband that night, and went out, and got a little to drink. My brother got into a row, and when I went to see what was the matter, the policeman had got hold of him, and they said I was one; but I never struck the officer.
Thorogood's Defence. One of them caught hold of me by the handkerchief, and said, "You young b----, I will take you away."

READ—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BAILEY—
GUILTY . Aged 27.

THOROGOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

1026.
PAUL GARNSTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Sept., 3 desks, value 4l. 10s., the goods of
John Gillett, his master.

JOHN GILLETT . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Fetter-lane, the pri
soner worked for me. About the 22nd of Sept. he had some desks to work on in his own room—I met him on the 21st of February, and asked what he had done with them—he said he sold them to Mr. Willis for 10s.—I said I must give him into custody—he did not give me any money for them.
Prisoner. Q. Did I receive the whole of the materials of you? A. No—all the woodwork, but not the locks and hinges—they would not have been complete without them.

BENJAMIN WILLIS . In October the prisoner called on me to ask for employ—I said I had none—he called two days after, and said he had three desks to dispose of, he had not the means of furnishing them, and he wished to sell them—I bought three of them.
Prisoner. Q. Were they completed? A. No, in the rough, they were not half finished.
Prisoner. I admit parting with them, but they were not desks. Witness.
The work had not been so far advanced at to make them desks—I call them the carcase of the desk.

JOHN GILLETT
re-examined. I produce a desk—this is not one of the three I gave him—I have not seen either of them—I brought this to show the state the others were in—I should call it a desk—it was not cut apart—we make them in this state, and then it is cut and hinged.
Prisoner's Defence. It was no desk at all, it was only a box.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.

1027.
GEORGE WYLD and
THOMAS HANNON were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of Feb., 1 pair of trowsers, value 28s., the goods of
Thomas Parker.

JOHN CHESTERMAN . I am shopman to Thomas Parker, of Marylebone-lane. On the 16th of Feb. Wyld came to our shop for a patch, to repair his trowsers—I said we did not sell cloth—he left, and in ten minutes Hannon came for a waistcoat—he looked at a dark one—he got to the door, and pointed to one in the window—and while I went to get it, I heard the horse that the trowers hung on fall—I turned, and the horse was right across the shop—I did not miss the trowsers till the officer brought them, about half-past three o'clock—these are them—they are my master's—I had seen them safe at half-past eight in the morning.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you quite sure Hannon was in the shop? A. Yes—it was three quarters of an hour after that I saw him in custody—he came to the counter—the horse was in a back part of the shop, about six feet from the door—I had my back to it—there were not a great quantity of things hanging about it—I have been foreman to Mr. Parker eight or nine years.

JOSEPH DAVIES LEATHART . I live in Park-place, Bayswater. Between two and three, on the 16th of Feb., I saw the two prisoners and another just going into Manchester-square—I looked up the street, and saw they were followed by an officer whom I knew—I spoke to him, and we followed them down High-street, into Marylebone-lane—three doors from the corner they all three stopped—one looked into the prosecutor's window, and one went into the shop—I cannot say which went in first—he very soon came out, and they all three went some distance, to the corner of the mews—they there had some con
versation—all three came back, and Hannon went into the shop, and Wyld went in at the street-door—after some time my attention was drawn from them for a moment—I then saw them all three hurrying away from the house, and turning into the mews—I left the officer, and went to Wigmore-street, where the mews comes into—the officer then came to me, and I saw Wyld going along with a bundle—I seized him, and took the bundle from him—I was obliged to drop it in the struggle, and he kicked me very violently.

EDWARD WELLS . I was in Wigmore-street on the 16th—I saw Leathart straggling with Wyld—he asked me to assist him—the bundle dropped—he told me to take it up, and take care of it—I did, and on the way there was another struggle—the prisoner's hat fell off, and there was this key in it.

WYLD*—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HANNON*—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

1028.
GEORGE GIBSON and
JOHN GIBSON were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 24th of Feb., 12 tame rabbits, price 1l. 10s., the property of
Benjamin Barker.

BENJAMIN BARKER . I am a carman, and live in Chatham-gardens, Hoxton—I keep rabbits in a shed, which is locked with a padlock. On Friday, the 24th of Feb., I had twelve rabbits—I fed them, and locked them up from

half-past nine to ten o'clock—I went to work at a quarter to five on Saturday morning—I went home to breakfast about eight, and they were all gone—this one I will swear to, and this is the skin of another which I believe to be mine, and these two young ones I believe to be mine—they were but three days old when I lost them—I will not swear to them—the two young ones found by the officer correspond in age with mine, and they sucked from the mother, that I have got here, and that I can identify.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. There were a number shown to you? A. Only five—one was dead—I swear to two—three of them might not be mine—young ones will not suckle at any other rabbits.
ANN BARKER . On the 25th I went to the rabbit place—I saw a nail on the water-butt lid, and a knife by the shed door—it had been undone, and every one of the rabbits were gone from the shed.

JAMES BRANNAN (police-sergeant G 20.) On the 26th of Feb. I went to the prisoner's lodgings in Golden-lane—I knocked at a room on the first floor—one of the prisoners opened the door—they were both in bed—I said, "I have come after some rabbits"—George covered his head over with the bed-clothes—John said, "We have no rabbits"—I said, "Yes, you have; come, George, get up"—he said, "We have none here; the gentleman next door keeps rabbits, perhaps they are there"—I waited till they dressed—the other officer called out, "The rabbits are here"—I took the prisoners down stairs, and the rabbits were in a cupboard—I said, "I thought you had no rabbits here"—John said, "Yes, my brother came in with a man who was going to be distrained on, and I bought them of him"—I said, "Where is the white buck you were hawking about yesterday?"—I meant George—John said, "I killed it, as the saying is, to save his life"—I found the dead rabbit in the cup
board, and the doe and the young ones my brother officer took out of a bag in the cupboard—it was John Gibson's shop—he is a turner—I have repeatedly seen him at work in the shop—John said to George, "I told you it would come to this."
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know that George was at work for Mr. Clark? A. No—their house was half a mile from the prosecutor's.
George Gibson's Defence. I thought it was the landlord come after me for the rent.
(The prisoners both received a good character.)

GEORGE GIBSON—
GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

JOHN GIBSON—
NOT GUILTY .

1029.
MARY JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Feb., 2 shillings, 3 sixpences, 1 groat, 4 pence, 6 halfpence, and one farthing, the monies of
William Noonan.

WILLIAM NOONAN . I live in Plough-court, near Field-lane. I have known the prisoner three weeks—about one o'clock in the morning of the 28th of Feb., she knocked at my room door, and said she had been turned out of doors by the party she lodged with—my wife got up, and let her in—I had two shillings, three sixpences, and the other money stated in my pocket—I let her bide in the room, and went to sleep—I saw her go out about seven o'clock, and soon after I perceived my trowsers, which I left on the back of the chair, had been removed, and my money was gone—I afterwards met her in Whitechapel—I asked her if she was not ashamed, for robbing me—she began to cry, and offered me part of the money—I would not accept of it.
JANE SCOTT . I searched the prisoner, and found on her 2s. 5 1/4 d.—she
said it was part of the money, and the other money she spent in buying these shoes and cap.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

1030.
MARY ANN BLUNT was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Feb., 2 waistcoats, value 6s., the goods of
Charles Alexander and another.
CHARLES ALEXANDER . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Church-street, Marylebone—I have one partner. On the 20th of Feb., I missed a waist-coat—I have since missed another—these are them.

WILLIAM HAYWOOD . I am a pawnbroker. These two waistcoats were pledged by the prisoner—one on the 20th of Feb. for 3s., and on the Thursday after she offered another—I asked her age, and to whom they belonged—she said, to her father.
Prisoner. I had no victuals to eat, that caused me to do it.
CHARLES HOLLARD (police-constable S 311.) I went to the prisoner's father—there were six children—the mother had been ill, and they were in great distress.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Eight Days.

1031.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of Feb., 1 can, value 2l.; and 16lbs. weight of copper, value 2l., the goods of
James Scott Smith and another; and
JOSEPH TRALING
, for receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

FREDERICK EVEMY . I am carman to James Scott Smith, and George Smith. About two o'clock, on the 9th of Feb., I had a wagon at the White Swan-yard, Mile-end—I had a copper can then—I went on to Thomas's-street, Whitechapel—some one gave me information a little after three o'clock, and the can was gone—I went to Traling's house—I saw him, and told him I came to search for a can—he said I might search, he knew nothing about it—I and the officer searched, and found the can in an ash-heap, covered with ashes—it is copper—it was beaten in this way when I found it, but was quite sound when in my wagon—I can swear to it as my masters'—it has his name and number on it—it is worth two guineas when new.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you go over any other premises belonging to Traling? A. Yes—he has the front shop and the room where he was living in—there are other persons living above him—I have no doubt about that—I cannot say whether the yard was common to the whole of them—you get into the yard by going through his house—there if a passage that goes to the other part of the house, and leads to the street—you can get to the passage without going through Traling's house—a person could get into the yard without Traling seeing him.

REBECCA HOLLOWAY . I am the wife of William Holloway, and live in Princes-street, Whitechapel. About three o'clock in the afternoon of the 9th of Feb., I saw Smith come up the street with a can on his arm—he stop
ped against Traling's shop door, at the corner of Dunk-street—I went into my room to see if I could see where he went, and I lost sight of him.

Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear that he did not go down the Passage? A. Yes—he did not go that Way—the passage is in Princes-street, and the shop door in Dunk-street—I was at my own street door—he passed the passage—other persons live in Traling's house—they get to the house through the passage—there is no other way for persons who live up stairs to get in—I swear Smith did not go through the passage.
Smith. Q. Can you swear it is the can I had? A. Yes.
HANNAH HARRINGTON . I am the wife of John Harrington. About half-Past two o'clock, on the 9th of Feb., I was cleaning my bed-room window—

I saw the distillers' wagon—I saw a man walk on the opposite side, and when he came to the wagon he stopped in the road, and took a large copper can out of the basket that was in the wagon, took it in his arms, and went along King Edward-street with it—I do not know him.
GEORGE BEECHAM . I saw Smith with a can—it was then quite perfect—I went quite close to him.

GEORGE TREW (police-constable H 125.) I went to Traling's house in Dunk-street, Mile-end—I said I was an officer, and suspected he had a can that had been stolen out of that man's wagon—he said he had not, I was welcome to search—I said I should like to go into the yard and search it first—he said, "You had better search the shop first"—I went into the yard, and saw the can found under the cinder dust, against the back door—I after-wards searched the shop, and found under the counter, covered with rags, a large hammer all over wet, cinder-dust, and marks of copper on it—the can was very much knocked about—I compared the hammer with the holes in the can, and it exactly corresponds with them.
Smith's Defence. I am innocent.

(John Gudgeon, a shoemaker, in Collingwood-terrace; William Day, a shoemaker; Thomas Chandler Butt; Charlotte Dunning, the wife of a la
bourer in the dock-yard at Chatham, gave Traling a good character.)

SMITH—
GUILTY . † Aged 18.

TRALING—
GUILTY . Aged 41.

1032.
BRIDGET O'BRIEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Feb., 1 gown, value 3s., the goods of
James Franklin.

JAMES GOLDER . I live with James Franklin, a pawnbroker, in Totten-ham-court-road. About the 20th of February the prisoner came to our shop—we had a lot of gowns hanging up, and when she went out I missed one—I ran out, overtook her about twenty yards off, and found it under her shawl—I am sure it is my master's.
Prisoner. I was passing the door, a woman came out, and put it under my arm. Witness. There was nobody else there.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Three Months.

1033.
JANE BAILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 14tb of Feb., 4 shillings and 1 sixpence, the monies of
James Grant.

JAMES GRANT . I am a smith, and live at Kensington. About two o'clock in the morning of the 14th of Feb. I and my shopmate were in a private house belonging to Simpson—the prisoner and another woman came in—the man belonging to the room ordered them out—the prisoner went down first, and the other stopped to talk a bit—my mate went down, and I went down—the prisoner was stopping on the stairs, and pulled me about—I got away from her as soon as I could—when I got into the street I missed 4s. 6d. frorn my waistcoat-pocket, where I had 5s. 6d. when I went into the room—I had only two sixpences left—I had been to a meeting for the benefit of one of our workmen, who had met with an accident—I charged the prisoner with robbing me as soon as she came out—she denjed it, and said she had not any money—I took hold of her, and kept her till I saw an officer—I had seen money safe in the room—the prisoner was the only one who touched me.
Prisoner. You gave me 6d. Witness. No, I did not—I did not speak to her—I have seen her before—I did not say another girl had robbed me of 1s.

GEORGE DUNBAR (police-constable T 91.) Between three and four o'clock in the morning the prisoner was given to me in High-street, Kensington—the prosecutor was arguing with her to give up the 4s. 6d.—she said she had not got it—they were about 200 yards from the house—in taking the prisoner
to the station she took a sixpence out of her mouth, and said that was all she had.

Prisoner. I said all I had belonging to him; I had money that was not his. Witness. At the station I found this 4s. in her right side-pocket—I asked her if she had any more—she pulled out a purse from her left arm, containing four sixpences, a fourpenny-piece, and 1 1/2 d.

Prisoner's Defence. There was a child died, and the landlady told me to go to the public-house; I met the prosecutor, two men, and a girl; the pro
secutor said she had robbed him of 1s.; I came back; I met the prosecutor; he said, "I have 6d. "—I said, "What if you have?" he said, "Julia robbed me of 1s."—I said, "Very well;" he gave me the sixpence, and I took it; he said, "Give me the sixpence;" I said, "No, I will give it to your wife in the morning;" he then said I had robbed him of 4s. 6d.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Two Months.

1034.
JOHN HARVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Feb., 1 carpet, value 2l. 3s., the goods of
John Hard man Pickford and another.

THOMAS WALDREN . I am in the service of John Hardman Pickford and Henry Roberts, pawnbrokers, Wittam's-buildings. On the 23rd of Feb., about eight o'clock, I missed this carpet, which hung from the ceiling of the shop—I had seen it safe at seven.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know it by? A. The ticket was on it.

JOHN RUSSELL (police-constable G 165.) I stopped the prisoner, about eight o'clock in the evening, with this carpet on his shoulder—he said he brought it from Rochester-row, Clerkenwell, and was going to take it to his uncle's.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1035.
WILLIAM CLARK was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.

FANNY CRAWFORD . I am shopwoman an to Victor Dumas, a ladies' French shoemaker, in Regent-street. On the 23rd of September the prisoner called at Mr. Dumas's, and asked to look at some French goods—I asked him if it was wholesale or retail—he said wholesale—I showed him some—he asked the price, and said he kept a shop in the general line at Epsom—I asked if he sold shoes before—he said yes, English, but not French; he had sold Eng
lish ones for some time, but, from having many inquiries, he was induced to get some—I asked him what quantity he should want—he said about 30l. worth—I said we allowed three per cent, for ready money, or three months' credit on good reference—he referred to Mr. Hamor, of Bread-street-hill—I went to Mr. Hamor's, and saw a man named Morris—he was the person called Hamor by the prisoner—Morris said, "I am Mr. Hamor"—I said I am come to make inquiries respecting Mr. Clark of Epsom—"Oh, yes," said he, "I know Mr. Clark perfectly well"—I told him he had called on Mr. Dumas the day before, and wished to have some goods on credit; that he said he had known Mr. Hamor some time, and he would speak to his ability to pay—Morris said he had served him with goods at Epsom of the first quality, that he always paid his bills before they were due, and he was a respectable man; we could trust him with security, his customers were all noblemen and gen
tleman, and wanted articles of the first quality, and what he sent him was al
ways of the best—he said he knew he was established at Epsom, he had had the shop he was in three years, and he had supplied him with hardware and

tin goods—I told this to Mr. Dumas—in the afternoon the prisoner called again—he had eighteen pairs of prunella shoes, which he said he must have that day, as he had a customer waiting—on the 24th he came with a horse and cart, and had goods to the amount of 30l. or 35l.—I said he must be very particular, or he would very soon have a stock of soiled good—he said, "I have taken precaution against that, I have a large glass case come in, that occupies the side of my shop," and he said he was about to have a smaller one—Mr. Dumas asked him for a little ready money—he said it was not convenient for him then, but he should be in town in a few days, and would bring 10l.—Mr. Dumas then drew a bill—the prisoner did not come again—he wrote twice.
Cross-examined by MR. WYLD. Q. Had you ever seen him before he came to ask for the goods? A. No.

VICTOR DUMAS . I keep this shop—I parted with some goods to the pri
soner upon his representations, and the reference he had given me—I have been to Epsom—I did not find a shop belonging to Mr. Clark, with a glass in front; there was no such person—I have not been paid a farthing for the goods—he did not come to pay 10l.

Cross-examined. Q. When was it you went down to Epsom to inquire? A. Some days after he called; I went alone; I went to two places: the bookseller said, "I have lived here three years; I know many persons, but I don't know any person of that name."

JOSIAH ALLWORTH PASH . I am a shoemaker in the Old Kent-road—about the 21st of October the prisoner called at my house; he said he was about to open a shop at Epsom, and wanted a supply of goods to the amount of about 40l.—I said I generally did business for ready money, but if he gave good references and supplied half cash I would supply him—I was referred to Mr. Hamor, of Bread-street-hill—I went, and found him at home—it seemed a respectable wholesale warehouse—there were hampers, apparently full of goods, and the counting-house appeared so full that there was hardly room for me to sit down—I told him what I came for—he said Clark was a respect
able man—he had known him many years, and the whole of the family, they were respectable, his relations were farmers, that his wife had some inde
pendency, and I might safely trust him; he would prove a good customer—on the 28th of October the prisoner came again—I parted with some goods to him, to the amount of something over 20l.—he paid me 5l.—he took them away in a cart—he was to have come again, and taken part of them—on the 4th of November he came again, and I refused to let him have more—I wrote several letters to "Clark, Epsom," and they were returned.

THOMAS FOOT PIPER . I am a stay manufacturer, and live in Cheapside—on the 4th of Nov. the prisoner came to my warehouse; he said his name was Wil
liam Clark; he was residing at Epsom—he said he was going into business, and wanted some goods—I showed him some, and told him my terms—he referred to Thomas Hamor, Bread-street-hill—I sent my clerk there—after I had received a communication from him I saw the prisoner again, the same day—I asked if he had a lease of the premises at Epsom; he said no, he had not, he had taken the fixtures, and was going to fit it up in an expensive style—I saw him again on the 28th—he had upwards of 20l. worth of goods—he gave a bill, and that was all that I have seen of the payment—I went on the 15th of Nov., with the inspector, to Hamor's warehouse—there were several crates which appeared to be full, but we found they were stuffed with straw, and a few goods lying at top, for the purpose of show—there was a ledger and a day-book—there was an entry in the ledger dated 1821, to Jones,
Lloyd, and Co.—there was the copy of a banking book, dated 1821—there was not one transaction in any of the books of recent date.

JOHN KNIGHT . I am clerk to Mr. Piper—on the 27th of Oct. I went to No. 20, Bread-street-hill—I saw Hamor, or a person that answered to that name—the warehouse was then quite full of crates, and apparently it was a place of considerable business—I saw plenty of crockery-ware and sauce
pans, and other things strewed about—I said I had been sent by my em
ployer to inquire about a man named William Clark, that was opening a shop at Epsom—he said he knew him for some years—he gave as good an account as ever I heard, and I gave him a good character to my employer.

RICHARD SWIFT . I am a shoemaker, and live in Greville-street, Hatton-gar
den—in Nov. the prisoner came to me—he represented himself as William Clark, of Epsom—he wanted about 40l. worth of boots and shoes, as he was about to open a shop—I told him my terms were cash, and at last asked for a refer
ence; he referred me to Mr. Hamor—on the following day I saw him again, and on the 4th of Nov. I parted with the goods, to the amount of 39l. 15s.—I received 14l. in cash—I gave an invoice of the goods—they were in a hamper, and at the bottom of the hamper was a paper, stating the hamper was 12s. if not returned—he promised to bring 12l. more on the following Tuesday morning—he did not do so—I heard of some of my goods being in the bands of Mr. Davis, but did not see them—I have never been paid.
WILLIAM SADD . I went to Bread-street-hill at the request of my master—I saw Hamor—he said he had known the prisoner some time—he was of a good character, and trustworthy.

CHARLES JOHN CHAPMAN . I am in the service of Mr. Holland, of St. John-street-road. A person named Davis, at the latter end of Oct., brought me a sample of leather clogs and French shoes—he offered them to be sold at 2s. a pair—they were worth more.

JOHN HOLLAND . I am a shoe-manufacturer in Cheapside and St. John-street-road. About the 8th of Nov., a man who has been indicted, by the name of Davis, brought some articles to my shop—from having dealings with Mr. Swift, I recognised them as his—Davis showed me an invoice, and I recog
nised it as Mr. Swift's handwriting—the heading of it was cut off, but at the foot of the invoice it was stated that the hamper, if not returned, would be 12s.—I waited on Mr. Swift—Davis took me to a place near the Jews' sy
nagogue, and showed me the goods—I made an appointment, and went again with Mr. Swift, but no goods were there, nor Davis neither—I went to Mr. Hamor's, and saw Horner—he said he was acting as clerk—he introduced Mr. Hamor to me as Mr. Hamor.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Hamor? A. No, not previously.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1036.
WILLIAM BAKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Feb., 1 gown, value 2s., the goods of
John Ives.
MARTHA IVES . I am the wife of John Ives, and live in Willow-walk. I had a woman to wash a gown—I missed it on the 21st of Feb.—this is it—it is mine.

THOMAS NORTON . I am a carpenter, and live in Seymour-place, Bryan
ston-square. On the 21st of Feb. I saw the prisoner take the gown off the line, and run into a vault near Mr. Ives's house with it.
Prisoner. There were three or four more in the field; he was sixty or seventy yards away. Witness. There was no one in sight but you, you are the person.
EMANUEL JAMES . I live in Willow-walk. I saw the prisoner run into the vault—I examined it, and found the gown there.
Prisoner's Defence. I went there for a necessary purpose; I never saw the gown.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1037.
SAMUEL JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 shilling, the money of
Sarah Hanson.

SARAH HANSON . I am servant at Canonbury-terrace, Islington. The pri
soner came to sweep the chimney in the morning of the 27th of Feb.—I had 3s. 1 1/2 d. in my purse—I took one shilling out and put back the 2s. 1 1/2 d.—I turned my back to the back room—about nine o'clock I missed a shilling—no one bad been in the room but the prisoner from the time of my leaving 2s. 1 1/2 d. in the purse, and my missing a shilling.

WARD STANWELL . I am street-keeper. I went after the prisoner about eleven o'clock—I told him it was for stealing a shilling from No. 15, Canon
bury-terrace—he said he had not stolen anything—I took him to the house—he then put his band into his pocket, and said, "Here is the shilling, I did take it."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Ten Days.

1038.
JOHN OLDBURY BURNS and
WILLIAM WHEATLEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 1 saddle, value 1l. 5s.; 2 bridles, 18s.; 1 collar, 5s.; 1 pair of harness, 8s.; 1 crupper, 7s.; 1 breeching, 12s.; 1 belly-band, 2s. 6d.; and 1 pair of reins, 2s. 6d.; the goods of
William Ben
nett Bailey.

JOHN LYNCH . I am carman to William Bennett Bailey—the prisoners have been employed by him. Between seven and eight o'clock on the 24th of Feb., I hung up my harness—about ten o'clock I was sent for, and the door of the place where the harness was was open—(it was locked when I left it)—the harness was all gone—this is it—it is my master's—they must have used a false key to get in.

THOMAS MALIN (police-constable H 74.) On the evening of the 24th of Feb. I saw Burns with this harness in a sack, about a quarter before nine—Wheatley was in his company—I had seen Wheatley give Burns a lift up with it on his shoulder—when I detected Burns, Wheatley passed by.
Burns. I am a porter; I was employed to carry this.
(Burns received a good character.)

BURNS—
GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

WHEATLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Nine Months.

1039.
RICHARD MEAD and
JAMES MEAD were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of Feb., 8lbs. weight of pork, value 4s., the goods of
Charles Hobbs; and that
Richard Mead had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES HOBBS . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Sarah-place, Old-street-road. On Saturday evening, the 25th of Feb., I had a leg of pork safe between six and seven o'clock—I afterwards missed it—I saw it next in the hands of Kemp the policeman about a quarter past six o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You took Kemp into custody, did you not? A. I stopped him seeing him in possession of the pork, and then he turned out to be an officer in disguise—this leg of pork is worth 4s.—it was exposed in the window.

HENRY SMITH . I live in Wellington-street, Kingsland-road. On that Sa
turday

night I met Kemp—he pointed out three persons to me—Richard Mead was one, the others I cannot swear to—Richard had a basket with him I watched him—he walked up Pitfield-street and back again—he crossed over to Old-street-road, then they went by Mr. Hobbs's shop—Richard had the basket on his left arm, and with his right hand put the pork into it.

Cross-examined. Q. You were a stranger to Kemp? A. No—I know him by living many years in the parish—I know nearly all the police-con
stables—I do not walk about with them—I have walked about with Kemp when I met him accidentally—I know another policeman named Pretty George—I have gone with him when I met him accidentally—I am a press
man, and work for Mr. Nicholls, of Hoxton-square—I went out to take a walk that night and met Kemp—I was with him about ten minutes altogether—I had been to work that morning—I have walked with Kemp three or four times when he has been in plain clothes—I will swear it was Richard Mead who took the pork—I was ten yards from them—I and the policeman went to the station—I afterwards saw Kemp laid hold of by Mr. Hobbs—I dragged him from Kemp, and then I went home.
COURT. Q. Have you any doubt about Richard's taking the pork? A. Not the least.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) I was on duty in plain clothes in Pitfield-street. I saw James Mead, and I believe Richard, in company with another in Pitfield-street—I watched them, saw them loitering about and followed them—I saw them go to the prosecutor's shop—Richard passed and come back again with his basket—he put his hand on the board, pulled the leg of pork down, and put it into his basket—James was standing about two or three yards from the shop, looking to the shop—James had been with him before for twenty minutes—they then ran up the "Vinegar-ground, and I pur
sued.

Cross-examined. Q. You are not sure about Richard? A. No—I have known Smith about two years—I have occasionally met him—I have seen Richard before—I took James about two hours after in the Carlisle public-house—Richard came on Monday morning to the station, and then I said to the inspector, "I really believe this is the other"—I did not say I would shove the basket in his eye—I said if he did not go away I should take him—Pretty George was not present at the pork being taken—he knows nothing about it.

MARY ANN SCUDDER . I live in Devonshire-place, Old Nichol-street, Bethnal-green. I know Richard Mead—on Saturday, the 25th of Feb., he came into my house about five—he remained there till half-past seven—he had been to Billingsgate, and was very cold—I told him to sit down, and he had some tea at my house—Elizabeth Carpenter was present—Mrs. Cotton came in about half-past five, while Richard Mead was at tea.

COURT. Q. Are you sure he remained till half-past seven? A. Yes—I remember it, because at half-past seven I went out to ascertain the time, be
cause I had a baby who was ill to take to the doctor's—my husband was there and Carpenter, me, the prisoner, and Cotton—she came in about half-past five and staid about an hour—she did not drink or eat anything—Carpenter drank tea with me, my husband did not drink anything—he was at home, sitting in his own room, which is an adjoining room—I am sure he did not drink tea—the prisoner was doing nothing but sitting in my place and warming himself—he sat by the side of me—I do not recollect what we were talking about—we had bread and butter to eat—Carpenter was sitting at the table with me—the prisoner is no relation of mine—he drank nothing but tea—my hus
band

was in the room getting his tea—I do not know how many cups he drank—I did not take particular notice—I sat on one side the fire and my husband on the other—the prisoner sat at the table the same side as my husband.
MR. PAYNE. Q. What did you mean by saying your husband was in his own room? A. Mrs. Carpenter's husband was—she lives in the house with me.

ELIZABETH CARPENTER . My husband works in the docks—I live in De
vonshire-place, Old Nichol-street, in the same house as Scudder—on Saturday night, the 25th of Feb., I was in Mrs. Scudder's room from five till half-past seven—my husband was at home in his own room—Richard Mead was at Mrs. Scudder's—we had tea—Cotton was there—Scudder's husband was not at home—I am certain of that.

GEORGE KEMP . I produce a certificate of Richard Mead's former con
viction, which I got from the Sessions House, Clerkenwell—(read.)
PRISCILLA SARAH BARTLETT . I was present at the trial—the prisoner Richard Mead is the man.

R. MEAD†—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

J. MEAD—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

p.hi:
Sixth Jury, before
Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1040.
ARTHUR HARVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Feb., 1 purse, value 6d.; 13 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 crown, 3 half-crowns, 10 shillings, and 5 sixpences, the property of
John Smith; in a certain vessel on the navigable River Thames.

JOHN SMITH . I am captain of the Quicksilver, which trades from Sunder
land to London. The prisoner had been on board one passage—his mother remained in London—he came up with me as far as Gravesend—I then paid him, and he asked leave to stop till the Christmas holidays were over with his friends in London—he afterwards made application to be taken again—I ar
ranged that he was to go to Sunderland, and have 10s. for the voyage, and then become apprentice to the vessel—he came on board on Saturday, the 4th of Feb., at five o'clock—I had got all my business done, and was about pre
paring my vessel for the voyage—I took my purse out of my pocket, and put it into the register-box—there were thirteen sovereigns and a half in one end, and 25s. in silver in the other—I put the register-box into a drawer in the state-room—the prisoner was in the cabin—I counted my money before I put it away—he did not see me do that—I cannot say whether he was in the cabin when I did that—as soon as I got my tea I went on deck—as soon as the pri
soner had done his tea I went down to balance my cash—I heard a noise on deck, and the mate said the boat was gone—I determined then to send the other lad and the prisoner to look after the boat—when I looked after the pri
soner he was not there—they were all on board but him—I went down, opened the box, and missed my purse—I have never seen it since—the pri
soner had left his hammock and all his things behind—I gave information.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long had you known him? A. He came from a place in the North—the mate, Joseph Deane, and the prisoner, had quarrelled on the passage up from Middleborough—the mate quarrelled with all hands—it was about ten minutes from the time I left the cabin till I went down again—I left Bassett in the cabin—I am sure I put my purse into the register-box—the prisoner ought to have been there before that Saturday, but his mother had written to me to say he was not well—I did not hear the mate or any man grumble at him for not being on board before.

FREDERICK BASSETT . I am nephew to one of the owners of this Vessel. I was on board on the 4th of Feb.—I was going as a passenger—I remember the prisoner's being in the cabin in the evening—I saw Captain Smith count his money—the prisoner had an opportunity of seeing that—I saw the Captain put it away—he had his tea, and went on deck—after he was gone up, the prisoner put away the tea things—while doing so he went near the cupboard—he opened the door, which prevented my seeing into the berth, and went into the sleeping berth—I could not see the drawer in which the register-box was kept, but I beard it opened—he came out again directly, and went right out of the cabin—just before this he asked me to go into the mate's bed—I told him it was too soon—he asked me to go on deck, and see the cargo stowed in the hold, but I declined it—in five minutes after he left the cabin the captain missed his money.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he leave the cabin more than once? A. Yes, once before—there was only one way of getting into the cabin, unless by shoving up a board—the mate's berth is not far from the captain's—it is in the same cabin—the mate was in the hold, stowing the goods—he could get into the cabin from the hold by pushing up the board—I never quarrelled with the prisoner—I only saw him that day—no one went into the cabin from the time the captain left the deck, till he came back—I was not asleep—I did not take the money.

THOMAS TYLER (police-constable N 225.) I received information on Satur
day night, the 4th of Feb., and went to the prisoner's mother's house—I looked for him in the neighbourhood—I saw him a fortnight after, about a quarter past twelve o'clock at night, between the Angel and his mother's house—he passed me with his mother—I turned round, and said, "Jack," or something of that sort—his mother stopped—I said, "Arthur, how long have you been home from sea?"—he said, "Not long"—I said, "You must con
sider yourself in my custody"—he laughed—I said, "For stealing some money from the Quicksilver, a vessel lying at the Tower"—he said, "I don't know it, I never was on board"—he had all new clothes and hat and shoes—I took him to the station, and asked how he got all these clothes—he said he had them at home—the sergeant asked if the Quicksilver was a schooner or a barge—he said he knew nothing about it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to his mother's before? A. I went there on Saturday night, the 4th of Feb.—I did not go again, but I watched it pretty closely—I am quite sure he said he knew nothing about the Quick
silver or the robbery.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Two Months.

1041.
LYDIA GORMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Feb., 4 yards of a certain cloth, called Orleans, value 2s.; and 1 pair of stockings, 8 1/2 d.; the goods of
