David Le Boutillier; and that she had been before con
victed of felony.

MILES GABRIEL . I am in the service of David Le Boutillier, a linen-draper, in Northumberland-place, Commercial-road. On the night of the 23rd of Feb. I missed four or five yards of Orleans cloth from inside the door—it was pinned—I then concealed myself behind some goods—in five minutes I saw the prisoner come to the door, and take hold of a piece of plain cloth, which I had seen unpinned—she then came and took a pair of stockings, which were on the stick, hung to an iron—she then unpinned the piece of Orleans cloth, came back, took the stockings away, and out them under her

shawl—I went after her, and caught her by the waist—she dropped the stockings—I pushed her into the shop, ran for a policeman, and gave her in charge—these stockings belong to my master—I have not seen the cloth again.

Prisoner. Q. When you first took me, did you mention about any Or
leans? A. No; I did not know it was gone till I went back.

HENRY ISAACS . I live in Swallow's-gardens—I was in the Commercial-road—I saw the prisoner and two more with her—I saw her unpin a plain dress; she then went on the left-hand and unpinned another, but did not take it—in a few minutes she returned, put her arm up, and laid hold of the stockings—I saw her take the stockings—when the witness caught hold of her round the waist, she dropped them—the witness took up the stocking—these are them.
SAMUEL WIGGINS (police-constable K 73.) I took the prisoner—she said, in going to the station, she did not care; there could not be much done to her, as they were not of much value.
LAMBERT WILKINSON (police-constable G 175.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.

1042.
REUBEN LIDSTONE was indicted
for embezzling and stealing, on the 1st of Oct., 60 screws, value 9d.; and 1 set of dampers, 7s.; the goods of
Daniel Chandler Hewitt, his employer.

JAMES WHIPP (police-constable D 86.) On the 17th of Feb. I had a war
rant to search the prisoner's house in Grove-street, Camden-town—Mr. Hew
itt's pianoforte factory is in High-street, Camden-town—they are both close together—I went to the prisoner's house, accompanied by Mr. Hewitt—I found a brown paper parcel, directed to Mr. Hewitt, in the prisoner's cup
board, the prisoner said that the parcel had been left there by the maker, instead of taking it to Mr. Hewitt's shop—this is the parcel—(produced)—here is written on it "Mr. Hewitt, one set of dampers."

Cross-examined by Mr. WYLDE. Q. This was on the 17th of Feb.? A. Yes—Mr. Hewitt was present, a person named Bonny, and another man, whose name I do not know—I did not take down the words which the prisoner made use of—he might have said that the maker may have left them there, but I do not think he did—he offered no obstruction—he gave me all the as
sistance he could—he went to the cupboard, and brought these—they were not locked up.

DANIEL CHANDLER HEWITT . I am a manufacturer of pianofortes, on a new principle, in High-street, Camden-town—the prisoner was in my service at this time, and had been for four years; during the last two years as fore
man—I employ a person named Hall to manufacture what are called dampers—his dampers have something peculiar about them—the prisoner had no au
thority to take any of my dampers, or any other property, to his house in Grove-street—if they had been delivered to him in Oct. it was his duty to bring them to my establishment, and place them among my stock—I have seen this book before—(looking at one)—it is called a pass-book—when goods are delivered, the person who receives them signs his name—this book is generally kept at the factory—if Mr. Hall had sent goods, he would have en
tered them, and the person who receives the goods would sign it—I find the last entry of the prisoner for dampers is on the 15th of Oct.; two sets were delivered then; I have received none since—the prisoner had no right what
ever
to have them at his house—I cannot say whether these were ever in my stock.

Cross-exanincd. Q. During the whole of the time he has been with you, you had every reason to be satisfied with his conduct? A. I had some rea
son to be dissatisfied—these dampers are cut at a different angle to other per
sons—the prisoner was my traveller as well as foreman—I constantly cor
responded with him—there are letters of the 1st of Feb., 1843, from me to him—I had several persons working in my employ—there are no written in
structions in my shop as to the course of conduct the men are to pursue—I generally gave the instructions individually; but the prisoner, as foreman, generally gave the instructions—he had considerable discretion as to what the men should do—I have very recently discharged his brother, who had been in my service—the prisoner may be acquainted with the secrets that I had in making these pianos—I have told him many of them, but many I have not—I wished to have his practical experience, and therefore I communicated to him the principles on which I proposed building the pianos—I have some
times travelled myself, and then he has had the management of my business—I have had no suspicion that he intended to leave me—this letter is my writing—I do not know a person named Grandison—the prisoner behaved in a very extraordinary way, and I suppose he thought I was going to send him away—I had no idea of discharging him—it would be impossible to tell when I had these—the prisoner was in Devonshire, on my behalf about three weeks before the 17th of Feb.
MR. DOANE. Q. Has he availed himself of some of these secrets? A. Yes; he has been travelling for me from Nov. till about three weeks ago.

WILLIAM HALL . I am a manufacturer of small work for pianofortes, and live in Whittam-place, Upper Holloway—I have manufactured dampers for Mr. Hewitt many times—I made a difference in his dampers from those of other manufacturers—the last I made for Mr. Hewitt were three sets at one time, delivered Oct. 10th—I have two persons in my establishment be
sides my son, Isaac Tarry and Josiah Blanch—they are all the persons who carry out goods—this signature in this entry of the 10th of Oct. is Mr. Hew-itt's—this set of dampers is of my manufacture—they are such as I manu
facture for Mr. Hewitt, and different from what I manufacture for others—I have a particular saw which I began to use some time since June—I am able to say these dampers most have been in my manufactory since June—I have myself delivered dampers at Mr. Hewitt's factory—I never delivered damp
ers, or any other articles, at the prisoner's house—I do not know where he lives—I never gave directions to my son or to my men to deliver any to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. What other work is done to them before they are used? A. They are cut in pieces—these dampers would make sixty divisions; they are cut, and secured with little screws—if I had met the prisoner, I should have hesitated to deliver him a parcel of goods—I never took goods and found the factory shut.

MR. DOANE. Q. Do you call these a set of dampers? A. Yes, it is wood covered with woollen cloth, and there are screws in it—all I have sent have been paid for, except the last delivery, and they are still debited to Mr. Hewitt.

ALFRED HALL . I am son of William Hall. The direction on this brown Paper parcel addressed to "Mr. Hewitt, one set of dampers," is my handwriting—I wrote it for the purpose of being sent to Mr. Hewitt—I have never taken any dampers to the prisoner's house—I do not know where it is—I have
always delivered them at the factory—our parcels are always folded up and sealed in this manner—I cannot state when I wrote this.

ISAAC PARRY . I am in Mr. Hall's service. I have been in the habit, since June, of carrying things to Mr. Hewitt—I never took dampers, or anything, to the prisoner's house, and sever delivered them to him out of the factory.

JOSIAH BLANCH . I am in Mr. Hall's service. I have taken dampers from him to Mr. Hewitt's in Camden-town—I have never taken any thing of the kind to the prisoner's house—I have never delivered any thing to him out of the factory.
Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. Are you well acquainted with the pianoforte trade? A. I have been in it five years—it is not the custom of persons to take work home to their own house.

MR. CROUCH to MR. HEWITT. Q. If he had attended to his work, and finished it at home, would there have been any objection on your part? A. Yes, decidedly; there was no reason at all why it should be done at home—he might have done some very insignificant things at home.
NOT GUILTY .

1043.
REUBEN LIDSTONE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of June, 16 pieces of wood, value 12s.; 9 pieces of wood, called veneers, 15s.; 1 plane, 1l.; 3 castors, 4s., the goods of
Daniel Chandler Hewitt.—2nd COUNT, for stealing 4 picture frames, value 2l.; 3 boxes, 11s.; 1 nest of drawers, 3l.; 1 square, 2s. 6d.; 1 rule, 2s. 6d.; 1 plane, 1l.; 3 castors, 4s.; the goods of
Daniel Chandler Hewitt, his master.

JAMES WHIPP (police-constable D 86.) I went to the prisoner's home in Camden-town on the 17th of Feb. I first read the warrant—when I came to the word "plane" the prisoner said, "Oh, I have got the plane!"—he went to the cupboard in the front parlour and produced it—Mr. Hewitt said that was his plane—I then went to the cupboard and found two castors—this other castor I found in the bed-room—the prisoner said he put them into his pocket when he was at work, went home, threw off his coat at home, and they were left at home—I afterwards found these two boxes in his bed-room—they were pointed out by Bonney—he said in the prisoner's presence, "Mr. Hewitt, these are your property; they are made of your wood"—the prisoner said they were not Mr. Hewitt's wood, and Bonney bad not made them—in the front parlour I found this square, which was pointed out by Bonney, who said it was made of Mr. Hewitt's wood, and he had made it—the prisoner said it was not Mr. Hewitt's, and Bonney had not made it—I found a rule in a small box on the parlour table—Mr. Hewitt said it was his rule—it was marked with the prisoner's name—I afterwards found four picture-frames which Bonney said he made, or assisted in making, out of Mr. Hewitt's wood—the prisoner said they were not Mr. Hewitt's wood, and Bonney had not made them—I then took him into custody—I afterwards searched a box of his and found a nest of drawers—Bonney stated they were made of Mr. Hewitt's wood.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. When you went in what did you say? A. That I had a warrant to search his house—I said, "Consider yourself in custody, and what you state now I shall have to repeat in evidence before the Magistrate"—Mr. Hewitt and Bonney were there—upon my oath the prisoner said Bonney did not make them—the picture frames were hanging round the room.
EDWARD BONNEY . I am a pianoforte maker, and live in Great Clarendon-street,

Somers-town. I was formerly in the serivce of Mr. Hewitt—I was so in June, 1841—I remember Mr. Hewitt being ill, and being in the country—the prisoner was foreman, and I was under his orders—while Mr. Hewitt was away I made this nest of drawers by the prisoner's order in the factory during the usual business hours—I made them out of Mr. Hewitt's wood—the prisoner said he had liberty from Mr. Hewitt to make them, or any thing he liked—I made these picture-frames by the prisoner's orders out of Mr. Hewitt's wood, partly at the factory, and partly at my own house—I made this drawing square by his orders out of Mr. Hewitt's wood—it is the same wood as is used at the factory—I delivered it to the prisoner after I made it—these two boxes were made by the prisoner himself at the factory, during Mr. Hewitt's absence, of Mr. Hewitt's wood—I cannot speak of this rule—I have seen such an one about—this plane, I believe, belongs to Mr. Hewitt.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. How came you to leave? A. I do not know—I left Mr. Hewitt, but I do not know on what grounds—I know a man named M'Gregor—he did not accuse me of stealing his tools—the prisoner and another person did not accuse me of stealing his tools—it was a pawn ticket, not tools—they brought up other things as well—there was nothing about a jacket—I had some tools of my own stolen from the factory; among them there was an iron stock—on that account they said I had stolen the ticket, as it appeared that the tool M'Gregor lost was a stock—the pri
soner discharged me about ten months ago—I made these things about June, 1841—I made the drawers, the picture-frames, and the square—I began to make them about June, 1841—I might be about two months doing them—I did not tell my master till the week of the prisoner's examination—I never told my master that I had any misunderstanding with the prisoner—I will swear these picture-frames are my own work—I did not know it was wrong—the prisoner said he had leave from Mr. Hewitt to do any thing he liked—there was Wales and several other persons at work when I made them—this nest of drawers was kept in the prisoner's tool-chest—he told me it was his chest—I made all the internal work of the chest—every man has a tool-chest in the factory—my master came backwards and forwards—the prisoner was in the habit of using all the tools in his chest in his master's business—I am not aware whose tools were in his chest—I had not access to it—it was kept in his own bench room—I have seen his tool-chest open many times, and when other persons were by.

MR. DOANE. Q. There was nothing particular in such a nest of drawers being in a tool-chest? A. No; all the men have similar tool-chests, and nests in them—Mr. Hewitt was not able to come out of his door during the three months he was ill.

ROBERT WALES . I am a pianoforte-maker, and live in Gress-street, Rath
bone-place; I work for Mr. Hewitt. In June, 1841, I was at Mr. Hewitt's factory at times—I saw Bonny at work on this nest of drawers, and on some picture-frames—I believe these are the same—I have worked with this plane—it is Mr. Hewitt's.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. You saw these things made in the shop? A. Yes—he used to make them on Wednesday and Saturday—there was no concealment in it—I know M'Gregor—I believe he lost some tools—he did not accuse any one of taking them that I am aware of—Bonny was dismissed, I do not know what for—I do not know of the prisoner having any wood of his own.

DANIEL CHANDLER HEWITT . I am a pianoforte-maker; the prisoner was in my service four years. During June, 1841, I was laid up, and was unable to attend—during that time the prisoner had the control of the men and the

business—I did not authorize him at that time, or at any other, to have things made up out of my wood—he had no right to take castors to his own house, or my plane—I went to his house, and found all these things there, but the nest of drawers—they were afterwards found in the tool-chest—he had no authority to do as he did—he had no wood of his own in the factory, to my knowledge.

JURY. Q. Did this nest of drawers form part of the fittings of his tool
chest? A. Yes; the outer case was his tool-chest, and this was made to put in it—I never saw it open, and if I had I should not have known it was my wood.

Cross-examined by MR. WILD. Q. When can you swear to having seen the castors and plane? A. I cannot swear to them—I believe them to be mine—I do not know when the things were there—I received information that there was some property of mine on the prisoner's premises on the Tuesday evening after he returned from Devonshire.

Q. Did not the prisoner offer you to go to his house some months before? A. There had been a disturbance in the factory—he had been charged with having things, and he said I might go to his house and search—he had told me that Bonny had said that he (the prisoner) had things of mine in his house, and I wrote to the prisoner, saying I should not dismiss him; for I did not believe it then; but when, on this occasion, I sent fur Bonny, and he told me this, I did believe it—the prisoner lodged in the same house with me for a time—I did not write letters to him as though he Were a brother—he lived with me some months in Bayham-terrace, Camden-town—I should not have permitted the workmen to have wood in the factory, if I knew it—there was a good deal of wood, and there might be some of theirs, but there was no business to be—I do not know what quantity of satin wood I had in June, 1841—I think I had some—I am not in the habit of taking minute notice of what I have—I had no means of keeping a correct account of the wood—I could not swear that there was any satin wood there in June, 1841—when I was not there the wood was in the prisoner's care, and when I was there he had access to it—there were three little cellars with wood in them—I do not believe he had any wood there—he could not have had any of any value, the place was not big enough.

MR. DOANE. Q. Had he any right to have this plane at his house, and to carry it backwards and forwards? A. He had no work to do for me at his house which he would want a plane for—about July last he told me that Bonny bad accused him of having some of my property, and then I wrote this letter, and declined going to his house—if I had seen these things I should not have had the least idea that they were made out of my stock—I never gave him leave to have this nest of drawers made, or the picture-frames, or other things—I never beard of his having wood on my premises—some men once said that they had wood on my premises, but the figures on the wood were joined, and it proved to be mine, and then I ordered that none of the men should have any wood on my premises.

MR. WYLD. Q. Did you not allow the prisoner to take any tools to his own premises? A. No—there were tools he had when he travelled, which he was to bring back, box and all—he might have brought them from the country, and taken some of the tools home—it was not so much tools as small things that he carried; he certainly would not want to carry castors and planes.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1044.
RICHARD SIMPSON and
GEORGE STACEY were indicted for
an assault, with intent, &c.—Other COUNTS, charging certain indecent acts.

SIMPSON—
GUILTY . Aged 47.

STACEY—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

1045.
JAMES THOMAS was indicted
for assaulting
Henry Maley, on the 13th of Feb., with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

1046.
JAMES RAWLINGS was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 79 1/2 yards of lawn, value 38s., the goods of
Thomas Allen and another, his masters; and
JAMES NEWCOMBE
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

MOSES MARTYN . I am warehouseman in the vice of Messrs. Allen and Smith, who live in Friday-street, Cheapside. On the 21st of Jan. I was ordered to conceal myself—Amos Hayton was at the entry-desk in the counting-house at that time—Rawlings, who is a porter in the house, was directed to remain in the warehouse while the others were gone to dinner, and not to leave—he was left in charge of the warehouse—I concealed myself behind the counting-house—about half-past two o'clock I watched Rawlings, and saw him go into the linen-room, to a box in which some lawns were—I bad counted the pieces of lawn in that box about five minutes before, and found forty-nine pieces—I saw him put his band on the goods—his back was towards me—he instantly left, and walked behind some boxes which were standing in front of the warehouse—I then came forward from my hiding-place, and asked what he was doing there—he said he was looking for a sheet of paper—I immediately went to the box, counted the pieces, and found three pieces were missing—in the meantime Rawlings walked forwards, and Hayton told me he was gone out—I went in, search of him, and could not find him—in about an hour he returned—Mr. Allen called him into the counting-house, and afterwards gave him into custody—no one had any pos
siblity of getting to the box between the time of my finding forty-nine pieces of lawn and counting them again, and finding only forty-six, except Rawlings—there are three pieces of lawn here now—I am able to say that this is one of the forty-nine pieces which I saw in the box before I saw Rawlings go to it—I know it by the "No. 591" on it—the marks have been removed from the other two pieces—I had observed this number on them before—here are several other pieces of the same lot, and the same manufacture, but there is no mark or number to enable me to detect them—they contain about six yards and a half in each, and are wrapped in green.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. There is only one that you can swear to as having been in the box? A. No—the manufacturer puts the number on it—we get them in round numbers, from 591 to any number we like—there may be a great number sent out from the same manufactory with "591" on them.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do they come in duplicate pieces? A. Yes—these are half pieces—I have brought the other half piece from the warehouse, which is the duplicate to this "No. 591"—there were seven of these" No. 6" in the box, and three of them were missed.

AMOS HAYTON . I am in the prosecutor's service. I remember on the 21st of Jan. Rawlings was directed not to leave the premises—I did not know at that time that Martyn was concealed—Rawlings asked me for a sheet of paper—I told him he would find one in the Irish warehouse, which is the place where it is kept—he went there, but I could not see what he did—I saw him go to the part where the lawns are kept—shortly after Mr. Martyn made his appearance suddenly—Rawlings came away, and went out—he had no occasion to go, and I had not given him leave—in about an hour he returned and Mr. Allen gave him into custody—I was present when Mr. Smith gave Rawlings direction not to leave.

NICHOLAS PEARCE . I am an inspector of police of the A division. In con
sequence of information, I went on the 7th of Feb. to the shop of Wallis and Southwood, in Parliament-street, and found these six pieces of lawn, which are the subject of this inquiry.

WILLIAM SOUTHWOOD . I am in partnership with Mr. Wallis, a linen-draper, in Parliament-street. I believe these six pieces were bought of Newcombe; but my partner buys the goods—I was not present—I delivered these goods to Mr. Pearce.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you before this bought similar pieces to these of Newcombe? A. We have bought lawns with the same name on them.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. How much did you pay for these? A. I am not certain, but I see that one is marked to sell at 1s. 4d.

SAMUEL SPARROW WALLIS . I am in partnership with Mr. Southwood. I bought these six pieces of lawn of Newcombe, at 1s. a yard—I bought nine other pieces at the same time—I think I bought ninety-six yards and a half.

THOMAS ALLEN . I am partner with Mr. Smith—we are warehousemen, in Friday-street. These lawns, as charged to us by the manufacturer, average about 2s. a yard—I should say 1s. a yard is not a fair price for them—we should be happy to buy any quantity at that price, if we could buy them fairly—on the 21st of Jan. I directed Martyn to conceal himself—we had missed upwards of fifty pieces of lawn—Rawlings was to be told by my partner to remain in the warehouse while the others went to dinner—we sell these lawns at 1d. or 2d. a yard profit—we get four or five per cent, on them—there is no doubt about this one, "No. 591," being ours, and the others too.

HENRY SMITH (police-constable E 148.) I have been lately searching into some transactions in the neighbourhood of Friday-street, among the warehousemen—I found that a number of the porters of the warehousemen were in the habit of congregating at the Admiral Carter, in Bartholomew-close, which is kept by Deadman—I took a lodging there, for the purpose of watching those persons—I have seen Rawlings and Newcombe there, talking and drinking together—I saw Rawlings there several times while he was in the employ of Allen and Smith—I have watched him when he went from the Admiral Carter, to Allen and Smith's, in Friday-street, and gave them in
formation—the last time I saw the prisoners together, previous to the 21st of Jan., was on the 17th of Jan.—they were then in conversation—Newcombe went to the bar and changed a sovereign, and gave Rawlings some money, or some money passed between them—I apprehended Rawlings on the 11th of Feb., in the Commercial-road—I said, "I am a police officer, and you are my prisoner"—he said, "What for?"—I said, "For stealing seven pieces of lawn of Mr. Allen, your late master"—he said, "Very well, I will go quietly with you."
Rawlings' Defence. On the 21st of Jan., when he accused me of taking three pieces of lawn; he said, "If I would not go into the warehouse, and

tell him where it was he would give me into custody; I said I had not seen any; he said Mr. Martyn saw me take it; I did not go out for ten minutes, and if he saw me take them, there was plenty of time for him to take me; there were other porters in the warehouse; Mr. Smith told me to wait till some one came, and when I saw Martin, I said, "If you will wait I will go;" he made no answer.
(Joseph Mallett, servant to Mr. Cullam, a brewer, gave Rawlings a good character.)

RAWLINGS—
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Transported for Seven Years.

NEWCOMBE. Aged 39.—
GUILTY .

1047.
GEORGE COWARD was indicted for
stealing, on the 6 Oct., 30 1/2 yards of waistcoating, value 8l.; the goods of
John Smith and another, his masters and
JAMES NEWCOMBE
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

SYDNEY SMITH . I am in partnership with John Smith—we are woollen and Manchester warehousemen, and live in King-street, Cheapside. Coward was our porter—on the 6th of Oct., he was desired to take two trusses of silk and wollen which were to be returned to Mr. Norton—they were called waist
coatings, and I believe Coward went away as though to take them—I do not remember his returning—I should think about five or six days afterwards, I questioned him about this parcel delivery book—I asked him how it was the two trusses had not gone back—he said they had—I said, "It appears they have not, and beside that there is only one in your entry for them"—I had asked for the book when I heard the trusses had not gone back—this figure which is now a 2 in this book was then a 1, and the word "One" is written un
der it as being received by Pickford—the prisoner said, "I tied the two trusses together"—that satisfied me that it might be so, and that they had been taken as one by Pickford—on the 8th of Feb., the officer showed me these goods which are here—I than looked at Coward's book again, and found the figure I had been altered to a 2, but the word "One, Pickford and Company," re
mained—I have examined these two pieces of waistcoating which are here, and they correspond in pattern and quality with the goods I expected to re
ceive from Mr. Norton—I do not know whether the trusses had been opened or not, but I received the invoice, and I said, "Let them go bank"—these are precisely the description of goods which I had ordered, and which I desired might go back—they amounted to 8l. 0s. 7d., at 5s. 3d. a yard—Coward had access to the warehouse—his wife and him slept there.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are we to understand that you saw the contents of either of these trusses, or that on the 6th of Oct, you saw either one or two delivered to Coward? A. I did not—I was as that time very busy about my own private affairs—I did not send a vast quantity of goods back—I had very few—I do not recollect tending any others back, but these on the 6th of Oct.—I did not see these trusses—I ordered them to go back—I can only tell the contents of them from the invoice—these are called waistcoating—they are known in the trade by that name.

JOHN AYRES . I am porter to Messrs. Pickford and Co., of Wood-street. On the 6th of Oct. Coward came to the wharf, and brought one truss, not two tied together, but one single truss, directed to Norton Clayton West—he pro
duced this book (looking at it) for me to check it with the figure 1, and I put my initial A on it, and the figure 6—I then handed it to him to take to Mr.
Edwin—I recollect at the time there was but one truss—if there had been two tied together, I should have noticed it.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you see the truss? A. I did not—it is not usual to weigh the goods, unless they are carriage-paid—those that are not paid are weighed at the station at Camden-town—small parcels might be sent without weighing, but this was a truss, and would be weighed at Camden-town.

THOMAS EDWIN . I am clerk to Messrs. Pickford and Co. I was in their employ on the 6th of Oct.—I have examined this entry in this parcel-book—this is not the way in which it left our office, it has been altered from a 1 to a 2—this word "One" and "T E" is my writing—I should not have written "One" if there had been a 2—I did not see the truss myself.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you know any thing about the bales? A. I did not see them—you can see where the I has been; and, to the best of my belief, it has been changed to a 2—I can see the remains of the 1.

GEORGE GELDER . I am clerk and traveller to Mr. Norton, of Clayton West, near Huddersfield. About the 21st of Sept. I received an order from Mr. Smith for waistcoating—amongst others, these two pieces were forwarded to him; and a third piece, corresponding with this small pattern—they were sent on the 4th of Oct.—I expected to receive these back—we received as piece, but not these—Mr. Norton then went to London—these were invoiced at 5s. 3d. a yard.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. you had things of this kind? A. Yes—I did not take them to the carrier or the railway.
Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. There was some order sent to your master about the 20th or 21st of Sept.? A. Yes—this was not the only Order we had for waistcoating—we had a variety of orders.

SAMUEL WOOD . I am a fancy weaver, and live at Malthorp, near Hudden-field. I am employed by Mr. George Norton—I wove the piece ef waist
coating from which this little pattern has been taken between the 20th and 30th of Sept. last—I also wove one of these two pieces, but not the other—this is the one I wove—each piece was ten yards and a half long—I never saw a piece of exactly the same pattern as this is—I never made one of the same figure before—I delivered them to the person who takes in work for Mr. Norton—this other piece I saw on the 16th of Feb.—it is the same descrip
tion as mine, hut I did not weave it.

GEORGE GELDER
re-examined. This other piece was woven for us by one of our weavers, and it is one of the pieces that was forwarded to London.

HENRY SMITH (police-constable G 148.) In consequence of direction, I placed myself as a lodger at the Admiral Carter—I saw Newcombe there, and Coward was there almost everyday—I have seen them in conversation toge
ther, and they have dined together there.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. When did you first set them? A. About the 27th of Dec.—I found out the house on the 23rd, and on the 24th I took lodgings there—I do not know whether it is a house of call for porters—there is a cobler's stall outside the house, but not-a pitching-block.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you see a great many linen drapers' men and porters there? A. Yes.

JAMES DEADMAN . I keep the Admiral Carter, in Bartholomew-close. I know both the prisoners—Coward frequented my house for about five weeks, from Dec. to Jan., and Newcombe was in the habit of coming for about three months—I cannot say whether he came before Dec. or not—I have seen the
prisoners together two or three times a week at my house—they might have dined there, but never dined with me.

Cross-examincd by MR. DOANE. Q. I suppose you have seen many other people at your house? A. I may have seen twenty more—Newcombe went by the name of Roberta, I think—there is a block for porters to pitch their loads at the door.

SAMUEL SPARROW WLLIS . I bought these two pieces of waistcoating of Newcombe, on the 6th of Oct., at 3s. 9d. a yard, and another piece of which this small piece is a pattern—there were 10 1/2 yards in each of those pieces that are entire, and 10 3/4 yards in the other piece—I sold the piece that, this is the patten of for 50s., not quite 5s. a yard.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. What day do you venture to say you purchased these? A. On the 6th of Oct—I recollect the day by this-entry, "6th 0ct, Newcombe, 24l. 11s. 6d."—this includes other things as well as these—my attention was called to this in Feb. last, after I had been to Bow-street—I will swear these goods were not bought in Aug, last—when I was examined before, I spoke from memory—I was in the country in Sept., and these goods were not purchased till I returned—I have an entry in my day book that I sold this piece for 2l. 10s.

Cross-examined by MR. WYLDE. Q. you do not mean that there is anything particular about the goods themselves? A. No—I swear I had them in my possession, and that 1 bought them of Newcombe—I have never expressed a doubt as to who I bought them of—I did speak with hesitation, but I cor
rected myself afterward, and recollected it perfectly well directly after.
SAMUEL RUST . My wife bought a piece of waistcoating at Mr. Wallis's, at 5s. a yard, and I paid for it.
NICHOLAS PEARCE . I am inspector of police. I went on the 7th of Feb. to Mr. Wallis, and found these pieces.
JONATHAN WHITCHER (police-constable A 27.) I took Coward on the 7th of Feb.—I asked if he knew a man named Newcombe—he said he did not.

(Henry Cockrell, an upholsterer; Benjamin Turner, parish-clerk of St. Se
putchre's; Richard Hutchinson, a grocer; and Benjamin Dowling, a meat-salesman in Newgate-market; gave Coward a good character.)

COWARD—
GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Transported for Seven Years.

NEWCOMBE—
GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(There was another indictment against Newcombe.)

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1048.
EDWARD HOLLAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Feb., 1 pair of clogs, value 9d., the goods of
Sarah Williams.

ARCHIBALD JENKIN WILLIAMS . I live with my mother, Sarah Williams, in Leather-lane, Holborn, she sells clogs. At half-past nine, o'clock, on the 17th of Feb., a young woman came in and told me something—I ran out and saw the prisoner running away with these clogs under his arm—I called, "Stop thief"—I saw him drop them when he had got ten or twelve doors off—they are my mother's—he was taken directly, at the corner of Bleeding Heart-yard.
HENRY MORGAN . I heard a cry, and saw the prisoner run out of the shop with the clogs in his hand.

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months.

1049.
CHARLES PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 25lbs. weight of cheese, value 1l., the goods of
William Knight.

WILLIAM JOHN KNIGHT . I am in the service of my father, William Knight, who lives in the Strand—I saw this cheese at the door on the 24th of Feb., a little before half-past six o'clock—I then missed it, and ran out—Isaw the prisoner running with it under his arm—I pursued—he turned up a street and dropped it at the corner—he ran a few yards, and I caught him, and gave him to the officer.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. It was in the evening? A. Yes—the place is rather crowded occasionally—I am quite certain as to the pri
soner's person—I never was further than three yards from him all the time.

RICHARD LATTER (police-constable F 51.) About half-past six o'clock that evening I was in Southampton-street—I saw the prisoner running towards me—Mr. Knight caught him—I took him, and have the cheese.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you acquainted with the Hammersmith Pett? A. Yes—I saw him at the Police-office, and he gave evidence against the prisoner—I heard him take his oath as to somethings he saw—he said the prisoner did not prig it—after some time the Magistrate struck out his evi
dence—I heard that he afterwards made a different statement—t did not make any inquiries into the Pet's character—it did not want inquiries—I knew him—I heard him tell a story about the prisoner carrying the cheese away.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined Three Months.

1050.
CHARLES MURRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Feb., 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns; 5 shillings; 2 sixpences; and 1 5l. Bank-note; the property of
Patrick Hanton, from his person.

PATRICK HANTON . I am baker on board the Solway steam-vessel, board to the West Indies—she was lying in a place called Pilcher's Dock, opposite Black wall-stairs. On the 15th of Feb. I was in High-street, Poplar—I was intoxicated, and was taken to the prisoner's house, I think about nine or ten at night—when I was sober I had a 5l. note, two sovereigns, and some silver—the note and sovereigns were in my pocket-book—I did not sleep above ten minutes or a quarter of an hour in his house, for I was taken to the station, and locked up for being drunk—I did not miss my money till the morning—the policeman went to some house, and got the remainder of the money—it is not likely I should have given it to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You were drinking with a man of the name of Boatswain? A. Yes—that was before I went to the prisoner—I was a good while with him; he took me to the prisoner to put me to bed there.

ELIZA MASTERS . I live in Red Lion-court, Poplar—I was sitting by the fire with the prisoner on the night of the 15th of Feb.—Boatswain brought the prosecutor, and asked me to give him a bed; I said I would if he would pay me—Boatswain said he was going to sail the next day, and it would be all right—I told him to take the candle and go into the adjoining room; they went, and I saw him no more—next morning Boatswain brought me a 5l. note—Boatswain got it changed at the Commercial public-house tap, and he gave me the change to take care of.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not Boatswain say he was a shipmate of the young man, and he would make it all right? A. Yes.
THOMAS WATKINS (police-constable K 310.) I told the prisoner I wanted him on a charge of stealing a 5l. note and two sovereigns—he said "Boat-swain did it, and gave me the money."
NOT GUILTY .

1051.
MARY ANN LEMON and
JANE LEMON were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 5th of Feb., 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 piece of muslin, 6d.; and 1 quart of beer, 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Bruce.

JOSEPH BRUCE . I live at Ealing. On Sunday, the 5th of Feb., I went to London with my wife and one of my daughters—Mary Ann Lemon was in my service—I left her in my house, with my daughter Elizabeth and my sons William and Joseph—my instructions to the prisoner and to my son were, that my daughter should go to the Sunday-school, and William should go to chapel, but Joseph, the youngest, should not go out—I had received information before I went out, and had given some directions to the officer—this bottle is not mine; I have examined the beer which is in it, but not tasted it—I do not know whether it is mine or not.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you keep beer in your house? A. Yes; table ale.

JOHN PASCOE (police-sergeant T 19.) About ten o'clock at night on Sunday, the 5th of Feb., I went to take Mary Ann Lemon into custody—I said she was charged with being concerned with Jane Lemon in stealing some things from Mr. Bruce—she said, "If Mr. Bruce had behaved to me in the manner he ought, I would have confessed; but now, if you take me before twenty magistrates, I will not say one word"—she also stated, that she had bought three half-pints of beer, and had given it to Jane Lemon to assist her—I asked her where she bought it; she said that was best known to herself—I measured the beer; there is a quart of it—my wife found this muslin hand
kerchief, which Mrs. Brace identified, on Jane Lemon.

ALICE PASCOE . I am the wife of John Pascoe—about half-past twelve o'clock on Sunday, the 5th of Feb., I searched Jane Lemon—I found this muslin handkerchief in her pocket—Mary Ann Lemon, who was present, said, "That is mine; I gave it to Jane to hem for me; I have another at home that I am wearing every day."

MARY BRUCE . I am the prosecutor's wife. This piece of muslin is mine—it is now in the state ia which it was when I lost it—it had been originally a dress for one of my daughters, and was afterwards cut up for the purpose of making a neckerchief, which it now is—I had kept it, to the best of my belief, in the top drawer of my double chest in my own bed-room—that drawer had never been kept locked; but when I got home on that Sunday, I found some of the locks in another chest of drawers had been opened, and some of the mahogany had been broken away with a knife—I had not seen this muslin for some time, as it was put up with articles that were not immediately in use—it was in the state it now when it was put away.
NOT GUILTY .

1052.
GEORGE LEMON was indicted, and
MARY ANN LEMON and
JANE LEMON were again indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of Jan., 2 cur
tains, value 8d.; 5 yards of carpet, 1s. 6d.; 1 shirt, 3d.; and 1 sheet, 1s.; the goods of
Joseph Bruce.
MR. CIARKSON offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1053.
JOHN CLARK was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 ham, value 11s., the goods of
Joseph Wing Arnold.
JOSEPH WING ARNOLD . I live in Long-acre, and deal in hams. A little before six o'clock on the 27th of Feb. I saw a ham safe in my window—I missed it soon after—I have not found it.

GEORGE TINKIN . I was standing opposite the prosecutor's shop, and I saw a woman go to the end of the shop—the prisoner came and joined her—they then went into the shop—the prisoner took the ham and came out—they came past me, and the prisoner gave the ham to another man—I ran and took the prisoner, but the other man got off with it—I went and told the prosecutor.

Prisoner. He says he never lost sight of me, and yet he went into the shop. Witness. They walked very deliberately along till they saw me, and then he gave the ham to the other man—the prisoner popped into Broad-court, and ran into the pawnbroker's, and I after him—he did not say what he wanted; the pawnbroker asked him, and he said, "I want a fustian jacket."
Prisoner's Defence. I went into the pawnbroker's to buy a jacket; the witness came in and accused me of the ham; I said, "You must be mistaken, I have not been so far as the shop."

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1054.
ELIZABETH BETSY MINTER was indicted
for stealing on the 25th of Feb., 5 pieces of foreign silver, value 2s. 8d.; 2 buckles, 6d.; 2 clasps, 6d.; and 1 printed book, 6d.; the goods of
Charles Cooling Herndon, her master.

HARRIET HERNDON . I am the wife of Charles Cooling Herndon—we live at Elizabeth-terrace, Islington—the prisoner was in my service—she had notice to quit, and was to leave us on the 25th of Feb.—I desired to look in her boxes—the one that was in the kitchen she had no objection to my seeing, but the one up stairs she said I had no business to see, but I did see it, and in it I found my hymn-book; and in her red box I found these silver coins, buckles, and these other things—she begged my pardon, and hoped I would forgive her.
Prisoner. Some of the coins are mine—my mistress gave me leave to go to her cupboard, and said I might read her books—my master turned me out. Witness. No, she went out, he did not turn her out.

WILLIAM EVERETT (police-constable N 377.) I heard the prisoner say that she would go, and her mistress said she should not—the prisoner then asked me what she was to do—the boxes had not been searched then—I did not bear her master say any thing.

CHARLES COOLING HERNDON . These things are all mine, I did not give them to the prisoner—I have saved these coins for, some time, except two par
ticular Bombay coins, which I have not had long.
Prisoner. I have not stolen the things—my boxes were not locked, and I gave my mistress leave to look into them.
HARRIET HERNDON . They were both locked.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1055.
SARAH HOLDEN was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of Jan., 1 watch, value 15s.; 1 watch-chain, 6d.; and 1 seal, 1s.; the goods of
Joshua Stringer, from his person: and
HENRY CANNON
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOSHUA STRINGER . Iam a sailor. On the 21st of Jan. I was in Rat
cliffe-highway—Holden was dodging me, and wanted me to go home with her—I stopped, and took my watch and chain and seal out of my fob, and put it into my great-coat pocket—I then had occasion to stop, and while I was stopping, Holden put her hand into my coat pocket, where I had just put my watch—she took it and ran away—these are my watch chain and seal—I gave her in charge.
Holden. I was in bed when the officer took me.

COURT. A. Are you sure she is the woman that came to you? A. Yes, and I saw her running away as hard as she could go—my watch had been in my pocket about five minutes—I did not feet any thing at my pocket when I stopped, but she was close behind me—I was sober.
Holden. Q. Do not you-know Gravesend Hannah, that was with you that night? A. No, there was no one with me.

GEORGE ARNOLD . I am a pawnbroker. This watch was pawned on the 24th of Jan., to the best of my belief, by Cannon—he said it was his own property, and he had had more than I lent him upon it in the neighbourhood of the Commercial-road.

JAMES MAYNARD (police-coastable K 99.) On the 17th of Feb. I appre
hended Holden at a house in Bluegate-fields—I said, "Holden, I want you, for stealing a watch from a man three weeks ago"—she said, "Me? I know nothing about a watch; the prosecutor left it with another girl, for 3s."—on the 4th of Feb. Holden had given Cannon into my custody for an assault, and on the road he said to Holden, "If you go against me I will transport you, for sailing the one-legged man of his watch. I don't mind, fifteen years myself, so long as you get fifteen"—(she is a prostitute, and lives with Cannon in a brothel)—Cannon then put his hand into his pocket, and said, "Here is the ticket, policeman"—this is the duplicate.

GEORGE ARNOLD
re-examined. This is the-duplicate of the watch.
Cannon's Defence. My mother keeps a brothel; the prosecutor slept in her house with a young woman; he gave me the watch for 5s., instead of giving it to my mother, and I put it to my own use.

HOLDEN**—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

CANNON†—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1056.
JAMES M'KENZIE was indicted
for stealing on the 23rd of Feb., 5 3/4lbs. weight of pork, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
John Joseph Mason.

CHARLES CHRISTMAS MASON . I am the son of John Joseph Mason, a cheesemonger, in Chiswell-street—on the 23rd of Feb. I saw the prisoner going out—I stopped him, and found this pork on him—It was my father's, and I had seen it safe a quarter of an hour before—I had not sold it to the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. A man came and said, "Will you carry this pork? "—I said I could not, as I was going up Bunhill-row, but I would carry it as I came back—I came back and he gave it me.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Eleven Days and
Whipped.

1057.
MATILDA FRANKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 9s.; 1 coat, 8s.; 1 waitscoat, 1s. 6d.; and 1 cork-screw, value 6d.; the goods of
John Parman.

JOHN PARMAM . I am a coachman out of place—I lodge in Shepherd's-court, Hanover-square—I missed the articles stated from my room on the 27th of February—I saw them safe at nine o'clock that morning—these are them.

JOHN STANLEY (police-constable D 48.) I received information from a little boy, and found the prisoner about seven that evening in the Cock and Lion public-house—I found on her this coat, waistcoat, cork-screw, and two old brushes—she appeared to have been drinking.

ANN COLE . I keep the house where the prosecutor lives—about four or five o'clock I saw the prisoner come down into my passage—I asked who she wanted—she said, her brother—I said, "Who is your brother?"—she said, "That is my business"—I said, "How did you come here?"—"That is my business," said she—she had a bundle, and went out.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought these old things for 2s. to make up into boy's caps and sell them; I do not know where they came from; I had never been in that house; I was lost to what I was doing.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1058.
ELIZABETH ELWOOD and
CATHERINE KELLY were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 28th of Feb., 13 yards of printed cotton, value 10s., the goods of
Jesse Jones.

THOMAS MURRELL . I am shopman to Jesse Jones, a linen-draper, in High-street, Islington. About one o'clock on the 28th of Feb. the prisoner Elwood was brought into our shop with this piece of printed cotton, contain
ing thirteen yards—I had seen it safe about five minutes before in the lobby of the shop, between the two windows—it is my employer's—I had seen the prisoners standing about the door for nearly ten minutes.

THOMAS GIBBS . I am a linendraper. I saw the prisoners and two other persons at the prosecutor's shop door—I watched, and saw a third person take this print, and give it to Kelly, and she gave it to Elwood—I ran across the road, and seized Elwood with the print—she dropped it from under her arm—I had been watching them for nearly an hour—they bad gone to different shops—I followed them from my own door in the City-road, I should think nearly a mile to the prosecutor's.

ELWOOD*—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

KELLY*—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

1059.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the lst of March, 100 cigars, value 10s., the goods of
Robert George Cattell.

MARY ANN CATTELL . I am the wife of Robert George Cattell, tobacco
nist, Goswell-street. On the 1st of March I missed a bundle of about 100 cigars from a board in the shop window—I had seen them safe about an hour and a half before—the prisoner was brought into my shop—I had seen him in my shop on the Monday before—the cigars have not been found.

RICHARD POOL . I live in Whitecross-street. Between one and two o'clock on the 1st of March, I saw the prisoner come out of Mr. Cattell's shop with a bundle of cigars in his hand—he threw them into another boy's apron and they ran away—I am quite sure the prisoner is the boy who came out with the cigars in his hand—I ran to my master's door, and then I ran after the prisoner—I called, "Stop thief"—he turned round, swore at me, and asked what I wanted—I stuck to him—he tried to get away, and struck me—I fell down, and a gentleman took him.

Prisoner. He came hallooing out "Stop thief"—I turned and said "What do you want?"—he said, "I will tell you what I want," and then he struck me, and I hit him again. Witness. I did not hit him, he hit me.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

1060.
ELIZABETH AYRES was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Searles.

HENRY SIMMONS . I am foreman to Thomas Searles, a shoemaker, in Whitechapel. On the 20th of Feb. the prisoner came to purchase a pair of boots—after trying on several pairs, she got up, and said she would call the next day, as we had none to suit her—after she was gone I missed a pair of boots—I ran after her as far as Whitechapel church, and she had these boots on her left arm under her shawl—she dropped them in the mud, and said they must have been entangled with her umbrella—she had two umbrellas in her hand, but I could swear the boots were under her arm—she has borne a good character before.
JOHN BURT (police-constable H 81.) These boots were delivered to me—
the prisoner had this shawl and her handkerchief under her arm, these two umbrellas in her hand, and 3s. 3 1/4 d. in her purse.
Prisoner. I implore your forgiveness; it is the first time; I promise it shall be the last.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 43.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Confined One Month.

1061.
WILLIAM HURRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Feb., 1 coat, value 30s.; and 1 handkerchief, 2s.; the goods of
John William Car
rington.

JOHN WILLIAM CARRINGTON . I am a dentist, and live in High-street, St. Giles's. On the 21st of Feb. the prisoner and two other men came into my shop—one of the other men requested to have a tooth extracted—I examined his mouth, and saw no tooth that wanted extracting; but he fixed on one in the lower jaw, and said he would have it out—I said it was quite sound, but he insisted on having it out—I desired him to walk into the sur
gery—they all three walked into the surgery—I then set the man in a chair to take his tooth out, and on the back of another chair was my coat—I pro
ceeded to extract the tooth, but the man slipped out of the chair, and pre
vented me—I made another attempt, and he served me the same again—I then made a third attempt, and succeeded—I got the tooth out, but I am sure he did not expect it—while I was doing so the prisoner left the surgery, and in a few minutes the other man left, and left me with the man whose tooth I had taken out—he then washed his mouth—he asked what it was; I said one shilling—he said he could afford no more than sixpence, and I took it—I went back to the surgery to put away the things, and missed the coat.

ANN KEALL . I am the wife of John Keall; we live in Charles-street, City-road. I saw the prisoner and two others go into the prosecutor's shop—I can swear the prisoner is one—I saw him come out with a coat on his right arm.

GUILTY . * Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1062.
RICHARD PECK was indicted
for obtaining a loaf of bread by false pretences.

JOHN BRANCH . I am a baker, and live in St. James's-street, Islington. I do business with Mr. Ramsay. On the 3rd of Feb. the prisoner came and asked for a quartern loaf for Mr. Ramsay—my wife asked which Mr. Ramsay—he pointed to the house of Mr. Ramsay, which is at the corner, and said, "That"—I let him have the loaf on the faith of his coming from Mr. Ram
say—I watched him as far as the corner to see that it was correct, and as he turned, the corner I judged it was—he was soon after brought back by the officer.

JOHN RAMSAY . My house is near Mr. Branch's shop—I did not autho
rize the prisoner to fetch a loaf for me on the 3rd of Feb.

THOMAS WITHERS (police-constable N 211.) I had seen the prisoner loitering about—I stopped him with the loaf—I asked where he got it—he said he bought it for 7d.—I took him to the prosecutor's shop—he then said a boy sent him for it.

Prisoner. I was passing by, and a young man at Mr. Ramsay's asked me to go for a quartern loaf for Mr. Ramsay; I could not see the man again; I was going towards Mr. Ramsay's house with it. Witness. He had passed the house nearly ten yards.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1063.
SOLOMON MARKS was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences.

WILLIAM HENRY MORGAN . I am warehouseman to Benjamin Wilmott Gabriel, of Watling-street. On the 21st of Jan. the prisoner called there—he said, "How is Mr. Gabriel?"—I said, "Pretty well"—He then said, "I want two dozen pairs of stockings for Mr. Moses Nathan"—I gave them to him—I should not hare given them to him if he had not said he came for them for Mr. Moses Nathan—I gave him a receipt, which he signed—I have it here.

MOSES NATHAN . I am a tailor, and live in Ratcliffe-highway. The pri
soner was in my service about ten months ago, but not in Jan.—I did not send him on the 21st of Jan. to Mr. Gabriel's for any stockings—I did not authorize him to take any from there, or to get any either then or at any other time.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS . I am a hatter, and live in Shadwell. Between eight and nine o'clock on the 3rd of Feb. the prisoner came to my shop—he said he came for a hat or two for Mr. Lee, naming the size, and saying it was for the mate of a ship—in consequence of his stating he came from Mr. Lee, I gave him two hats—Lee was a customer of mine, and believing the prisoner came from him, I gave him the hats, which I would not have done otherwise.

JOHN LEE . I am a tailor and outfitter, and live in High-street, Shadwell. I did not send the prisoner on the 3rd of Feb. to Mr. Saunders for hats—he was not in my service at that time, nor did I receive any.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1064.
JOHN BAILEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 copper, value 1l., the goods of
Stephen Goundry, and fixed to a building; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH MADON . I am the wife of Thomas Madon. I resided in a house of Mr. Stephen Goundry's at Hillingdon—I left it on the 20th of Feb., the copper was then safe, and fixed in the house—this is it—I am quite sure it is Mr. Stephen Groundry's.

JAMES DARVILL . On Monday evening, the 27th of Feb., I was going to my house on Uxbridge-moor, which is about 100 yards from Mr. Goundry's house, where Mrs. Madon had lived—I met the prisoner and another man—they were both carrying the copper—as I came round the corner of a wall they dropped the copper and ran away—I am sure the prisoner was one of them—this is the copper they were carrying.

JOHN ROLLE . I am a labourer. On the evening of the 27th I was going home from my work—I met the prisoner and the other man on Uxbridge-moor—they had the copper with them—I said to the prisoner, "Halloo, my lad, where are you going?"—I am sure the prisoner was the man, and there was another with him—they dropped the copper.
Prisoner. Q. Had not Mr. Darvill got the copper when you came up? A. No, you dropped it.
Prisoner. He said Mr. Darvill had it when he came up; I am innocent of it
RICHARD ROADNIGHT (police-sergeant T 11.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office (read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1065.
JOSEPH HARDEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Feb., 1 tea-caddy, value 4s., the goods of
Guisue Vago.

GUISUE VAGO . I live in Oxford-street, and deal in looking-glasses, cabi
net-work,

and tea caddies. I was standing in the middle of my shop on the 25th of February—I saw the prisoner go by—he put his hand in, took a tea-caddy, and ran away—I ran after him—somebody else stopped him with this caddy—it is mine.
JAMES ROSS . I am a tailor. I was in Oxford-street about six o'clock that evening—I saw the prisoner take the caddy—he ran off—I ran and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1066.
ISAAC DAVIES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 spade, value 4s., the goods of
James Baldwin.

ALFRED BROWN . I am a gardener to Mr. James Baldwin, and live near Chiswick. On the 27th of Feb. I left my spade in my work, about thirty yards from the hedge—when I came from breakfast it was gone—this is it.
HEDRY HEMPSTEAD . On the 27th of Feb., between eleven and one o'clock, the prisoner pawned this spade with me for 1s. 6d.—I am sure he is the person.
GEORGE LOWE . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner—he said it was not him that got through the hedge for it, but he was with the man that did—he it first denied all knowledge of it.
Prisoner's Defence. It was given to me to pledge; I did not know it was stolen.

GUILTY . * Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.

1067.
THOMAS TINSWORTH and
JOHN BLUNT were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of Feb., 1 ewe, price 1l. 6s., the property of
Ed
ward Cavell.—2nd COUNT, for killing the same, with intent to steal the carcase.

WILLIAM TYE . I am a cattle salesman. On the 6th of Feb. I received fifteen ewes from Edward Cavell, of Boardsay, in Suffolk, for the purpose of being sent to the London market—they were marked over the loins with red ochre—on the following Tuesday, the 9th, I sent them to London by my drover, Samuel Ringe—I have since seen the skin of a sheep produced by the policeman—it corresponded in every respect with the marks of the sheep I saw.

SAMUEL RINGE . I am a drover. On the 9th of Feb. I received fifteen ewes from Tye—they belonged to Mr. Cavell, of Boardsay—I was to drive them to Smithfield-market—I drove them as far as Chadwell, twelve miles from London, and three miles this side of Romford—I folded the sheep there—the number was right when I left them—between two and three o'clock on the following morning, Sunday, when I went to turn them out, I missed one—about a week afterwards I saw the skin of a ewe in the possession of Craw
ford, the policeman—I knew it—it was the skin of the sheep I had lost.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What time was it you folded the sheep? A. About eight o'clock.

SAMUEL TEBENHAM . I am a police-sergeant, stationed at Dagenham, in Essex. In consequence of information, I went to Chadwell-heath on Sunday evening, the 12th of Feb. to the house of Mr. Bacon—the prisoner Tinsworth lodges there—I saw him sitting by the fire—I asked him where he was the pre
vious

night—he refused to tell me—I asked him if he was at his lodgings—he said no—I told him I apprehended him on a charge of stealing a sheep the pre
vious night—I searched his lodging, found a pair of smallclothes and a shirt, which I produce—there are marks of blood on it, red marks, on the back of the neck, and spots of blood in different places—I asked him to account for the blood—he said his nose had bled the day previous, and that was where he wiped it—I asked him if these were the breeches he had on the night previous—he said they were—they are cotton corded breeches—they would make a mark on the soil of the field—I have compared the knee of these breeches with some marks I saw in the field at Chadwell—they correspond exactly—there are marks of blood on the knee where he had been kneeling down—I gave him into custody of Crawford, the policeman—on Monday morning I saw some boots produced by Crawford—I compared them with some marks in the field leading towards where the sheep appeared to have been killed, in seve
ral places—they were quite distinct—it was the pair that was taken from Tinsworth that corresponded—I was not present when they were taken—this is the boot that I compared the following morning—it corresponds minutely, and I have the clay impression of the foot-mark—I compared some pieces of mutton, produced by Crawford, with the skin found in the field, and it corresponded in several parts—I have been a butcher—the meat was in such a state of decomposition we could not preserve it—I was able to match it—part of the shoulder-piece of the skin was left on, and the part left on the skin exactly corresponded with it—the sheep was very badly cut up—this is the clay impression—it is not a mark that I made myself—this is the actual mark taken from the field—a portion of the tip of the heel corresponds, and some high nails—it was far more plain when first taken than now—I did not make any impression by the side of it—I afterwards apprehended Blunt at Chadwell-beath, on Monday evening, at his house—I told him I came, from information, for the purpose of apprehending him, charged with being concerned in stealing a sheep the Saturday night previous—he said he was willing to go with me, he knew nothing about it—I inquired if he had a smock-frock which he had worn on the Saturday—on the following morning I got a smock-frock from some woman in the house—I went to his house to ask for it—it came from a bed-room—they had but one room—he was not present when it was produced—it came out of his bed-room—there are marks of blood in three places on it—the boots taken from his feet did not agree with the foot-marks in the field.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you received your information first from Wil
liam Bennett? A. Yes—I did not apprehend one Little—he was in custody, and he was before the Magistrate—I believe it was on the information of Bennett—Little was discharged, and Blunt detained—that was through some misunderstanding of the witness Bennett—I believe Blunt was the last ap
prehended—I believe the female who gave me the sack was the nurse who was attending Blunt's wife—I understood at the time that his wife had been very recently delivered—I asked at his lodging for the clothes he wore on the Saturday night—I am quite satisfied that I used the expression, "wore"—the woman brought me a smock from the bed where the female was—I was near enough to observe that—this was after he was taken—I believe Blunt was in the employ of Mr. Flower, of Bow—his house is between half and three quarters of a mile from the place where the sheep was missed.

WILLIAM BENNETT . I am ostler at the White House, at Chadwell-heath. On Sunday, the 12th of Feb., about seven o'clock in the morning, I was in the yard of that public-house, and saw William Little and the two prisoners—Blunt looks after the horses there for Mr. Flower—I saw Little come from

the stable, and go towards his own house—Tinsworth came from the stable, fetched a pail of water from the pump, and took it into the stable to Blunt, who was looking after his horses—about ten the same morning I saw Blunt come from the stable with something in a sack, and take it across the yard—I did not see where he put it—there was a cart of turnips standing there, be
longing to Mr. Bonnett—about one o'clock I went to that cart—I saw part of a sack in the cart—I opened it, looked in, and there was some meat in it—I then went and told Mr. Bonnett—there is more than one stable in the yard—Blunt came from a large brick stable—the same into which Little had taken the pail.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it not the same stable in which his master's horses were? A. Yes—I was before the Magistrate—while I was there Little and two other persons were there—I do not know whether Little was charged—he was taken up on what I told Mr. Bennett—I did not tell the police anything about Little—I did not see him with the sack—I saw him at the stable—it was not through what I said that he was taken—I did not at first say that it was Little that was carrying the sack—I am quite certain of that—I told Mr. Bennett Little was in the stable, but I did not say that he carried the sack.

MARY ANN BACON . I am the wife of John Bacon, of Chadwell—the prisoner Tinsworth lodged in our house. On Saturday night, the 12th, he was not at home at all—he came home on Sunday morning a few minutes before ten o'clock—he had on a pair of corded smallclothes and asmock-frock—the same things that the policeman has produced.

WILLIAM BONNETT . I am a carter at Chadwell-heath. On Saturday night, the 11th of Feb., I placed a cart full of turnips in the shed of the White Horse—Bennett afterwards told me of a sack that was in it—I did not go to the cart then—I went and gave information to the police—the sack did not belong to me—I know nothing about it.

JAMES CRAWFORD (police-sergeant K 253.) I am stationed at Chadwell, near Barking. On Monday morning, the 12th of Feb., I received information—I went to a place called Cat's-lane, and found this sheep-skin with the head attached—I examined it—I showed it to the drover—he said it was the skin of the sheep he had lost—I carried it to Mr. Webb'a stable—I then went to a field belonging to Mr. Webb—I had seen some sheep driven into that field the night before by Ringe the drover—I discovered footmarks of three per
sons leading over three or four fields to where I found a sheep had been slaughtered, in a field adjoining Cat's-lane—I compared the marks in the field with some boots which I got from the prisoner Tintworth's feet, and they corresponded—I also saw a mark of a knee, where a person had been kneel
ing, between where the sheep was taken from, and where it was slaughtered—I was with Tebenham when he compared these marks with a pair of breeches found at Tinsworth's lodgings, and they corresponded—I have kept the boots, and produce them to-day—the left boot was the one I examined most particularly—here are peculiar nails which made the impression in the earth, three nails in the heel, and the tip projects out a little—it correspond
ed in every respect with the mark in the field—I afterwards traced the same footmarks from the place where the sheep had been slaughtered towards the back of the White Horse-yard—I afterwards received information from Bon
nett, and found the sack and meat in his cart—I apprehended Little, and he was discharged—I found a knife on Tinsworth, with blood on the handle where the blade shuts—it had been apparently fresh cleaned when I found it—the blood was inside where the blade closes.
Tinsworth's Defence. My landlord bought two sheeps' heads on Thursday
evening, one for me, and the other for himself; the knife found was what I cut the head up with on Friday; likewise the liver, and I wiped my hands on my smallclothes.

TINSWORTH—
GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Twelve Months. BLUNT—
NOT GUILTY .

1068.
JAMES SULLIVAN was indicted
for a rape.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 36.—
Confined Two Years.

1069.
THOMAS SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Feb., 1 pair of boots, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas George Sizer; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

1070.
FRANCIS DESMOND was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Feb., 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 handkerchief, 1s.; and 1 pair of gloves, 6d.; the goods of
John Johnson.

JOHN JOHNSON . I am a plumber, and live at Stratford. On the 12th of Feb. I went to the Harrow public-house—I pulled off my coat, which had a handkerchief and a pair of gloves in it—when I went for it it was gone—this is my handkerchief.
Prisoner. Q. See if there is a hole in the middle of the handkerchief? A. Yes—I swear to it from a small hole in it.

WILLIAM HOPKINS . I am a bricklayer, and live at Stratford. I was at the Harrow—I saw the prisoner come in, and sit down in the chair which had the coat on it—when he got up he took the coat from the chair, and took it out.
CHARLES REED . I saw the prisoner go out with the coat.
THOMAS PRENTICE . I am a pawnbroker. This handkerchief was pawned by the prisoner, on the 13th of Feb., with another.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1071.
JOSEPH WEBB was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Jan., 1 10l. Bank-note, the property of
Henry Willis, his master.

SARAH WILLIS . I am the wife of Henry Willis—we live at Chadwell-heath, Barking, in Essex—I cannot read. On the 15th of Jan. I called the prisoner, and asked him whether he would go to Mr. Philpott's for me—he said, "Yes"—I asked if he would tell me what that note was, showing him a Bank-note—he said it was a 5l. note—I then showed him another note, and asked what that was—he said a 10l. note—I then gave him the note which he said was a 5l. note, and a sovereign; told him to go to Mr. Philpott's, and pay the rent—he went, came back, and brought me the receipt—last Tuesday I thought, by his buying some new clothes, he must have taken the 10l. note—I went into the next door, and asked the person to read the note which I had left—they said it was a 5l. note—I then went to Mr. Philpott's, and he said the prisoner had given him six sovereigns—the prisoner owned to Mr. Philpott that he had nine sovereigns and two half-sovereigns.

Cross-examined. Where was your husband at this time? A. He was in the room, but he could not tell me what note it was—the prisoner had been employed for us, off and on, for two years—I saw him the day after this, and nothing passed then—he brought the receipt back—the rent is paid.
THOMAS WEBB . I changed a 10l. note for Mr. Willis—the prisoner brought it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he say he wanted it changed for Mr. Willis? A. Yes—I have known him for years—I never heard anything against him.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

1072.
DANIEL BIGGS and
HENRY JOYCE were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of Feb., 1 log of wood, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Christopher Tyler.

CHRISTOPHER TYLER . I am a coal-merchant, and have a house at Ilford, in Essex. I had a pear-tree growing in my garden a year and a half ago—it was taken up by the roots, and carried to my yard—I did not miss it—I was told it was gone.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You had this in 1841? A. Yes, and it was taken into the yard to be put down as a pile, but it was left on my wharf, and never put down.

WILLIAM PARSONS (police-constable K 63.) On the night of the 16th of Feb. I was on duty near Ilford—I know Biggs—I saw him that evening, with another person, whom I did not know—they were carrying a piece of a tree—out, "Biggs, what are you at?"—they both ran away, and left the piece of the tree behind them—I got assistance, and took it to the station—I took Biggs at his father's house the same night—I am sure he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. He said he knew nothing about it, did he not? A. Yes—when I saw him with the tree he was about six feet from me—there was an iron pallisade, about six feet high, which prevented my laying hold of him—it was seven o'clock at night, but it was not dark—there were two gas-lights, about fifty yards apart, and he had to run past one of them—the fence was six feet below my feet—I was above it—I could not get over it—I was about sixteen yards from Biggs.

WILLIAM CURLE . I am a gardener, and live at Wanstead. I have worked for Mr. Tyler—I remember the pear-tree that was grubbed up—I should know the trunk of it well—this is it—(looking at it)—from my knowledge of the wood of that tree when it was growing, I can undertake to say that this is part of that tree—I know it by cutting the branches off myself, and the marks I made on it at the time, and here is the mark of a trellis fence that it laid against—I am sure it is a part of Mr. Tyler's pear-tree.

Cross-examined. Q. How long is it since you had to do with it? A. Twelve months last October—I have not seen it since—I have cut branches off a great many trees, but I can swear to this, because I made marks on it when I cut the branches off—I have possibly made marks on other trees, but not the same as these.

JOHN WIGGS . I am a brick-maker's labourer, and live near Ilford. I know both the prisoners well—I remember, on the 16th of Feb., being at a beer-shop, where the prisoners were—we were very joyous and singing there—Joyce, asked me if I would go with him after a piece of wood—I refused—my brother was outside the house—he did not come in—I left the house at the time the prisoner did—we went together just outside the door—we then parted, and the prisoners went away together, towards Ilford, and towards Mr. Tyler's—I bade them good night, and told them to mind they did not get cotched.

Cross-examined. Q. What were you singing? A. I cannot describe the song—some of the words of it were about going to Botany-bay—and when we got outside I told them to mind, and not get cotched—I left them as near seven o'clock as could be—I suspected there was something wrong—I did not go with them—my brother came, and I went home with him. GEORGE WIGGS. I was not in the pubic-house with my brother and the Prisoner, on the night of the 16th, but I saw them coming out—my brother
and I did not walk with them any further than the door—we left them—my brother said, "Good night; mind you don't get taken, if you go on that subject"—I did not know what the subject was.

Cross-examined. Q. You went to get your hair cut, did you not? A. Yes, and I called at the beer-shop, to see if my brother was there—I did not ask my brother to go with Joyce, to get a bit of wood—I am labourer to Mr. Curtis, a builder at Stratford—I have not worked for him the last four or five months—since then I have worked a good deal at shoemaking.
HENRY JAMES PITT (police-sergeant K 40) I apprehended Joyce on the 20th of Feb.—he said he knew nothing at all about it—I found him at his own lodging.
NOT GUILTY .

1073.
RICHARD MASHITER was indicted
for stealing 1 umbrella, value 4s., the goods of
William Nicholls.
JOHN TAYLER . I am a corporal in the Royal Marines. On the 13th of Feb. I saw an umbrella in the hands of the prisoner—I put him in the guard-room.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What time of day was this? A. About nine o'clock in the morning—he belongs to the same room as I do—I saw him bring the umbrella open into the room with him—it was a fine morning—I have not known him above a fortnight—I have not been long in the regiment myself—it was opened in the room to be looked at.

ELLEN NICHOLLS . I am the wife of William Nicholls—this umbrella re
sembles mine—I had sewn a button on mine, but any person might do that—I cannot swear to my work—I cannot point out any difference between the umbrella I lost and this one—it appears to have had a button sewed on since it was made—it looks like my work as far as I can see—it looks like mine, certainly—there is no mark on it whatever—it is sewn on with silk.

Cross-examined. Q. There is a great resemblance between this and yours, you are not able to swear to it? A. No, mine was very like this—it is the sewing on of this pearl button to which I refer, but it is a thing anybody might do.
COURT. Q. Have you always given the same account? A. Yes—I was before the Magistrate—I had rather not swear to it—I thought it was a thing any person might do—I expressed a doubt at the Police-court.
WILLIAM NICHOLLS . I think this umbrella is mine, I have no doubt of it, but I do not know it from anything but the use of it—I have had it about two years.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you reason to pay any particular attention to it? A. No—umbrellas are made by dozens in the same form—I speak to it from its general appearance—I lost it out of a return-cab, which I left at the railroad at New-cross.

THOMAS HAWKINSON . I am a cab-driver, at Woolwich. On the 18th of Feb. Mr. Nicholls hired my cab to New-cross—when I got there he left an um
brella in my charge—I returned to Woolwich, and on my way home, between Greenwich and Charlton, I overtook the prisoner—he got inside my cab and rode two miles and better to Charlton—when I got home I missed the um
brella—I had placed it in the bottom of the cab—I did not notice that the

prisoner had an umbrella when he got in—I afterwards inquired at the Ma
rine barracks for the umbrella.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean that Mr. Nicholls left it in your charge? A. Yes—I was to give it to my employer, Mr. Milton, at Woolwich, and he was to call for it—I missed it about a quarter to nine at Woolwich, better than a quarter of a mile from the barracks—I went to the barracks, and saw the prisoner and the umbrella, about an hour and a half afterwards—I did not tell him I had got an umbrella in the cab when he got in—I saw him get out, but I did not get off my box—he had paid me when he got in.
MR. NICHOLLS re-examined. The umbrella I delivered to the cab man was the one I was in the habit of using.
NOT GUILTY .

1074.
WILLIAM WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of June, at Plumstead, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 bag, 1d.; 16 half-crowns, 100 shillings, 60 sixpences, and 30 groats, the property of
Jonathan Brazefield, in his dwelling-house:—also on the 27th of June, 1 watch, 4l.; 1 seal, 7s.; 1 watch-key, 2s. 6d.; and 1 watch-ribbon, 1d.; the goods of
Jonathan Brazefield; to both which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

1075.
MARY KEMP was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Feb., 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., the goods of
Joseph Ward, and that she had been before convicted of felony.

SARAH WARD . I am the wife of Joseph Ward—he is waiter at a tavern—I keep a shop at Greenwich—I lost a pair of shoes from one of the shelves behind the counter—they were my husband's, but he has been confined, and not out for this month—the shoes were safe at eleven o'clock last Mon
