day when I went out, and when I returned, about a quarter past eleven o'clock, they were gone—these are them—I never saw the prisoner till about ten that morning, when she came to ask for a ready-furnished apartment at my house.

JOHN DELINE . I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pledged these shoes with me last Monday morning, before twelve—I am sure she is the person—she came afterwards to pledge another article and was detained.
BENJAMIN PRIOR (police-constable R 194.) I went to the pawnbroker's and took the prisoner about two o'clock last Monday—I told her it was for stealing a pair of shoes—she said she was sorry for it.
Prisoner's Defence. Two persons asked me to go and pawn these shoes, which I did—they gave me 6d. and the ticket.

SAMUEL EDWARD FREEMAN (police-sergeant R 3.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1076.
CATHERINE KELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Feb., 84 yards of mouseline-de-laine, value 3l. 16s. 6d., the goods of
Francis William Vant.

THOMAS DAVIES . I am apprenticed to Thomas William Vant of Wool-wich. In the afternoon of the 17th of Feb. a person bought a parcel of goods, and said they would call for them—they came again—I went to give them the parcel, which was on some sheeting, and as I turned, I

saw the prisoner take this mouseline-de-laine from the shop and go out—I pursued up a court—I went back, and called a person to mind the shop—I went the back way, and caught her at the top of the court with these pieces of mouseline-de-laine in her apron—they are my master's—the private mark is on them.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had you known her? A. She had been a customer for reels of cotton and small things—I said she had something that did not belong to her—she said she had not.
HENRY WEBB (police-constable R 277.) I took the prisoner about ten minutes after this occurrence—she was not drunk.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she not resist a great deal? A. Yes, at one time in going to the station, she tried to get her pocket off, and these handkerchiefs were in it.

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1077.
WILLIAM OXFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Feb., 5 pairs of boots, value 1l. 5s. 6d.; and 1 pair of clogs, value 6s. 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Bailey: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

1078.
WILLIAM ARTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Dec., 401bs. weight of horsehair, value 10s., the goods of
Jane Phillips Dalgety, his mistress; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

1079.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Feb., 1 loaf of bread, value 3d., the goods of
William Brown.

MARY BROWN . I am the wife of William Brown, a baker, in Greenwich-road. About twelve o'clock on the 15th of Feb. the prisoner opened the door, and came into the shop—he took a loaf from the window, walked of, and shut the door—I told him, as he was going, that he had not paid for it—he turned round, laughed, and went away—I sent the boy after him.
WILLIAM WITHERS . I am in the prosecutor's service. On the 15th of Feb. my mistress sent me after the prisoner—I caught him—he was eating the loaf.
STEPHEN BROOK (police-constable R 50.) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I was hungry, and took the loaf—I am a silk hatter by trade.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Eight Days.

1080.
JAMES SAUNDERS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering Conn
terfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Six Months.

1081.
HENRY JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 1 printed book, value 1s., the goods of
Jonathan Blagden; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1082.
THOMAS LOVETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Feb., 1 sieve, value 1s.; the goods of
Aaron Munday.
AARON MUNDAY . I am a gardener. I was working on the banks of the canal at Deptford, getting ice, on the 17th of Feb.—I left my sieve on the
bank while I was absent for about three quarters of an hour, going with a load of ice—when I returned I missed my sieve—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was it on the bank where people walk? A. Yes.

GEORGE BOTLEY . The prisoner came to a cellar, where I was at work—he asked if my brother was at home, and said he wanted to sell him this sieve—he wanted sixpence for it—my brother was not at home—I bought it of him.
JOHN FOX . I was on the bank of the Surrey canal, near Deptford—I saw the prisoner coming along with the sieve—I asked where he got it—he said he picked it up.
NOT GUILTY .

1083.
WILLIAM BAKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Feb., 1 key, value 6d.; 1 sovereign; and 1 half-crown; the property of
Frederick Beauclerk, from his person.

FEEDERICK BEAUCLERK . I live on my own property on Blackheath-hill. I was at the Swan public-house on the 7th of Feb.—I waa sober—I do not exactly know who I met at the public-house—I saw the prisoner there—I did not drink with him—I did not tell the Magistrate that I got drunk with the prisoner—I deny that charge altogether.

Q. Well, read this deposition—is this your handwriting? A. Certainly; and seemingly I have sworn to this statement—(reads)—"On the forenoon of yesterday, instant, I got drunk with the prisoner"—that is certainly not true—I deny that—it is no such thing—I drank with him certainly—I had seven sovereigns, a key, and, I think, some silver in my pocket, but I cannot say how much—I lost my money and key in that public-house—I did not get drunk there—the prisoner put his hand in my waistcoat-pocket, and drew some gold out—the policeman was called instantly, and he was given in charge—I am sure this is my key—(looking at it.)

JAMES FIGG . I keep the Swan at Greenwich—I remember the prosecutor being there on the 7th of Feb.—I gave the prosecutor change for a sovereign—the prisoner was then sitting on the left-hand side of the prosecutor—I did not see him do anything—there was a policeman in the house, and I called his attention to what was going on, as I thought the prisoner was sitting closer to the prosecutor than he ought—I then went into the tap-room—I cannot say that the prosecutor was sober—he was the worse for liquor.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were they drinking and tossing? A. They were drinking—I understood that they were tossing, but I did not see it—I do not allow it—I know the prosecutor.

ROBERT ALEXANDER COOK CLARK . I was at the Swan, and saw the pri
soner sitting on the left side of the prosecutor, and two other men on his right—one of the others took two half-crowns and tossed with the prosecutor; then one of them said Mr. Beauclerk had lost a gallon of ale, and would not pay it—the prisoner said, "I will soon make him pay"—he put his hand in his pocket, and pulled out a key, some sovereigns, and some silver—he put one sovereign into his pocket, I am sure of that—I went out and fetched the policeman—I did not take notice what became of the key, because I went out directly to give information.

Cross-examined. Q. Then you did not see him count out some silver on the table? A. I saw some chucked out on the table—I am a marine-store dealer, and carry on business at Bexley-heath—I saw this done openly—I did not see the key on the table—I saw it in the prisoner's hand.
WILLIAM BOLTON (police-constable R 166.) I was called in to search the
prisoner—I found on him a sovereign and a half-crown—Mr. Beauclerk was very drunk, and, not knowing where he lived, I detained him at the station.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know from the public-house where he lived? A. No—I did not inquire there—I found this key and some silver on the table.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

1084.
HENRY KNIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 1 coat, value 2l. 10s.; and 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; the goods of
Robert Smith.

ROBERT SMITH . I am a pensioner of the Royal Artillery, and live at Ship-stairs, Woolwich. The prisoner had lodged with me—I missed a black frock-coat and a waistcoat on the 24th of Jan. from a box in my room—these are them.
ROBERT HUNTER . I am a pawnbroker. I took this coat and waistcoat in of the prisoner, on the 24th of Jan., between five and six o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

1085.
JOSEPH RUSSELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Feb., 1 shovel, value 2s. 4d., the goods of
William Wheatley; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Month.

1086.
DAVID GOW and
HENRY DOWDELL were indicted for
stealing on the 24th of Feb., 1 spoon, value 8s., the goods of
George Warren Parsons.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be 2oz. of silver.

ELIZABETH ELLIS . I am servant to Mr. George Warren Parsons, who keeps the Crown and Cushion, at Woolwich. On Saturday night, the 25th of Feb., I missed a silver table-spoon—this is it—I can swear to its being my master's—I had seen the prisoners at our house—they were in the habit of coming.
Dowdell. Q. Did you not say before the Magistrate that you had never seen me on the premises? A. No, I never saw you, only Gow.

ANN SPURGE . I am the wife of William Spurge, a jeweller, who lives at Woolwich. On Friday evening, the 24th of Feb., Dowdell brought me part of this silver spoon, and I bought it of him—Gow afterwards brought this other part of the same spoon—I then thought it was not come by honestly, and I asked where he got it—he said he found it in some dust—I detained him, and called the officer.
JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant R 8.) About seven o'clock that evening I was passing Mr. Spurge's shop—I went in, and Gow was there—Dowdell had come out, and was waiting outside—I took them both.

Dowdell's Defence. I was standing at the waterside, and this man called me; he said, "I have got a silver spoon here, let us go and make sale of it;" "Is it any harm?" says I; he said, "No;" it was in three pieces.

GOW—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

DOWDELL—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

1087.
JOHN DAVIS was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM DANOERFIELD . I keep a public-house in Palace New-road, Lambeth. The prisoner was in my service about nine months—he was em
ployed to receive money on my account sometimes, from my regular cuto
mers—he usually paid me on a Saturday night, but there was no time in parti
cular—there was 3s. 2d. due from Mrs. Farrell—I directed the prisoner to recieve it on Saturday night, the 18th of Feb.—he did not return till the Tuesday night following—he was then intoxicated, and I said nothing to him that night—on Wednesday morning I asked if he had got any money for me he said no—there was then due to me 3l. 10d. for that week's account, exclusive of this 3s.—the 3l. 3s. 10d. was due from customers of his own—I allowed him a halfpenny a pot for selling it, but Mrs. Farrell's was a private account

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you got your account, out of which you claim this 3l.? A. I have not—I desired him to receive this 3s. about nine o'clock on Saturday night; the time for settling accounts, had then arrived—he lived on the premises—Mrs. Farrell's was a week's account—I did not give him the account—he was told the amount—I gave him 14s. a-week—I debited him with all the beer that he sold—I believe he sometimes gave credit—he came home about nine or ten o'clock on Tuesday night—he did not serve the customers—he laid down on the seat in the tap-room—he did not go about his work as usual next morning—I did not allow him—in
deed, he did not make the attempt—he was up in his own room—I did not see him till I went up at ten that morning—I said, "Have you got any money for me?"—I went to make the best terms could with him, to see what money I could get—when he said he had got no money, I said I would give him through the day to do the best he could, to see if he could get me some money—I did not specify any money in particular—I do not know whether he went out, but instead of his coming to make any terms, he came in front of my bar at night, drinking with some of the customers, thereby adding insult to injury—I do not know that I should have been satisfied if I could have got the 3l.—I should not have been satisfied without the whole of my money, or security for it—I gave him into custody about ten on Wed
nesday night—I had no quarrel with him before I did so—do not know whether he had been in the house all day—I did not inquire—I told the po
liceman to take charge of him for embezzlement—for the 3s. 2d.—I owe him his last week's wages—I did not tell him on Tuesday night that if he could get me security for the remainder of what was due to me, it would be all very well. nor anything of the sort.

ELIZABETH FARRELL . I live in Palace-street, North Lambeth. The pri
soner frequently brought beer to my house—he brought it on Saturday, the 18th of Feb., and I gave him 3s.—the week's account was 3s. 2d., but I had no halfpence, and said I would give him the 2d. next day, but he did not come again—I paid him the 3s. for Mr. Dangerfield—the prisoner did not apply for the money, I always paid him on Saturday night.
Cross-examined. Q. What time did he come? A. At nine o'clock—I live about two minutes' walk from the prosecutor—the prisoner appeared sober when I paid him.
JESSEE CANNON . I am a policeman. I received the prisoner in custody.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you take him? A. At the prosecutor's door about ten o'clock—he was standing talking to the prosecutor as I was passing by on the other side of the street, and he sent a man over to me to come and take the prisoner—he said he should give him into custody for money he owed him—that was the expression he used to me.

WILLIAM DANGERFIELD
re-examined. The prisoner was in the habit of paying me the weekly money due from Mrs. Farrell, every Saturday, as he received it—it was never mixed with other money.
NOT GUILTY .

1088.
WILLIAM POINTON was indicted
for a rape.
NOT GUILTY .

1089.
WILLIAM BROWN, alias Martin
, and
CHRISTOPHER TUCKER , were indicted for
falsely making 2 counterfeit shillings.

RICHARD RICE . I am an Excise-officer. In consequence of information on the 9th of Feb., I obtained a warrant, and on the 10th I went with it, with William and Thomas Hughes, M'Kay, Shakesby, and Frith, to No. 61, Princes-street, Lambeth, about a quarter after eleven o'clock in the morning—we knocked at the side-door twice—there was about a quarter of a minute between the two knocks—there are two doors, one in the street, and a side-door down an arch—the prisoner Brown opened the door—I asked for Mr. Jones, or Brown, or some fictitious name—he opened the door a few inches, saw me, and went to shut it again—we forced our way in—he left the door, and made his way towards the stairs—we secured him about half way up the first flight of stairs—he was taken down into the front parlour by myself and Thomas Hughes, and given into custody of a policeman—I then proceeded up stairs to the back room, first floor, and there saw a chair standing opposite the fire-place, with a board lying across it, and a fire-shovel with one end resting on the board, and the other between the bars of the grate—I saw some moulds with coin in them, and a great quantity of coins lying about—I put my hand on the moulds, and they were quite hot—there were two shil
lings in one mould, and one shilling in another—there was a pipkin on the fire, with white metal boiling in it, in a fluid state—I took it, and threw it on the floor—there was nobody in the room then besides me—some files and a knife were lying on the board, and two new metal spoons—some coins laid on the mantel-shelf—I saw about forty coins in the room altogether—I called Mr. Hughes into the room, and he took possession of all the articles.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You went on some information con
nected with the Excise I apprehend? A. Yes—the parties were working a private still—I went through every room in the house—there were three floors and seven rooms in it—I found two beds, one in the coining-room, and one in the back parlour—the other rooms had no furniture whatever—I found no female apparel about the first floor—I do not think there was any—Mr. Hughes was with me when I searched—I took possession of nothing besides these articles, which I considered suspicious—when I look Brown into custody he did not say he could not be bound by what his lodgers did, and did not know anything about it—I was not with him above a minute—he did not say in my pre
sence that he had a female lodger who had people coming to visit her—I saw no one in the house besides these two—I first saw Tucker down in the
still room, in the custody of the police—that was below, in the kitchen, I think.

THOMAS HUGHES . I am assistant to William Hughes, the supervisor of Excise. I accompanied the officers to this house on the day in question—I ob
served Brown open the door—I asked if Mr. Smith lived there—he attempted to shut the door, but I put my foot in, and it was forced in by Mr. Rice—when I got in, Brown made his escape towards the stairs—he got half-way up—I followed him, pulled him back, and, after a deal of difficulty, two or three of us got him into the front-parlour, and kept him in custody—he was in his shirt sleeves, which were tucked up—he asked for his coat, and said, "Do I know whether I came out of the still-room?" (meaning down stairs) "or from up stairs"—I told him, "From out of the still-room, (meaning down stairs)—he said he came down stairs, and not up stairs, I am sure of that—he was making his way up stairs when I went in—I went over the house after he was in charge of the police—I did not find anything—I did not observe any sign of paper-staining or paper-manufacturing—all the rooms were empty but the still-room, the coining-room, and the back kitchen—there were seven rooms-five were totally unfurnished—the still-room it on the ground floor, under the front parlour—that was one of the furnished rooms—the front par
lour was furnished—that would make three rooms furnished, the front parlour, another room, and the coining-room—there was a bed and bedstead, a box or two, and a chair, in the coining-room; also, a bed in the back parlour, and one in the front parlour—there were but two beds in the house.

Cross-examined. Q. Had he his coat off when you took him? A. Yes it was in the front parlour—I believe I have told you all the conversation I had with him—he did not tell me he could not be answerable for what his lodgers did—I am the son of Mr. William Hughes—I am not in the Excise, I am employed by him—I found the still going on, a thriving trade apparently—Tucker was found down in the still-room—I first saw him there.

WILLIAM HUGHES . I am a supervisor in the Excise. On the 10th of Feb. I accompanied the other witnesses to No. 61, Prince's-street—I guarded the front door, to see that no one came out, while the other parties made their entrance—I went in after them, and found Martin in custody of Rice and my son—they took him to the front parlour—I left him in custody of my son and the police, and proceeded after Rice, up stairs to the room, where I found the implements of coining—these are the articles, which I produce—this silver watch was lying in the centre, with two heaps of base coin, on the mantel-piece—the moulds were quite hot—I could not hold them in my hand at first—there were two impressions in one mould, and one in another—I produce a file, a knife, and a pipkin—when I left the room up stairs, I proceeded down stairs the under-ground kitchen or cellar, where I found Tucker, and the private still going on—I there found a quantity of spirits—I examined some ashes that were lying in the still-room, and found one of the base shillings un
finished, which I produce—this shilling was not kept apart from the others—they were all put together—it was rough in the edges—I also found some pieces of cuttings, or parings of metal, lying in the ashes—I did not take any notice of them—I left them there—they had a bright appearance, as if not long cut off—they had been melted—they had been pared off the shillings, I have no doubt—I asked Tucker how long he had been in the house—he said between three and four months—I asked him if the man Martin had been there the same time he had—he said they both came together—I then asked if he knew any thing about the coining going on up stairs—he said no, the business was carried on up stairs by the other man, Martin, and he did not know what he was doing there—I said it was impossible for the business to be carried on

up stairs without his knowledge—he said he did not know what he was doing—I then asked him if they were not partners—he replied, they were—I asked him about the shilling I found in the ashes—he seemed rather confused at the first moment, and stated after, they might be brought down in the ashes, a Martin used to bring his ashes down into that room—I do not believe he saw me rake it out—the front parlour had a few chairs in it, and a table—I found some papers in a cupboard, such as receipts for hats, which I did not remove—I also produce a receipt from the landlord, which I found in an ornament on the mantel-piece, in the front parlour—I went over the house—I did not see any thing of paper-staining or hanging going on—not the least—there was one bed in the coining-room, and there were two or three beds on one bedstead in the room below—the distance between the still-room and the coining-room is perhaps about ten yards.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose your cross-examination of Mr. Tucker took some time? A. Not a very little time—I might be five minutes in the questions I put to him—I have been in the Excise upwards of twenty-seven years—I did not arrange this conversation when anybody else was present—there were parties in the room—I cannot charge my memory, at the present time, who the parties were that were present—I am sure there were parties present, because they had not left the still-room—Tucker was with me in the still-room, the police, and also my brother officers—I cannot charge my memory with their names—they could not be very far off—the room was not three yards across—I cannot say whether my son or Rice was present, or the other witnesses—Martin was taken down out of the parlour into the still-room—I do not know whether he was present—it might be before he was taken down—I think there were persons in the room at the time—those were the words that I put to Tucker—I have told all that was said—I never heard a word about a female being up stain before this time from anybody—my information was connected with the private still and something else—I did not know where to find the still till I got to the house—I first went into a lobby which leads to the staircase—the first room I went into was the room up stairs, where the coining was going on—that was the first place I went to, after Brown was brought down stairs into the front parlour—I assisted in getting him into the parlour, and I bolted up stairs a quick as I could possibly go, leaving him with my son and the police—I think there was a gown, or something of that sort, which Tucker said belonged to his daughter—there was a little piece of very inferior linen, in a chest in Tucker's room) in the back kitchen, where the bed was, adjoining the still-room, going down to it.

JOHN CHARLES KAY . I was one of the Excise officers that went to the house—I remained outside for some time, to see that nobody escaped—when I went in 1 found the prisoner Brown in custody of Thomas Hughes, and the policeman, just coming off the stairs as I entered the house—I assisted Thomas Hughes in securing him—he became very restless—I told him to be quiet—we took him into the parlour, and got his coat—I left him for a moment, and ran up stairs, where the coining had been going on—I just cast my eye round on the things, but did not touch anything—Thomas Hughes called me down stairs, as Brown was very restless—I assisted in taking him down into the still-room, where I found Tucker—Thomas Hughes and one of the policemen was there—William Hughes came down then to me—I continued there for some time—I heard William Hughes say he had picked up a shilling while I was in the still-room—he was raking about the ashes at the time—Brown was there, at the time Hughes said he had found it—I did not hear the coversa
tion between William Hughes and Tucker—I heard him talking to him—I did not direct my attention to what was passing—my attention was chiefly
called to looking after the still, seeing there was no accident happened with that—I left my brother officers to attend to that.

THOMAS SHAKESBY (police-constable L 114.) I went to this house—Brown was given into my custody—I took him to the station, and then re
turned to the house—I went up stairs to the front room first floor, and found these things by the fire-place—I found this plaster of Paris at the right-hand side of the fire-place, in this state, in this box—I produce a tin band which was by the side of it, and a file, which I found in a box at the side—I after
wards went down stairs to the still-room, and found this crucible by the side of the still, and this iron spoon, in the back-kitchen, which is very near the still-room, it goes down the steps into the cellar—it is under ground, and this was the kitchen, just four or five steps above—I found some more plaster of Paris in a paper, in the coining-room—I did not make a minute search before I took Brown to the station—I left the Excise officers in posses
sion of the premises.
EDMUND FRITH (police-constable L 122.) On the 16th of February I received a small paper box, containing cuttings from William Guest.
RICHARD GLOAG (police-constable L 113.) On the 10th of Feb. I went to the house in Prince's-street—the four excisemen were there—I remained till ten o'elock at night, Etheridge then relieved me.
JOHN ETHERIDGE (police-constable L 35.) On the 10th of Feb. I went to this house—I staid from nine o'clock at night till Saturday morning—Tawerden then relieved me.

ALEXANDER TAHERDIN (police-constable L 57.) Early in the morning of Saturday, the 11th of Feb., I went to this house—I staid there three hours—Shaw relieved me—on the Monday following I went again—Shaw was there then—I went into the back-kitchen—seeing Shaw raking over the cin
ders, I took a stick, and picked up several pieces of metal, which I put into a box, which I returned to Shaw—I left him there.

JOHN INGS (police-constable L 22.) On Saturday, the 11th of Feb., I went to this house—I relieved Thomas Shaw—I staid from nine till six o'clock the following morning—Shaw returned to relieve me—I went again on Sunday evening at nine, and staid till six the following morning—Shaw then relieved me.

THOMAS SHAW (police-constable L 30.) On Saturday morning, the 11th of Feb., about nine o'clock, I went to this house, and staid till nine at night—Ings relieved me—I went there again at six the following morning, Sun
day—I relieved Ings, and remained there till I was relieved by Ings again—I went there again on Monday morning—I then understood that coining had been going on—that induced me to search—I went into the back-kitchen, and searched the fire-place—I found a quantity of metal cuttings—Taberdin came in afterwards, while I was raking among the ashes—I took a little box off the mantel-piece, put the cuttings into it, and kept it in my possession till the following Wednesday, the 15th—I took it to the superintendent's office and gave it to Sergeant Brown.
WILLIAM BROWN (police-sergeant L 9.) On the 15th of Feb. Shaw gave me this card box—I was sent for to the office, I gave it to him again—I do not know what became of it afterwards—this is it.

COURT. Q. Why could you not have kept it? A. I did not know any
thing of the case at the time.
THOMAS SHAW (re-examined). After Brown returned it to me I gave it to him again. Lupton took it, and afterwards I saw it in his possession.
HENRY LUPTON (police-sergeant L 7.) I received this box and gave it to Guest. I did not keep it, because I was ordered to go into West-square.

WILLIAM GUEST (police-constable L 62.) I received this box from Lup
ton and gave it to Frith.

JAMES RANDALL NASH . I am a barge builder. I am the owner of the house, 61, Prince's-street—about the first of Oct. the prisoner Brown called at my counting-house, with a friend, for the purpose of renting this house—I enquired what trade or business he intended to carry on in the premises—he told me a paper stainer—I let him the house; he was to pay 24l.—this receipt has my signature—I received the money from Brown on the lst or 2nd of Jan.
Cross-examined. Q. You went to receive the rent on one occasion, I believe? A. Yes, I saw a young woman there, and left a message with her for Brown.
MR. DOANE. Q. In consequence of that did you receive the money for your rent? A. Yes, it was paid by Brown himself.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This platterd of Paris mould is intended for casting two counterfeit shillings at one time—it has the impression of both sides of a shilling on it—it is in a condition to work—here are two counterfeit shillings which appear to have been cast in it—these appear in the state in which they first came out of the mould, with the get attached—the plaster of Paris and these moulds are of the same kind of material—this is another mould for casting shillings—it has a shilling cast in it—it has never been removed till this moment—this tin band is for the purpose of forming the mould—it appears to have been so used—there is plaster of Paris now in it—here are twenty-eight counterfeit shillings which appear to have been cast in the mould which now has the shilling in it—there is white metal in this pipkin, of a similar description to the counterfeit coin—it appears to have been in a fused state—these white metal spoons are corre
sponding metal to that in the pipkin and the counterfeit coin—they are known as Britannia metal—the crucible appears to have been used for the purpose of fluxing metal—it has a portion of metal of a similar description in it now—the files would be used for the purpose of removing any superfluous metal from the edge of the coin after first cast—they appear to have white metal in the teeth—here are some more clippings of white metal of a similar description—they appear to have been taken from the edges of the counterfeit coin after first cast—such particles would attach to the coin cast in these moulds, and must be removed by scissors, a knife, or file—these appear to be of that de
scription—here is a knife and files—there appears to be every thing neces
sary for coining—here are also five shillings cast in the double mould—they are different from the twenty-eight.

JAMES ALLEN . I have known the prisoner Brown two months. I know the house he lived in, No. 61—I have brought coke to the house and shot it in the bottom room, by Mr. Brown's orders—I have brought a bushel and half a hundred weight of coke up stairs, as far as the front door, and shot it in the cupboard on the left of the party that lived up stairs, by order of the party that lived in the room—she was a tall genteel woman dressed in black—I have seen her standing at the door—she lived in the room—she was standing there when I brought the coke and coal, and showed me the cupboard where to shoot it—on the Sunday after that I served her with a bundle of greens—I never was in the room in my life—I saw her at that time—she paid me for the things—I cannot tell how often I have been in the house; as often as they ordered me to bring things—I have not seen this woman in the lower room—I never saw Brown in the upper room.
Tucker's Defence. I worked the still since I went into the house, but I do
not know any thing about any thing else, not the least; all the ashes and other things were sent down to me in the cellar, and I took no notice of what is was.

WILLIAM HUGHES
re-examined. There were two doors to this house, a side door, and a door to the street; no other—I was guarding the front door and a window very near it, that no person might make their escape—Kay was standing at the side door—we were so stationed round the house that no one could escape—the windows were all fast down with the catch and not dis
turbed—I examined every part of the house, and am sure no one could have escaped without our notice.

J. C. KAY re-examined. I was stationed at the side door and window—it was impossible that any one could have escaped without my perceiving it—the other witness was at the front door—there is no other door, no back door—the back of the house butted on other premises.

Brown. There are two sliding windows to the top room, from which any body could escape; Tucker told Hughes that a woman went out three minutes before they came in, and they were not round the place then; I took the house, intending to work the still with Tucker as partner, and the upper part of the house was occupied by other people.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

TUCKER—
GUILTY . Aged 55.

1090.
MARY ANN LANDERS was indicted
for knowingly uttering a counterfeit shilling, having been previously convicted of uttering counterfeit coin.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am solicitor to the Mint. I produced a copy of the record of the conviction of Mary Ann Landers on the 9th of May, 1842, in this Court—I have examined it with the original in Mr. Clark's office—it is a true copy—(read.)
JOHN CHAPMAN WOREDRAPER (police-constable F 122.) I was present at the trial of Mary Ann Landers on the 9th of May, 1842—it was the prisoner, I am quite confident.

ELLIZABETH BURROWS . I live at No. 20, Upper Stamford-street. On the 24th of Feb., in the forenoon, I saw the prisoner looking at the window, holding up her hare-skins—I took a hare-skin to her—she was to give 2d. for it, and 4d. for kitchen stuff—she tendered me a shilling—I told her I had no change—she asked if I had anything else to make up the shilling—I produced four wine bottles which made up the amount, and she went away—I put the shilling into my pocket—I had no money of any kind in my pocket—a few minutes afterwards I gave it to the constable, John Meek.

COURT. Q. Were the whole of the things worth 1s.? A. Yes—she would not let me have the shilling till I gave her the bottles to make it up—I am certain she is the woman—I recollect her countenance so well—I had never seen her before—she was with me not quite ten minutes.

MARY TAYLOR . I am servant to Mr. North, of Stamford-street. On Fri
day, the 17th of Feb., about half-past eleven in the morning, the prisoner was standing at the door crying "Hare skins"—she bought one of me, and a small rabbit skin—I asked 4d. for them—she offered 3d., then she said she would give me 4d., and gave me a shilling—I gave her 2d. change—I was to give her 6d., but I had not got one—she said she would call on the Monday for the 6d.—she left the shilling with me—I put it into my pocket—I had no money in eiher pocket—directly I went into the kitchen I took it out, and took it to

the public-house to fetch some beer—they said it was a bad one—they knocked it double—I did not lose sight of it all—I informed my master, and showed him the shilling—he hammered it straight—on Friday morning, the 24th, I saw the prisoner again—master went out after her—I gave the shilling to Meek.

COURT. Q. Were the two skins worth 4d.? A. Yes—I do not think I ever saw the prisoner before—I am quite sure she is the woman by the look of her—she was with me about ten minutes—on the 24th she was brought to the house by the policeman—she went by the house about the same time as before, crying "Hare-skins" at every door—she cried it our door—she did not see me.

JOHN MEEK (police-constable M 48.) On the morning of the 24th of Feb. I saw the prisoner in Stamford-street—I received a communication from Mr. North, in consequence of which I took her into custody—I after
wards went to Mrs. Burrows, received this shilling from her, and one from Mary Taylor, which I produce—I found 1s. 7 1/2 d. on her, a good sixpence, and 13 1/2 d. in copper.
JOHN FIELD . These two shillings are both counterfeit—one has been very much battered—I suppose the other would be very easily detectd from its appearance.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Two Years.

1091.
ELIZA SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Feb, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Charles Ferguson; and 3 1/2 yards of lace, 11d.; the goods of
Robert Orme, her master.

MARY FERGUSON . I am the wife of Charles Ferguson; he lives in Breek
nock-street, St. Pancras—I lent this handkerchief to Mrs. Orme.

SARAH EMILY ORME . I am the wife of Robert Orme, of Gibson-street, Westminster-road, a haberdasher. The prisoner was our apprentice, and had been so for a year and a half—this is the handkerchief that Mrs. Ferguson lest me—I had it washed afterwards, and put in a drawer in which I always put such things—the prisoner could get to it—I frequently sent her there—I missed it on Thursday, the 2nd of Feb., when I was going to send it home—I inquired about it, and the next day I searched the prisoner's box in the pre
sence of the policeman—I found it there, and this piece of lace, which is my husband's—she unlocked her box herself in our presence with her own key—when these things were found she said she knew nothing of them—they must have been put there.
ELIZABETH WILD . I am shop woman to Mr. Orme. This piece of lace is his property—I had seen it safe on the Saturday before the handkerchief was missed.

WILLIAM GEAR (police-constable L 98.) I was called to Mr. Orme's on the 3rd of Feb.—the prisoner unlocked the box in my presence, and Mrs. Orme found the handkerchief, and then the lace—the prisoner said somebody must have put them in—I am sure the prisoner unlocked the box—she could not find the key at first, but she found it at the corner of the carpet, and un
locked it.

Prisoner's Defence. I did not know they were there—the key was by the side of the carpet when the policeman came up—I went into the City on the Wednesday after the Saturday, and left my box unlocked, and when I came
back it was locked—I never saw the handkerchief before—the lace was in the box on Monday morning, because I served from it.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Judgement Respited.

1092.
WILLIAM BOWLES and
ROBERT JONES were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of Feb., 220lbs. weight of coals, value 2s.; the goods of
Conrad Nohlgemuth, in a barge on the navigable River Thames; and that Jones had been before convicted of felony.

JOEL BARTON . I am wharf-clerk to Mr. Conrad Nohlgemuth, a coal
merchant at Crow's-nest Wharf, Lower East Smithfield—he had a barge called the William, at Hereford-stairs, on the 16th of Feb.—the coals in it were his property—there were about three tons in one room of the barge, and some Holy well coals in another room—I have examined the coals produced by the officers, and believe them to be my master's—I missed about half a ton from the barge.

JAMES WILLIAM GRIFFITH (Thames police-constable, No. 15.) At half-past six in the morning, on the 16th of Feb, I was on duty, and saw the two pri
soners alongside the barge William; one of them was in the barge, but I could not see which, and the other was in the boat—I made towards them, as soon as they saw me, the one in the barge jumped into the boat, and they rowed away—I followed, and got into their boat, and asked where they got the coals that were in their boat—there were about 224lbs. of coals there—they said they got them from a barge alongside the tier—but they had no business to take them from there—I went alongside the William, and in No. 2 room I found a basket and shovel—that was the room which the coals they had seemed to have come from—I compared the coals in their boat with those in the barge—they appeared to correspond in every respect, as near as I could judge—supposing them to have been taken from the plugs of a barge, as they said they had, they must have been wet, and they were quite dry, like those in the barge.
Bowles. You said if your mate had been quicker in the boat, I should not have seen you. Witness. I could not see which of you it was in the barge, it was not light enough; but I thought it was Jones.

JOSEPH SHAY (Thames police-constable, No. 40.) I was in the galley, and saw the prisoners row away from the barge—I took them to the barge, and the coals in their boat seemed to be the same as those in the barge.

Bowles's Defence. They rowed us from the barge about half an hour, and then they returned to the barge—the basket and shovel we know nothing about—the coals we had we got out of the plug of an old barge, with an old kettle.

Jones's Defence. We went down to an old barge, and looked down the plug—we got them in the boat—the boat shoved off—we could not keep her off this barge—we got on the thwart to shove her off, and the officers took us.
JAMES PECKHAM (police-constable M 229.) I produce a certificate of Jones's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.

BOWLES—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1093.
JOHN MANNIX was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Jan., 1 rasp, value 1s.; 1 hammer, 2s.; and 1 chisel, 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Twelvehee: and 166 pieces of wood, value 3l. 10s.; the goods of
Joseph Etherington, his master; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM HOWLETT . I am foreman to Joseph Etherington, of Morgan's-lane, Tooley-street—the prisoner was a labourer in his employ—in consequence of some circumstances I thought it necessary to set a watch, and after some time I searched the prisoner's house with a policeman—I found a quantity of mahogany, some other boards and wood, and wood bricks, and some other pieces, which appeared to have been cut off over night and taken away—they were my master's, and part of them are here—I can swear positively that this is Mr. Etherington's wood—this is a piece which I cut myself, and this is a tool made to cut mortices in—the value of the whole is 3l. 10s. or 3l. 15s.—I found a hammer and two chisels, one of which I can identify—the prisoner said I was quite at liberty to search his house—when I found these pieces of mahogany, I asked if he could look me in the face, and say that they were not Mr. Etherington's—he said, no; they were Mr. Etherington's, and he brought them off the premises.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. Mr. Etherington is in a large way of business? A. Yes—the prisoner has been in his employ since August—we make a great deal of wood, but not of this shape—I never did any like these since I have been in London—this piece I cut three days before, and these three pieces go all together, and form the bottom rail of a fencing to a gentleman's house—none of my master's men lodge in the prisoner's house—I did not make him any promise of forgiveness—I took this piece in my hand, asked if he did not bring it from his master's, and he said, "I did."
MR. ROBINSON. Q. When was this on your premises? A. This piece that he owned he took, had been on our premises about a month before—he said he took this piece, and these pieces of moulding.

PETER KENDALL (police-sergeant, No. 16.) I took the prisoner, and searched his house—I found a quantity of wood in all parts—this piece of mahogany was in a dog-kennel, and some old rags put over it—I found a quantity of tools—here is a rasp, a hammer, and two chisels—these were under the stair-case—I asked how he came in possession of so much wood—he said a car
penter lodged with him, and left him six months ago, and went to Dover; that he owed him some rent, and left him the wood—he tried to make his escape out of the window, and I took him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he make any resistance? A. No—it is a small house with four rooms—there are no lodgers in it, only him and his wife and son—I was searching under the stairs, and one of the carpenters said the prisoner was gone up stairs—I ran up, and he had got one leg out of the window.

THOMAS TWELVEHEE . I am a carpenter in the employ of Mr. Ethering
ton. Some of these tools are mine—I lost this hammer four months ago, and the others two months.

Cross-examined. Q. How long is it since you saw the tools? A. I saw this chisel and rasp in Christmas week—I know this rasp by a piece being broken off, to make it go into my chest—I do not know anything peculiar about this hammer—I have had it fifteen or sixteen months, and used it every day.

SAMUEL WOOD . I am a house smith. I sold the prisoner some tools above a month ago—there was a rasp, a band-hammer, two carpenters chi
eels, and a soldering-iron—I sold him this rasp—these chisels are wider than those I sold him—this hammer, I should say, I sold him.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Should you say it was two months ago? A. I should say from six weeks to two months—these tools had been in my possesion from five to six years—I am in business for myself—I sold these to the pri
soner,

as he said he thought he should do a little work at home—I showed him this part of the rasp, which I now have in my pocket, and he said he thought one like that would suit him—I sold him these because I have plenty of tools of this description—he gave me half a crown for the hammer, two chisels, and the rasp—I swear this hammer and this rasp were mine.
GEORGE WESTON . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—the prisoner is the man who was tried.

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1094.
ELIZABETH BROWN and
ANN CAMPLIN were indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 24lbs. weight of bread, value 3s. 9d., the goods of
Edward Thies.

EDWARD THIES . I am a baker, and live in Camden-street, Newington. On the morning of the 11th of Feb., about seven o'clock, my journeyman left me—he had given me no notice—I went with the officer, on the 11th of Feb., to Camplin's house, which is next to mine—the officer knocked at the door—Camplin refused to let him in—he said, if she did not open it, he would break it open—she then opened the door, and said, "O my God, what shall I do?" and she offered me a sovereign to say nothing further about it—I found there twelve 2lb. loaves on a bed, partly covered over—I have every reason to believe they were mine—I had directed some one to watch my premises.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you mean by partly co
vered? A. They were partly covered over on the bed, in the room on the ground floor—she seemed very much frightened.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What is Camplin? A. A shoemaker—my journeyman's name is John Radford—Brown had been in my service occasionally, and used to come for the waste for the pigs, and generally at the time the bread was hot in the morning—it is the custom to allow journeymen bread.

DONALD FRAZER (police-constable C 181.) On the morning of the 11th of Feb., between six and seven o'clock, I was watching the prosecutor's pre
mises—about seven I was at the back of the premises, and I saw Brown opening the bakehouse door—she had a pail in her band, which she placed outside the door—she then stood in the doorway—I saw Radford bring a quantity of bread, and give it to Brown—the yards of the prosecutor's house and Camplin's join each other—I did not see any thing of Complin at the time—as soon as Brown received the loaves from Radford she ran into Camplin's back-door immediately—I went to the front directly—I there saw Camplin standing in front, talking to a servant girl, who was taking down the shutters—Camplin then went in—I stopped a few minutes, and saw Camplin come out the prosecutor's shop-door in front—(I know the premises, she could get from the bakehouse out that way)—she then began to take down some of the pro
secutor's shutters—I then called the prosecutor, and went with him to Camp
lin's house—I knocked several times—Camplin would not let me in—she said at first there was a person in the house who was undressed—I knocked again, and she said she would not let me in—I began forcing the door, and then she opened it—I found twelve loaves on the bed, covered over, with the exception of three or four—they were quite hot, and some of them partly destroyed—I did not find any person undressed, but there was a girl there—I asked her whose bread that was—she said it was hers—I called in the prosecutor—Camplin was then greatly confused, and said, "O God, what shall I do?"

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How many loaves did you see deli
vered to Brown? A. Five or six—Brown went towards her home, and another officer took her.

FRANCES CHARTRES . I live next door but one to the prosecutor. On the morning of the 11th of Feb. I saw Brown bring some bread from the bake-house—Camplin was walking about in the yard, apparently watching—Brown came and joined Camplin—they both went into the back of the home occupied by Camplin, with the bread.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where is this yard of Camplin's? A. It joins the prosecutor's—Camplin was walking backwards and forwards, and she looked round into the bakehouse—I live next door to Camplin's, and was at my back window—the policeman was then gone to the front—the bread I saw was not that which the policeman saw given—it was then about seven o'clock—it was light—Camplin and Brown went into Camplin's house together—there is but one yard for Mr. Thies' and Mrs. Camplin's houses—Mr. Thies' bakehouse is at the end of the wash-house, and the bakehouse door fronts the wash-house of my house, because the wash-house projects—when Camplin was walking in the yard she was very near the bakehouse, and looked in several times—directly the policeman had left my house, and gone to the front, I went to my back window, and saw what I have stated.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where had the policeman been watching? A. In my father's wash-house—I saw Brown bring the bread from the bakehouse, and carry it into Camplin.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 52.

CAMPLIN—
GUILTY . Aged 53.

1095.
WILLIAM SMITH was indicted
for stealing on the 21st of Jan, 1 shawl, value 10s.; 1 apron, 1s.; 1 handkerchief, 1s.; 1 rule, 1s.; 1 shoe
maker's tool, called a frewet-wheel, 2s.; 1 shoemaker's tool, called a finish
ing-iron, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
George Robert Marsh, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

1096.
WILLIAM BROWN was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin.

CAROLINE DYER . My husband keeps a shop in Wellington-terrace, Spring-place, Wandsworth-road. On the 11th of Feb. the prisoner came for a 1/4lb. of sugar, he gave me a bad sixpence—I asked him where he got it from—he said his mother gave it him—I asked where his mother lived—he said, "Round there"—I said, "Round where?"—he said, in Frederick-place, South Lambeth, but he did not know the number—that her name was Brown—I sent Gastock to make inquiries—she came back, and said, in the prisoner's hearing, that she could not find any such person—I sent for the policeman—I gave the sixpence to my father.
JOHN MORGAN . I received the sixpence from my daughter—I held it in my hand till the policeman came, and I gave it him.

JOHN MENNIE (police-constable V 70.) I took the prisoner, and received this sixpence—I asked where he lived, he said, "Nowhere"—at the station I found on him this bad half-crown, wrapped in this bit of rag, and pinned inside the lining of his waistcoat—he made no remark.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1097.
JOHN WILLIAMSON was indicted
for feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 23rd of Dec., 1 bottle, value 2d.; and 1/2 oz, of oil lavender, 2s.; the goods of
John Fuller; well knowing them to have been stolen: against the Statute, &c.

JOHN FULLER . I am a chemist and druggist, and live in Crosby-row, Walworth—Weatherhead is in my service—he came the latter end of Oct., or the beginning of Nov.—I received information, and spoke to him on the 13th of Feb.—on the day after he made a communication to me, and in the after
noon I went with the officer, to a place called Camberwell-gate, where we saw the prisoner with a stall, containing cocoa-nuts—I gave him in charge—he asked me what for—I told him my name was Fuller, and he knew my boy better than he knew me—I left him with the officer, and went to his house with the sergeant—I found there this bottle of oil of lavender—I can swear to this bottle as mine, and I had oil of lavender of this description—there was about a shilling's worth of oil of lavender in it—on going to the station I said to the prisoner, "Where have you been in the, habit of getting your essences?"—he said, in the Borough, near a street which I understood was Trinity-street—(he would want them to put into his sweetmeats; they use a great variety of essential oils in sweetmeats)—I asked if it was at Mayne's—he said he didnot know, but he thought it was—I said, "When did you get it there?"—he said in the autumn of the year, mentioning, I think, Oct.—I said, "Where have you got them lately?"—he said Mr. Fuller's boy had brought him some—I said, "That is what I wish to know"—he then said, "I have paid for them."

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Then you said, "That is what I want?" A. Yes, and I was satisfied when I had obtained what I believed to be the truth—Weatherhead is now in Newgate—I fetched him out to go before the Grand Jury—I have not been to him in Newgate—I wished to see over Newgate, but they would not let me—when I went to the prisoner, he ap
peared to have given up business for the time, on account of the snow or sleet—I have 4000 or 5000 bottles, but not one like this one—the lip of this has been cut off apparently by a diamond—I suppose it is worth 1 1/2 d.—before I gave Weatherhead into custody I said to him, "I am determined to have justice; if it puts you to inconvenience it is your own fault, but I will give you every recommendation in my power"—I went to get him before the Grand Jury as I thought it would forward justice, as he could explain the matter—this essence that I found at the prisoner's was in a jar in an up-stairs room—it appeared to be a place where he makes his sweetmeats—his wife was in the house, but not in that room.

WILLIAM WEATHERHEAD . I am fourteen years old. I was in the employ of Mr. Fuller—I have known the prisoner for the last two years—I had known him before I went to Mr. Fuller—he sells sweetmeats about, and keeps a machine called a dolly—I saw him when I had been about a week at Mr. Fuller's, but he did not say anything to me then—I saw him again a little time afterwards—he then asked me if I saw such things lying about as essence of lemons or cloves, and oil of lavender—I said, "Yes"—he said if I got him such things as he wanted to use in his trade, he would put 2s. or 3s. in my way—I did not say anything to that—I know this bottle—I saw it in my master's cupboard—I put into it some oil of lavender, which I found in a small bottle on the shelf—I took it to the prisoner—I do not know on what day—I did not say anything to him, but I gave it him—he did not give me anything then, but on Christmas-day he gave me a sixpence, and on boxing-day

he gave me another sixpence—that was all the money he ever gave me—I have played at the dolly—I did so about the second Sunday, when he came to the shop, which he kept on Walworth-common—it was before Chirst
mas—when I lost I used to pay him, as I used to have a few halfpence on a Sunday—I did not pay him in any other way—when I won he used to pay me with peppermint, or anything in the shop—my master charged me with robbing him, and then I made a communication to him—the prisoner knew that I took this lavander from my master, because he asked me whether I saw such things about—he did not say anything about paying my master for them.

Cross-examined. Q. Where have you come from? A. From Newgate—I have been there a little more than a week—I have not been visited by any
body—I once lived next door to the prisoner—he is a housekeeper—he bore a good character—other boys played at this dolly as well as me, and they won sometimes—it is all by chance—when Mr. Fuller said if I would tell him the truth he would do what he could to get me off, I then told him the truth—I do not know that if I get the prisoner convicted that I am to walk home—I have no expectation about that—my master said if I told him the truth he would get me off—I was with Mr. Robinson, a shoemaker, for two years—I left him because I did not like the trade—I live with my mother, in Webb-street—she has not been to see me in Newgate—Mr. Fuller came for me to go before the Grand Jury—the prisoner gave me 1s., but he did not tell me to bring him a shilling's worth of this particular stuff—I told him I was at Mr. Fuller's—I know the prisoner uses things of this sort—he did not say, "As you are coming by my stall, bring me so much"—he told me to bring some, and he would pay me—I do not know what this oil of lavander was worth—I do not serve in the shop more than a pennyworth of anything—I did not tell him that this was damaged oil.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was the 1s. the prisoner gave you for that laven
der alone? A. No, for the three articles that I took him, 6d. on Christmas-day and 6d. on boxing-day—nothing had been said to me about the price I was to have.

WILLIAM ADSHEAD . I live with my father, in Prince's-row, Walworth. I have been in the prisoner's shop before and since Christmas—I remember seeing Weatherhead there one Sunday, about Christmas, and the prisoner passed 6d. to him—I have seen Weatherhead play with the dolly there several times.
JOHN ADSHEAD . I am Mr. Adshead's brother. I know the prisoner—I have seen Weatherhead at his house three or four times.

GEORGE BALLARD . I live in Portland-street, Walworth. I have seen Weatherhead at the prisoner's house, both before and since Christmas—I have seen him playing at the dolly, and have seen him take parcels there, but I do not know what was in them.
THOMAS BARNABAS DUNN (police-sergeant P 13.) I saw the prisoner taken into custody at Camberwell-gate.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

1098.
THOMAS NICHOLLS was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Feb., 2 half-crowns and 5 shillings, the monies of
Charles Poore, his master.
CHARLES POORE . I keep the sign of the Duke of Clarence, in Tooley-street.

The prisoner had been my barman for about five months—in con
sequence of information, I called in sergeant Parker, and marked 3l. worth of silver in his presence—it is my custom to clear the till at night, and to put into it 1l. worth of silver tied up in paper, 5s. loose, and 5s. in copper—our business begins at five o'clock in the morning, and the prisoner was there alone till breakfast time—we have a great morning business from potato-men and others—our average taking is from 9s. to 10s. in a morning—I had given the prisoner notice, and he was to quit my service on Tuesday, the 7th of Feb.—on the night before that, I gave 1l. worth of marked money to my housekeeper, Mrs. Birt, to place into the till—I do not sleep in the house, bat on the 7th I went to the house, and took a policeman with me—I told the prisoner I wished to search his box—he made no objection—the officer asked him if he had got any money about him—he said a few shillings, and that was all—the officer asked him to show him the silver—he pulled his purse out—it contained 22s. or 23s., and amongst them were two half-crowns and five shillings that were marked with the marks I had put on the money I gave my housekeeper—he was then asked if he had any more money about him—he said, "No, I have no more"—the officer then searched him, and found two shillings and a sixpence folded in paper—one of the shillings was marked—he was asked bow they came in his pocket, and made no answer—with respect to the other money, he said that he had got change for a sove
reign that morning.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did he apply to you for his wages? A. He came down for his wages—a little more than 4l. is due to him for two months and a fortnight—I was to pay him quarterly—it is not unsual to pay every week—I paid him 5l. in Dec.—I have not paid him the 4l.—I have his clothes—I am ready to give them up, but I have not been applied to—I think the exact expression he made use of when he was asked what he had got in his pockets, was, "A few shillings in silver"—he did not say "somesilver"—he said "a few shillings"—I swear he used the word "few"—he pulled a bad half-crown from his pocket, and put it on the mantel-piece—that had no business in his pocket.

JAMES HAMS (police-constable K 248.) I was stationed near the prose
cutor's house on Tuesday morning, the 7th of Feb., at a quarter before six o'clock—I remained there till half-past nine—upwards of twenty persons went into the house—on that same evening I was called into the house by the prosecutor—I was present when he asked the prisoner if he had any objection to have his boxes searched—he said no—I went up to the kitchen where the boxes were—the prisoner put a bad half-crown on the shelf—I then asked him what money he had about him—he said, only a little silver—I desired to see it—he produced a purse from his left hand pocket with 22s. 10d. in silver in it—Mr. Poore said, it seemed to be a good deal—the prisoner said it was only a few shillings—I produce the two half-crowns, and four shillings which were marked—I said, "This looks black against you, this is marked money"—he said, "I changed a sovereign this morning"—I said, "Your giving change for a sovereign would not bring the marked money into your pocket, you would hare paid it to the customer"—he made no answer—I said, "Have you anything more about you?"—he said, "No"—I said must search you"—I felt in his left hand waistcoat pocket, and found two shillings and sixpence more, and one of the shillings was marked—I said, "Here is some more marked money, how do you account for this?"—he said in a low tone, "I do not know"—we then went down to the bar parlour to the housekeeper—Mr. Poore asked her in the prisoner's presence if there was a sovereign in the till—she said, "No, but there is a

half-sovereign"—the prisoner could hear that—I then took him to the sta
tion, and as we were going he said, "I made a mistake, it was a half-soverign I changed this morning; if Mr. Poore looks into the till he will find one"—he stopped till Mr. Poore came up, and told him—that was about five minutes after he heard the housekeeper say there was a half-sovereign.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you correct in saying how many persons went into the house that morning? A. There were more than twenty—I could not say whether they had anything or no—persons might go in to light their pipes only.

SARAH BASS . I am housekeeper to the prosecutor. On the Monday night, I cleared the money from the till after the business of the day was closed—I then put some money in to begin business on the following morn
ing—I put into the packet or paper 1l. worth of silver, which had been all marked by my master—I put in 5s. in shillings and sixpences loose, and 5s. in copper—the business begins about five in the morning, and the prisoner has the management of the bar from that time till breakfast—at half-past nine on the Tuesday morning I went to the till—I found a half-sovereign in the gold box which had not been there the night before, and found 10s. in the paper where 1l. of silver had been the night before—the half-sovereign was separate from the silver—the gold box is kept locked—it is in the same drawer, but in a separate division—there was very little increase above the 30s., that I had left in the till—there was not above 32s. or 33s.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you take the money out and count it? A. I did not take it in my hand, but I could see what there was—I had not my spectacles—I could see that without them—I swear that at half-past nine o'clock, there was not 5s. in addition to the money I had left—there might have been 4s.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you examine the till to look? A. Yes—the till is large, you can see what is in it without taking it out—I am quite sure it did not exoeed what I have stated—about 8s. or 9s. are usually taken at the counter till half-past nine—I was not there that morning till half-past nine.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you remember the Monday or Tuesday morning previous? A. No, I do not remember any particular morning—some morn
ings there were 9s. or 10s.—Mondays and Tuesdays there is not quite so good as others.
NOT GUILTY .

1099.
GEORGE WALKER and
ELLEN GILBERT were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of Jan., 300 eggs, value 18s., the goods of
George Miles, the master of the said
George Walker.

GEORGE MILES . I am an egg merchant, and live in Ebury-place, Pimlico. Walker was in my service for four or five months—it was his duty to go round with the cart to sell eggs—he took out so many every morning—they were counted out to him—I counted them to him on the morning of Tuesday, the 24th of Jan.—I sent out 2900 eggs, and he returned in the evening with 1900—he gave an account of where he had sold 700, which we do not dispute—I asked where the other 300 were—he could not account for them that day, but at the latter end of the week he wanted his wages, and I said I could not pay him till he accounted for these 300 eggs—he then said, did I not see them in the book?—I said, "No"—he said a person of the name of Grayson bad come and taken them out of the cart—I had a customer named Grayson—the pri
soner had a book which he carried with him, and he has booked the 300 eggs to Grayson on the Friday following—here is the entry, "300 eggs, 6s."—in con
sequence

of information from the police I went to a house in Windmill-street, New-cut, in company with the policeman—I found the prisoner Gilbert there, and 2411 eggs in baskets—the baskets belonged to me, and I believe the eggs to be mine—there was one basket of mine there which contained 300 eggs, all but three.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Walker had been in your service about four months? A. Yes, this last time—he took out eggs and other things to sell to anybody—not to any one particular customer—if he had sold these to any person of the name of Grayson they would have been pro
perly sold—I do not know that he has been in business for himself—he has never charged himself with goods to my knowledge—when he came home on the 24th of Jan. he produced his book to me—the name of Grayson was not in it then—it was on the 27th that he entered the goods sold on the 24th—here is no entry in this book on the 24th—I have been in business where I now am for four or five months—before that I was in business in Broadway, Westminster—about twelve months ago I passed through the Insolvent Court—I was then out of business for some time.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Were you at all aware, or did Walker give you reason to believe, that he was carrying on any other business but yours? A. No, I never sanctioned his carrying on any business in such articles as I deal in—when he returned he was to account to me for the eggs he took out, by giving me the money or the names of responsible persons—I gave him a discretion to sell to strangers, and give them credit, if he thought proper—Mr. Grayson lives in John-street—the basket that was found at Gilberts had recently been in my possession—it had only been imported into this country about six weeks.

HENRY LUPTON (police-sergeant L 7.) At the latter end of Jan. and the beginning of Feb. I watched a street near the premises in which Gilbert lives. On the 1st of Feb. I noticed a cart there, and the two prisoners were with it—I have noticed articles taken out of that cart in White Horse-street, where the cart stood, and they were carried by Gilbert to No. 11, Windmill-street—Walker gave her the articles out of the cart—on Saturday, the 4th of Feb., I went with the prosecutor to No. 18, Windmill-street—there was a hamper found there containing 300 eggs, all but three.

SAMUEL HARRIS (police-constable L 177.) Windmill-street, New-cut, is in my beat. I have seen Walker draw up with a cart in White Horse-street, and have seen Gilbert there at the time—this was done frequently during different weeks in the month of Jan.—I have seen Gilbert talking with Walker at the cart, and I have seen parcels taken out of the cart by Gilbert—the cart was then twenty or thirty yards from No. 18, Windmill-street—it is a mile and a half from the prosecutor's—I afterwards received Gilbert in charge—she was told by another officer what it was for—she said she certainly had fetched things from Walker's cart, and was very sorry for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell me when in January you had seen any
thing? A. I cannot give any date—I did not tell Gilbert that these goods had been stolen from Mr. Miles—she said to a woman who was in her company that she was sorry for Walker; she certainly had fetched things from the cart.

GEORGE GRAYSON . I live in St. John-street, Clerkenwell, and am a cheesemonger. I deal with Mr. Miles—I had no dealings with him in January last—the last I had was a week before Christmas I think—I did not buy 300 eggs of Walker or of Mr. Miles on the 24th of Jan.—I think the last things I had of Mr. Miles were eggs—I know Walker by his calling on me—I have dealt with Mr. Miles through him—I suppose he was aware I was a customer of Mr. Miles.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you had dealings with Walker on his own ac
count? A. Not to my knowledge—I am not indebted to him 2l. 8s. for goods I have had of him to my knowledge—I have not dealt with him on his own account—I had 600 eggs on the 6th or 8th of Jan.—I had then from Walker on account of Mr. Miles—I think I had no bill of parcels with them—they were only delivered to me—I have had several other dealings with Walker—not on his own account—I should say it was three or four months since I first began to deal with him—I think I have the tickets in my pocket—(producing them)—here is one, "Mr. Grayson to George Miles, Dec. 2," and some others—they are all Walker's writing, and all "to Mr. Miles"—to the best of my knowledge I am the only person of the name of Grayson in my trade—I never knew that Walker dealt on his own account for any thing—some of these bills are dated in Oct.—I knew Walker six or seven years ago—he lived with Mr. Miles, then left him and came back.

FRANCES DAVIES . I keep the house No. 18, Windmill-street, where the officers searched—Gilbert lived in the room in which the property was found—I have seen Walker there frequently—I know he has been there since Christmas—I have seen him several times—on occasions of his coming Gilbert has gone out—I have seen a cart pass the door, and have seen Mrs. Gilbert bring in baskets almost directly after Walker came—he seldom came to our place with the cart, it generally stopped at the corner of White Horse-street—I have seen it there—he never stopped at our door with it—he could have done so—it is a carriage-way, and then Gilbert would have had the convenience of receiving the things at the door; but she brought them from the end of the street.
Cross-examined. Q. What it was she carried you do not know? A. No.

GEORGE MILES
re-examined. My cart had my name on it.

Cross-examined. Q. Walker was in your service some years ago? A. Yes, he might have been with me then twelve or eighteen months—since then I have taken the benefit of the act, and when I began to recover I took him again, knowing him to be an active, industrious, worthy servant.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I took Walker into custody—I told him I took him for robbing his master, Mr. Miles, of a quantity of eggs, flats, and other articles—he said he had not robbed his master, and knew nothing about any eggs—I searched him, and found on him this key—I have seen a cart at the corner of White Horse-street in Feb., with the name of George Miles, Little Ebury-street, on it—I have seen Walker with it, and I have seen him and Gilbert in a public-house near where the cart was standing—I found on Walker this 2l. 18s. 6d., and some duplicates.

MR. MILES. This key found on Walker belongs to my warehouse—I had lost it, and inquired about it—I am not certain whether I had asked Walker about it—he had business in my warehouse while he was in my employ, but he had no business with this key.
Cross-examined. Q. It is an ordinary key? A. Yes—the warehouseman lost it, and I was obliged to get a new one.
Gilbert's Defence. I knew Mr. Walker was in the habit of dealing for himself, and he has left full and empty baskets with me—I have taken them in at night, and brought them out in the morning.

WALKER—
GUILTY . GILBERT—
NOT GUILTY .

1100.
GEORGE WALKER was again indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Jan., 64lbs. weight of butter, value 3l.; the goods of
George Miles, his master.
GEORGE MILES . The prisoner was in my employ—it was his duty to take out goods to sell on my account, and to account to me for them. On the

23rd of Jan. he took out a large quantity of goods, and when he returned he made this entry in his book, in which he charges Mr. Brown with thirty-two lumps of butter, at 11s. 6d. a dozen—a lump weighs 2lbs.—there were 64lbs. of it, which would come to about 3l.—when I made the search at Windmill-street, I found about 1 1/2lbs. of butter in this basket, in which I sent out butter, and which I recognised as mine—this butter is kept in flats—that was the way in which it was the prisoner's duty to take it our for sale—one flat would take out thirty-two lumps—I found some flats of mine at the house in Windmill-street.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. And did you find any that were not yours? A. Yes; about as many of one sort as the other—flats are not all like one another—I cannot speak particularly to any flat that took out the butter on the 23rd of Jan.
COURT. Q. None of your flats had any business there? A. No.

JOHN BROWN . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Walworth-road—I am in the habit of dealing with Mr. Miles occasionally, and Walker supplied me with goods—he did not, on the 23rd of Jan., leave me any goods—I did not buy at that time thirty-two lumps of butter—I have not bought any thing of him for five or six months—I have not bought any thing of him on his own account for eighteen months or two years.

SAMUEL HARRIS (police-constable L 177.) In Jan. I saw Gilbert and the prisoner together, when the cart was in White Horse-street—I have seen Gil
bert talking to him, and have seen her leave with different parcels—I have seen her take things of the size of a flat.
COURT. Q. Do you remember the 23rd of Jan.? A. I do not recollect the day, but in the month of Jan. I have seen goods carried from the cart.

Cross-examined. Q. You never took any memorandum of the day? A. Not in the month of Jan.—I took a memorandum of the 3rd of Feb., but what was done on the 23rd of Jan., or any other particular day, I do not know.

THOMAS BAISLEY . I am a cheesemonger, and live in William-street, Westminster. I know the prisoner—I think he delivered me thirty-two lumps of butter on the 23rd of Jan., on account of Mr. Miles—I owe Mr. Miles the money for it, and am ready to account for it any time the bill comes forward.

COURT. Q. He left no bill, then? A. No—I never had any transaction with Mr. Miles—I have bought things of the prisoner before, and paid him for them—I bought this butter for my brother—I was not known to Mr. Miles as a customer—I never paid him a farthing—I have seen him at his shop—I have known him by sight these four years—I have not made any entry in my books against myself of this transaction, as bought of Mr. Miles—I bought this butter for my brother, who is here, and if the bill had been produced, he would have paid it—I have charged my brother with this butter, in my books—they are not here—I am not in business for myself—I am shopman to my brother—I did not make any entry in my brother's book—he always pays for every thing I buy when the bill is presented.

Q. How would anybody be able to pay, if the name is not put down? A. I do not know but what the name is put down—my brother is indebted to Mr. Miles for this—at least he has had the butter, and there was no bill of parcels with it—my brother was not at home at the time.
MR. CROUCH. Q. Did you ever deal with Mr. Miles before? A. I have dealt with the prisoner—I always paid ready money before—the date of this

transaction was the 23rd of Jan.—I knew where Mr. Miles lived—I have been to his shop before—I was in the service of my brother—I never bought of the prisoner on credit before, but I did not pay him then, because I had not money in the house, and he said he should call in a week—the butter came to about 3l.—I think there were 64lbs., at 1 1/2 d. a pound—it was is a flat—thirty-two lumps—2lbs. in a lump.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Above two years—he always bore a good character, as far as I know.

GEORGE MILES
re-examined. I know Mr. Baisley. The prisoner had never sold anything to him on my account—he never gave his name as a purchaser—I saw my cart drawn up by the end of the street he lives in—pulled up behind it, and saw Walker coming out—I asked what he had been doing there—he said he had only been up there—I never had the name of Baisley reported as a customer to me—Baisley's brother lived with me, and this one is out of place—they are idleing about, and it is my opinion they have taken the goods and sold them between them.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

1101.
MARY ANN PRICE was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of Feb., 2 planes, value 5s., the goods of
William Walters; 1 plane, 4s., the goods of
James Clark; and 1 plane, 2s., the goods of
Charles Henry Wood and another: and
ANN PRICE
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

EDWARD JAMES CLARK . I am apprentice to Charles Henry Wood, at Bermondsey. We had some planes safe on the 24th of Feb., about five o'clock, and they were missed about twenty minutes to six—these are then—this one is mine—it was on the bench at Mr. Wood's shop.
JAMES SAXBEY . I am shopman to Mr. Martin, a pawnbroker. I saw Stone take in these three planes to pledge from the prisoner Ann Price.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Are you quite sure she is the person? A. I am certain—I had seen her once before—nothing particular directed my attention to her—we might have had one or two other customers in the shop—there are three shopmen—I came up and spoke to Stone while he was taking in the pledge, and that was how I saw the prisoner—it was be
tween seven and eight o'clock in the evening—the gas was lighted—she was in a box which had the gas close by—I do not know what dress she had on—I had seen her two or three days before—she brought me a pledge which I told her would not suit me.

SAMUEL JOHN STONE . I am shopman to Mr. Martin, a pawnbroker. These three planes were pawned by Ann Price on Friday evening, the 24th of Feb., at half-past seven o'clock—this is the one that Clark swore to as his.

Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear she is the person? A. Yes, posi
tively—I had not seen her before.
NOT GUILTY .

1102.
MARY ANN PRICE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Feb., 1 plane, value 2s., the goods of
William Walters; 1 plane, 4s., the the goods of
Edward John Clutterbuck; and 1 plane, 4s., the goods of
Wil
liam Crawley.
