EDWARD JOHN CLUTTERBUCK . I work for Mr. Wood. On Saturday morning, the 25th of Feb., I saw the prisoner come at ten minutes before eight o'clock, with a basket and a mug of coffee for Crawley, one of the workmen—
she passed through the shop I was in, and went into another shop on the left hand.

JAMES CLUTTERBUCK . I also work for Mr. Wood. I was at work there with Walters on the morning of the 25th of Feb.—I saw the prisoner come in, and go into another shop to take Mr. Crawley's breakfast—she had a bas
ket with her—she then came to our shop, and took two smoothing-planes from the bench I was at work at, put them into the basket which she had in her hand, and went off the premises—I followed, and took her about a hun
dred yards off—she was running—she had these three planes, two in her basket, and one under her arm—one is William Walters's, this is William Crawley's, and this is Edward Clutterbuck's.
Cross-examined. Q. She took these, and went away? A. Yes—she was in the habit of bringing breakfast to Mr. Crawley.

WILLIAM SAVAGE (police-constable M 66.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody—these planes ware delivered to me by James Clutterbuck.
EDWARD CLUTTERBUCK . This plane is mine.
(The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to provide for her.)

GUILTY . Aged 12.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Eight Days.

1103.
CHARLES TUCKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Feb., 1 ring, value 1l.; 2 handkerchiefs, 8s.; 5 sovereigns, 1 half-sove
reign, and 1 piece of foreign silver coin, called a quarter-dollar, 1s.; the pro
perty of
David Ballance, from his person.

DAVID BALLANCE . I am bar-man to Thomas Ballance, who keeps the Red Lion, Ratcliffe-highway. On the 12th of Feb. I went with a party to Croydon, in a one-horse phaeton, and on our return to Tulse-hill, I was upset, and considerably injured—Miss Shepherd was with me, and Mr. and Mrs. Renton—I was taken into a stable—before I was taken in there the prisoner had come up—he said he was a particular friend of mine, and he gave his card—I could hear what he said, but I was unable to make an answer—a fly was procured, and I was taken home—I had 5l. 10s. in gold, 17s. in silver, and two Spanish coins—I had a ring on my finger—I missed that ring—I had a black dress-coat and two silk handkerchiefs—I missed some money and my handkerchiefs—I got information, and went to No. 2, New
ington-causeway—we knocked for an hour and a half, and got admittance at last, through the prisoner's brother, Douglass—he knocked at the door, and the prisoner opened it—I told the prisoner I had come to remunerate him for his trouble, and to ask him if he could give me any account of the articles missing, as I had lost a black dress coat, two handkerchiefs, a ring off my finger, 2l. 10s. in gold, and some silver—when I mentioned the ring, he said he knew nothing about it—I said, "Did you not see it on my finger?"—he said, "No"—I asked if he saw any one take it off—he said, "No"—I said, "Did you not take it off yourself?"—he said, did I mean to throw a slur on his character?—I told the officer to speak to him—he asked him two or three times over, and at last he produced the ring from his waistcoat-pocket—it was mine—we also found my two silk-hand
kerchiefs and the foreign coin—I had a foreign coin similar to this, and this ring I know to be mine.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Is it a ring you had worn some time? A. Yes, about three months—I had this coin, or one like it, for the last twelve

months—it is a Spanish quarter-dollar—it was not dark when the accident oc
cured, it was moonlight—it was on Sunday night—the prisoner called on the next day, and came again on the Tuesday—I then had some conversation with him—I was not up when he came on the Monday, and I saw him again on the Friday—he had given his card at the time of the accident—it was his right address—he did not tell me that he had expended a sovereign in get
ting a fly—he demanded 1l. 1s. 6d. on the Monday for procuring a fly, but he did not procure it.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did he tell you he had any money of yours in his possession? A. No—I was to give him the 1l. 1s. 6d. for bringing him home—I asked him about my things on the Tuesday—I did not on the Friday.

WILLIAM RENTON . I am a tallow-chandler, and live in Park-place, Wal
worth. On the 12th of Feb. I accompanied Mr. Ballance, Miss Shepherd, and Mrs. Renton, to Croydon—we were overturned in the Norwood-road, between ten and and eleven o'clock at night—I was slightly hurt—the prisoner came up, and assisted in taking up Mr. Ballance—he gave me his card, and said he was a particular friend of Mr. Ballance—I saw him take the watch and guard from Mr. Ballance, and the pin—I demanded them of him, and he gave them to me—I asked him to give me back the property, and he gave me three sovereigns—I had not see him take any money from him—I went home in the fly—I do not know who paid for it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not give you the purse with the half-crown and half-sovereign in it? A. He did.

WILLIAM BENTON . I am coachman to Mr. Retford; he keeps flies. On the 12th of Feb. a chaise was upset, and I volunteered a fly—I saw the pri
soner take some money out of Mr. Ballance's pocket—I heard him count it—he got out of the fly, and said he would take the gold from the silver—he counted five sovereigns.

Cross-examined. Q. Was Mr. Renton there? A. There was only Mr. Ballance, the cabman and me—Mr. Renton was in the stable-yard, assisting the lady who was hurt—I was quite sober—the policeman did not take any notice of me, that I am aware of—I was not taken up for being drunk—I took Mr. Ballance home—I then took the prisoner back to Walworth, and he asked me to go and have something to drink, which was ale and gin, and by the effect of that I was stupified—I never received any money—I do not recollect taking any money at all.

ABRAHAM TEARSE . I am a house-agent, and live at Norwood. I was near where this accident occurred, on the night of the 12th of Feb.—the party had just left my house before the accident happened—I saw the prisoner standing behind Mr. Ballance, assisting him after the accident, and I saw him take the ring off his finger—I cannot tell what he did with it—Mr. Chapman, the sur
geon, was attending to Mr. Ballance at the time.

JOSEPH PRICE (police-sergeant H 15.) I went with Mr. Ballance to the prisoner's house, in Surrey-place, Newington—I knocked repeatedly, but did not get in for above an hour and a half—I found his brother near the Elephant and Castle—his brother got in by giving a gentle tap at the door, and putting his mouth to the keyhole—that brought the prisoner—when I went in the prisoner was without his coat or shoes—Mr. Ballance said he had come to re
munerate him for his trouble—he mentioned about his ring, handkerchief, and coin—the prisoner said he had not got them, and knew nothing of them—I then told him I was a police-officer, and I should take him into custody for taking a ring from Mr. Ballance's finger—he said he had not seen it—he kept fingering his waistcoat pocket, and I told him to keep his finger out—he then wanted to

speak to his brother—I told him he might, but in my presence—he then said he had Mr. Ballance's ring, and produced it from his waistcoat pocket—I found this coin on him, and the two handkerchiefs were found by another officer—he gave no account of how he came by them.

WILLIAM COCKRILL (police-constable L 108.) I found one of these hand
kerchiefs in desk at the prisoner's, and the other was brought the next morn
ing by his brother.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you happen to know that a man has been charged with committing assaults on the prisoner? A. Yes, a man who has been in partnership with the prisoner's brother—I took the man into custody three times myself.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Three Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, APRIL 3RD, 1843.
